abstract: The Bcl-2 family of proteins are key regulators of programmed cell death. A distinct subfamily of BH3-only molecules has been identified, but their exact mechanism of action remains unclear. Here we show that the BH3-only Bcl-2 family members, Dp5/Hrk and Bim, are induced upstream of the Bax checkpoint in neuronal apoptosis in a manner that shows significant dependence on JNK signaling. We also show that Dp5 and other BH3-only proteins kill cerebellar granule neurons in a Bax-dependent manner. These studies demonstrate that BH3-only members do not act independently in their proapoptotic activities but rather require the action of multidomain proapoptotic Bcl-2 family members to produce cell death. The Bcl-2 family of proteins are key regulators of programmed cell death. A distinct subfamily of BH3-only molecules has been identified, but their exact mechanism of action remains unclear. Here we show that the BH3-only Bcl-2 family members, Dp5/Hrk and Bim, are induced upstream of the Bax checkpoint in neuronal apoptosis in a manner that shows significant dependence on JNK signaling. We also show that Dp5 and other BH3-only proteins kill cerebellar granule neurons in a Bax-dependent manner. These studies demonstrate that BH3-only members do not act independently in their proapoptotic activities but rather require the action of multidomain proapoptotic Bcl-2 family members to produce cell death. Bcl-2 homology nerve growth factor green fluorescent protein c-Jun N-terminal kinase 8-(4-chlorophenylthio)-adenosine 3′:5′-cyclic monophosphate brain-derived neurotrophic factor insulin-like growth factor-I Bcl-2 family members are defined functionally as either proapoptotic or antiapoptotic based on their ability to kill or protect cells in vitro and on the effect of gene deletion on cell death and tissue homeostasis in vivo. Bcl-2 family members share a number of conserved motifs known as Bcl-2 homology (BH)1 domains. In general, antiapoptotic molecules contain BH1–4. Proapoptotic molecules can be divided into two groups, multidomain proteins containing BH1–3 and the BH3-only subfamily. The functional and evolutionary segregation of the BH3-only subgroup from the rest of the family members is evident inCaenorhabditis elegans. The mammalian caspase and Apaf-1 gene families are represented by single genes in the roundworm, but the Bcl-2 gene family is represented by two genes: a Bcl-2-like Ced-9 containing multiple BH domains and the BH3-only family member Egl-1. Egl-1 was identified in a screen for worms defective in egg-laying. The mechanism for this defect is a gain of function resulting in the ectopic death of hermaphrodite-specific neurons (1Conradt B. Horvitz H.R. Cell. 1999; 98: 317-327Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). Egl-1 loss of function results in a block in all somatic cell deaths, a phenotype similar to that of the Ced-3 and Ced-4 mutants (2Conradt B. Horvitz H.R. Cell. 1998; 93: 519-529Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (512) Google Scholar). Interestingly, Egl-1 is not necessary for germ cell death despite the necessity of Ced-3 and Ced-4 in this process (3Gumienny T.L. Lambie E. Hartwieg E. Horvitz H.R. Hengartner M.O. Development. 1999; 126: 1011-1022Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), either indicating that furtherC. elegans BH3-only proteins exist or pointing to distinct biological pathways in cell death that exist in somatic and germ cells. The genetic model in C. elegans places the BH3-only Egl-1 upstream of the Bcl-2 family member containing multiple domains, Ced-9. Egl-1 is up-regulated transcriptionally in cells destined to die (1Conradt B. Horvitz H.R. Cell. 1999; 98: 317-327Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar). In healthy cells, TRA-1 inhibits Egl-1 expression. The Egl-1 gain of function mutant does not have an altered open reading frame but rather is mutated in a region of DNA that governs TRA-1 inhibition. Egl-1 binds Ced-9, disrupting the Ced-9/Ced-4 interaction and freeing Ced-4 to activate the caspase Ced-3. Although C. elegans has provided much useful information, the role of BH3-only proteins has become more diverse in vertebrate systems. In other words, the BH3-only gene family has evolved to respond to a variety of stimuli in different cell types via distinct mechanisms. Furthermore, the biochemical coupling of Bcl-2 proteins to caspase activation differs in C. elegans and vertebrate cells. The latter require efflux of cytochrome c from the mitochondria to activate caspases in the cytosolic apoptosome, whereas in C. elegans Ced-3 activation does not appear to involve cytochrome c. Several of the mammalian BH3-only Bcl-2 family members appear to be activated via different stimuli. Preexisting Bid is activated post-translationally via cleavage by caspase-8/FLICE in response to Fas or TNF receptor activation (4Li H. Zhu H. Xu C.J. Yuan J. Cell. 1998; 94: 491-501Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3787) Google Scholar). The truncated Bid cleavage product, p15, acts at the mitochondria to cause cytochrome c release (5Luo X. Budihardjo I. Zou H. Slaughter C. Wang X. Cell. 1998; 94: 481-490Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (3078) Google Scholar), although the exact mechanism for cytochrome c release is unknown. Bad is another BH3-only member post-translationally modified. In healthy cells, Bad is phosphorylated by the prosurvival kinases Akt and protein kinase A (6del Peso L. Gonzalez-Garcia M. Page C. Herrera R. Nunez G. Science. 1997; 278: 687-689Crossref PubMed Scopus (1986) Google Scholar, 7Datta S.R. Katsov A. Hu L. Petros A. Fesik S.W. Yaffe M.B. Greenberg M.E. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 41-51Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (552) Google Scholar). In the phosphorylated form, Bad is sequestered in the cytosol by 14-3-3. Upon apoptotic stimuli, Bad becomes dephosphorylated, is released from the 14-3-3 tether, and is, therefore, free to perform its apoptotic function at the mitochondria. Bik is another BH3-only family protein the phosphorylation of which regulates biological activity (8Verma S. Zhao L. Chinnadurai G. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 4671-4676Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (84) Google Scholar). Noxa is a BH3-only Bcl-2 molecule that was identified as a p53 target gene activated transcriptionally after DNA damage (9Oda E. Ohki R. Murasawa H. Nemoto J. Shibue T. Yamashita T. Tokino T. Taniguchi T. Tanaka N. Science. 2000; 288: 1053-1058Crossref PubMed Scopus (1706) Google Scholar). Dp5 and Bim are BH3-only members that are up-regulated transcriptionally after NGF withdrawal of sympathetic neurons (10Imaizumi K. Tsuda M. Imai Y. Wanaka A. Takagi T. Tohyama M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18842-18848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar, 11Putcha G.V. Moulder K.L. Golden J.P. Bouillet P. Adams J.A. Strasser A. Johnson E.M. Neuron. 2001; 29: 615-628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (415) Google Scholar, 12Whitfield J. Neame S.J. Paquet L. Bernard O. Ham J. Neuron. 2001; 29: 629-643Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (505) Google Scholar). Dp5 was identified in a screen for genes up-regulated after NGF deprivation (10Imaizumi K. Tsuda M. Imai Y. Wanaka A. Takagi T. Tohyama M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18842-18848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar) and is the ortholog of the human gene, Harakiri (Hrk), identified by its ability to bind Bcl-2 and Bcl-XL in a yeast two-hybrid screen (13Inohara N. Ding L. Chen S. Nunez G. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 1686-1694Crossref PubMed Scopus (331) Google Scholar). Bim deletion delays, but does not block, the neuronal apoptosis that results from trophic factor withdrawal of neurons (11Putcha G.V. Moulder K.L. Golden J.P. Bouillet P. Adams J.A. Strasser A. Johnson E.M. Neuron. 2001; 29: 615-628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (415) Google Scholar, 12Whitfield J. Neame S.J. Paquet L. Bernard O. Ham J. Neuron. 2001; 29: 629-643Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (505) Google Scholar). The activation of Bim seems to depend on cell type. In addition to being induced in neuronal apoptosis, Bim is subject to post-translational modification in nonneuronal cells. When bound to LC8 in the dynein motor complex, Bim is sequestered in the cytosol. However, apoptotic stimuli, in this case interleukin-3 deprivation of FDC-P1 cells, trigger release of Bim from the cytoskeleton enabling Bim to perform its apoptotic function at the mitochondria (14Puthalakath H. Huang D.C. O'Reilly L.A. King S.M. Strasser A. Mol. Cell. 1999; 3: 287-296Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (905) Google Scholar). These BH3-only family members are often studied for their ability to induce cell death when overexpressed in cell lines. It is not clear whether BH3-only proteins, when overexpressed, are sufficient to kill cells independently (15Shimizu S. Tsujimoto Y. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 577-582Crossref PubMed Scopus (264) Google Scholar, 16Schendel S.L. Azimov R. Pawlowski K. Godzik A. Kagan B.L. Reed J.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 21932-21936Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar) or rather, as suggested by the C. elegans model, BH3-only proteins kill via a mechanism that requires Bcl-2 family members containing multiple BH domains. To address this question, one would have to identify a cell that requires a single given proapoptotic Bcl-2 family member with multiple domains to execute apoptosis in response to physiological stimuli. If BH3-only proteins acted only by interaction(s) with multidomain proapoptotic or antiapoptotic family members, one would predict that overexpression of BH3-only proteins would not kill a cell deficient in the critical proapoptotic Bcl-2 family member. On the other hand, if BH3-only family members can act independently, one would expect them to kill regardless of the presence or absence of the critical proapoptotic Bcl-2 family member. An additional requirement would be a cell type that normally undergoes transcriptional up-regulation of BH3-only family members, such that the ectopic expression mimics the physiological stimulus. The system wherein these questions can be addressed is provided by neurons from Bax-deficient animals in which death in response to trophic factor deprivation in multiple neuronal types is completely abrogated. An additional technical requirement is that these cells be transfectable such that BH3-only proteins can be ectopically expressed. Cerebellar granule neurons deprived of potassium are a well characterized model of neuronal programmed cell death. These neurons are both transfectable and dependent upon Bax (17Miller T.M. Moulder K.L. Knudson C.M. Creedon D.J. Deshmukh M. Korsmeyer S.J. Johnson Jr., E.M. J. Cell Biol. 1997; 139: 205-217Crossref PubMed Scopus (360) Google Scholar) to execute cell death in response to switching from depolarizing to hyperpolarizing levels of potassium. Trophic withdrawal of neurons, including the hyperpolarization of cerebellar granule neurons, results in the JNK-mediated phosphorylation of the transcription factor c-Jun. Inhibition of c-Jun function with neutralizing antibodies or dominant negative cDNA constructs can block the death that occurs after NGF deprivation of sympathetic neurons (18Estus S. Zaks W.J. Freeman R.S. Gruda M. Bravo R. Johnson Jr., E.M. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 127: 1717-1727Crossref PubMed Scopus (786) Google Scholar, 19Ham J. Babij C. Whitfield J. Pfarr C.M. Lallemand D. Yaniv M. Rubin L.L. Neuron. 1995; 14: 927-939Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (757) Google Scholar). CEP-1347, a small molecule inhibitor of JNK activation, completely blocks c-Jun phosphorylation in trophic factor-deprived neurons (11Putcha G.V. Moulder K.L. Golden J.P. Bouillet P. Adams J.A. Strasser A. Johnson E.M. Neuron. 2001; 29: 615-628Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (415) Google Scholar). Expression of dominant negative c-jun partially blocks Bim expression in NGF-deprived sympathetic neurons (12Whitfield J. Neame S.J. Paquet L. Bernard O. Ham J. Neuron. 2001; 29: 629-643Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (505) Google Scholar). Herein, we show that Dp5 and Bim mRNA are induced in cerebellar granule neurons undergoing apoptosis in response to hyperpolarizing levels of potassium. The induction is Bax-independent, since it occurs regardless of Bax genotype and is moderately dependent on JNK signaling, because a majority of the induction can be blocked with CEP-1347, an inhibitor of JNK activation (20Maroney A.C. Glicksman M.A. Basma A.N. Walton K.M. Knight Jr., E. Murphy C.A. Bartlett B.A. Finn J.P. Angeles T. Matsuda Y. Neff N.T. Dionne C.A. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 104-111Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). We show that granule cells can be killed by ectopic expression of Dp5 and that this killing is Bax-dependent, since it does not occur in Bax-deficient neurons. Finally, this seems to be a general phenomenon, since similar results were seen with the BH3-only family members, Bim and tBid. CEP-1347, a kind gift of Anna Maroney (Cephalon, Westchester, PA) was used at 500 nm. BDNF was a kind gift of Dr. Qiao Yan (Amgen, Thousand Oaks, CA), and IGF-I was a kind gift of Monsanto Co. (St. Louis, MO). All other reagents were obtained from Sigma unless indicated otherwise. Cerebellar granule neurons were isolated as described (21Miller T.M. Johnson Jr., E.M. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 7487-7495Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Briefly, postnatal day 7 rat or mouse cerebella were dissected and minced with an iridectomy scissors. Tissue was then dissociated by trypsinization (Worthington; 0.3 mg/ml in HBSS for 15 min at 37 °C) followed by mechanical trituration with a fire-polished glass Pasteur pipette. Trypsin was neutralized with 0.5 mg/ml trypsin inhibitor, and the cell suspension was passed through a 200-μm Nitex filter to remove any cell aggregates. For all experiments, neurons were plated into “K25+S” medium consisting of basal Eagle's medium supplemented with 25 mmpotassium chloride, 10% dialyzed fetal bovine serum, 2 mmglutamine, and penicillin/streptomycin. Neurons were plated at 8 × 105 to 1 × 106/ml at 0.5 ml/well (2.0–2.5 × 105/cm2) in 24-well plates (Nunc Nalgene Inc., Naperville, IL). Prior to plating, wells were coated with 100 μg/ml poly-l-lysine overnight and then washed three times with distilled water and allowed to dry. Aphidicolin (3.3 μg/ml) was added 24–48 h after plating to reduce the number of nonneuronal cells. For induction of cell death, neurons were washed twice and then switched to K5+S medium, which is identical to K25+S except that it contains 5 mm KCl instead of 25 mm. Cultures of sympathetic neurons were prepared as described (22Johnson M.I. Argiro V. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 103: 334-347Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). Briefly, superior cervical ganglia were dissected from postnatal day 1 rats. Cervical ganglia were treated sequentially with 1 mg/ml type IV collagenase and 2.5 mg/ml trypsin (Worthington) for 30 min each at 37 °C followed by trituration through a fire-polished glass Pasteur pipette. Neurons were plated in AM50 on 12-well plates at 30,000 neurons/well. Plates were coated with collagen prepared from rat tail tendons. NGF deprivation was performed by washing 5–6 daysin vitro cultures with NGF-free medium and then adding anti-NGF neutralizing antibodies. AM50 consists of minimum essential medium (Life Technologies, Inc.), 10% fetal bovine serum (Harlan Bioproducts; Indianapolis, IN), 2 mm glutamine, 20 μm 5-fluoro-2′-deoxyuridine + 20 μmuridine, 100 units/ml penicillin, 100 μg/ml streptomycin, and 50 ng/ml 2.5 S NGF (Harlan Bioproducts). At the time of plating, 3.3 μg/ml aphidicolin (A. G. Scientific, San Diego, CA) was added to further reduce the number of nonneuronal cells. Because the presence of serum increases the required concentration of CEP-1347 to achieve bioactivity (23Maroney A.C. Finn J.P. Bozyczko-Coyne D. O'Kane T.M. Neff N.T. Tolkovsky A.M. Park D.S. Yan C.Y. Troy C.M. Greene L.A. J. Neurochem. 1999; 73: 1901-1912PubMed Google Scholar), deprivation experiments were performed in serum-free medium. A modified N2 medium was used for these experiments consisting of Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium/F-12, 40 nmprogesterone, 30 nm sodium selenite, 100 μmputrescine, 10 μg/ml transferrin (Jackson Immunoresearch, West Grove, PA). Bax-deficient mice and littermates were genotyped by performing PCR on tail biopsy DNA as described (24Deckwerth T.L. Elliott J.L. Knudson C.M. Johnson Jr., E.M. Snider W.D. Korsmeyer S.J. Neuron. 1996; 17: 401-411Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (654) Google Scholar). mRNA was isolated from neuronal cultures by using the QuickPrep Micro mRNA isolation kit according to the manufacturer's instructions (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). cDNA was prepared with Superscript II (Life Technologies, Inc.) according to the manufacturer's instructions. PCR was performed in the presence of [32P]dCTP for 21 cycles with the following primers: Dp5 sense, 5′-AGACCCAGCCCGGACCGAGCAA; Dp5 antisense, 5′- CTCTCTCTGTAGCTGGACCTC; BimEL sense, 5′-GGTAATCCCGACGGCGAAGGGAC; BimEL antisense, 5′-AAGAGAAATACCCACTGGAGGACC. Cyclophilin primers and conditions have been described previously (21Miller T.M. Johnson Jr., E.M. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 7487-7495Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). PCR products were electrophoresed on a 10% polyacrylamide gel that was dried, and the bands were quantitated with the Molecular FX PhosphorImager and QuantityOne software. The average of the twot = 0 data points was taken as 100%, and all other time point data were quantified relative to that value. Primary neurons were transfected via a modified calcium phosphate procedure (25Xia Z. Dickens M. Raingeaud J. Davis R.J. Greenberg M.E. Science. 1995; 270: 1326-1331Crossref PubMed Scopus (5034) Google Scholar, 26Moulder K.L. Onodera O. Burke J.R. Strittmatter W.J. Johnson E.M. J. Neurosci. 1999; 19: 705-715Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Cells that die in response to the transfection of proapoptotic molecules either do so before enough GFP is expressed to render them visible via fluorescence microscopy (i.e. with regard to amount of protein, the threshold for induction of apoptosis is lower than the threshold for visual detection) or lose their adherence to the dish. Because the percentage of primary neurons transfected is small (∼1%), one cannot appreciate a population of floating dead cells in the dish. We did not observe a population of cells that were GFP-positive with condensed nuclei that could be reliably quantitated for the analysis of apoptosis. Viable GFP-positive neurons were counted 48 h after transfection of enhanced GFP with the plasmids described. Enhanced GFP was from CLONTECH. Dp5 coding region (10Imaizumi K. Tsuda M. Imai Y. Wanaka A. Takagi T. Tohyama M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 18842-18848Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (145) Google Scholar), kindly provided by K. Imaizumi, was subcloned into pcDNA3. BimEL, BimL, BimS, and parental vector have been previously described (27O'Connor L. Strasser A. O'Reilly L.A. Hausmann G. Adams J.M. Cory S. Huang D.C. EMBO J. 1998; 17: 384-395Crossref PubMed Scopus (954) Google Scholar) and were kindly provided by A. Strasser. t-BidGFP was kindly provided by R. Youle. In this transfection paradigm, a ∼90% concordance rate of transfection is achieved when neurons are transfected with two expression constructs as evidenced by GFP/LacZ colocalization (26Moulder K.L. Onodera O. Burke J.R. Strittmatter W.J. Johnson E.M. J. Neurosci. 1999; 19: 705-715Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). For experiments involving the ability of neuroprotectants to rescue from Dp5 killing, neurons were placed in the presence of neuroprotectant immediately after transfection. Transfection experiments were performed at least three times in quadruplicate. The number of neurons cotransfected with pcDNA3 and GFP was set to 100%. Mean ± S.D. is shown. Semiquantitative reverse transcriptase-PCR was performed from cDNA time courses from wild-type cultures of mouse cerebellar granule cells undergoing programmed cell death in response to withdrawal of depolarizing levels of potassium. Dp5 mRNA was robustly induced after potassium deprivation (Fig. 1). Dp5 mRNA was expressed at low levels in potassium-maintained granule cells. The amount of Dp5 mRNA increased after hyperpolarization, reaching ∼1.6-, 5-, 6-, and 9-fold at 1, 3, 6, and 9 h postdeprivation, respectively (Fig. 1). Thereafter, the amount of Dp5 mRNA decreased because the neurons started to die after these time points (approximately half of the neurons are dead by 12 h). Because the neurons do not progress through the cell death program with complete synchrony, by the time the last neurons induced Dp5, the first to have done so may already be dead. To determine whether Dp5 induction occurred upstream or downstream of Bax action, the experiment was repeated by using cDNA time courses generated with neurons derived from Bax-deficient animals. Dp5 induction follows a similar time course of induction in Bax-deficient neurons, indicating that Dp5 induction occurs upstream of the Bax checkpoint. Specifically, a small induction of Dp5 mRNA occurred at 1 h postdeprivation (∼2-fold) followed by more dramatic inductions of 9-, 10-, and 30-fold at 3, 9, and 12 h postdeprivation, respectively (Fig. 1). The peak levels of Dp5 in Bax-deficient neurons were greater than that in wild type (30- versus 9-fold) because the Bax-deficient neurons do not die in response to the hyperpolarizing potassium. That Bax-deficient neurons subjected to apoptotic stimuli up-regulated BH3-only family members but did not die is indirect evidence that BH3-only family members did not act independently to induce death. Although the Dp5 levels remained above base line in Bax-deficient neurons as far as 96 h postdeprivation, peak levels of Dp5 mRNA levels were not maintained, and Dp5 levels fell from 30-fold at 12 h to 13-fold over control at 18 h and to 4-fold at the end of the experiment 96 h postdeprivation. The decrease in peak levels can be explained in part by the fall in global macromolecular synthesis that occurs in these neurons when hyperpolarized by low potassium (21Miller T.M. Johnson Jr., E.M. J. Neurosci. 1996; 16: 7487-7495Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). To determine whether BimEL was induced with a similar magnitude and time course as Dp5, we used the same cDNAs to examine BimEL expression in cerebellar granule neurons deprived of potassium. BimEL mRNA was induced with a similar magnitude and time course as Dp5 (Fig. 1), suggesting that these BH3-only proteins were coordinately up-regulated during neuronal apoptosis. To determine whether all BH3-only family member genes were up-regulated by trophic withdrawal, we examined whether Noxa, a known p53 target gene up-regulated transcriptionally by DNA damage, was induced after potassium deprivation of cerebellar granule cells. Noxa mRNA was not induced after potassium serum deprivation of both wild-type and Bax-deficient granule neurons (data not shown). Consistent with this lack of cross-talk, another known p53 target gene, Bax, was also not up-regulated after potassium serum deprivation of granule cells (data not shown). In addition, the BH3-only family members, Blk and Bid, were also not induced after potassium deprivation of cerebellar granule neurons (data not shown). To determine the effect of JNK signaling on the induction of the BH3-only Bcl-2 family proteins, Dp5 and Bim, we examined mRNA levels for these genes in cerebellar granule neurons. Neurons were deprived of potassium for 4 h in the absence or presence of CEP-1347, an inhibitor of the JNK signaling pathway (20Maroney A.C. Glicksman M.A. Basma A.N. Walton K.M. Knight Jr., E. Murphy C.A. Bartlett B.A. Finn J.P. Angeles T. Matsuda Y. Neff N.T. Dionne C.A. J. Neurosci. 1998; 18: 104-111Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Induction of c-jun mRNA, a result of JNK activation, was completely blocked in CEP-1347-treated cultures (data not shown). Other experiments demonstrate that CEP-1347 completely blocked c-Jun phosphorylation in cerebellar granule neurons deprived of potassium. 2C. A. Harris and E. M. Johnson, Jr., manuscript in preparation. Together, these data demonstrated that JNK activity was completely blocked by CEP-1347 in hyperpolarized granule neurons. Consistent with the results in Fig.1, Dp5 mRNA was up-regulated 6.3-fold after potassium deprivation but only 2-fold when neurons were deprived in the presence of CEP-1347 (Fig. 2A). Therefore, JNK inhibition reduced the Dp5 mRNA induction by ∼80% at this time point. Bim mRNA was induced to a similar level (5-fold) after potassium deprivation and 2.8-fold in the presence of CEP-1347. This corresponds to JNK inhibition blocking 55% of the Bim mRNA induction. The results further suggest that Dp5 and Bim were coordinately regulated upon trophic factor deprivation. To determine whether this incomplete block was true in other models of trophic factor withdrawal requiring macromolecular synthesis, we assessed the importance of JNK signaling in the induction of Dp5 and Bim that occurs after NGF deprivation of sympathetic neurons. Using primers to Dp5 and Bim, we performed semiquantitative reverse transcriptase-PCR on mRNAs purified from either NGF-maintained neurons or neurons deprived of NGF in the presence or absence of CEP-1347 for 6, 12, or 18 h. The amount of Dp5 and Bim mRNA was greatly increased after NGF deprivation, ∼4-, 15-, and 13-fold for Bim at 6, 12, and 18 h, respectively (Fig. 2, B andC). In the presence of CEP-1347, Bim RNA increased 2-, 2-, and 3-fold at these time points, corresponding to an inhibition of 85% in the induction. Dp5 mRNA increased 17-, 47-, 50-fold in NGF-deprived neurons and 7-, 10-, and 15-fold in NGF-deprived, CEP-1347-saved neurons, corresponding to an inhibition of Dp5 gene induction of ∼75% after NGF deprivation. Overall, the data indicate that ∼75–85% of the induction of Bim and Dp5 mRNA seen after NGF deprivation can be accounted for by the JNK signaling pathway. The previous data (Fig. 1) demonstrating that Dp5 and Bim were induced in Bax-deficient neurons, yet these cells did not die, suggested that the expression of the proapoptotic gene Bax was required in BH3-only protein-mediated death. To test this hypothesis directly, we determined whether ectopic expression of Dp5 killed neurons in a Bax-dependent manner. Rat cerebellar granule neurons were transfected with a Dp5 expression vector or control vector along with a GFP reporter plasmid. Two days after transfection the number of viable neurons was assessed by counting live green fluorescent neurons. Dp5 transfection resulted in the death of most neurons as the yield of GFP neurons cotransfected with Dp5 was ∼25% compared with cells cotransfected with pcDNA3 (Fig. 3). Similar results were obtained with neurons derived from wild-type mice. To assess whether Dp5 required the action of proapoptotic Bcl-2 family members containing multiple BH domains, we performed the identical experiment in neurons derived from littermate Bax-deficient animals. In striking contrast to wild-type mouse or rat neurons, Dp5 expression in Bax-deficient neurons resulted in similar numbers of GFP-positive neurons compared with pcDNA3-transfected neurons (Fig.4), indicating that Dp5 was unable to kill in the absence of Bax.Figure 4Dp5-induced apoptosis is Bax-dependent. Either Dp5 or pcDNA3 was cotransfected with GFP into Bax wild-type (+/+), heterozygous (+/−), or homozygous (−/−) deficient mouse granule neurons. Forty-eight hours later, the number of viable green neurons was counted. Dp5 kills wild-type neurons or hemizygous neurons (p < 0.001) but not Bax-deficient neurons.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) To determine whether the Bax dependence of Dp5-induced killing could be generalized to other BH3-only family members, we transfected potassium-maintained rat granule neurons with BimEL, BimL, BimS, GFP-Bid, or GFP-tBid. These constructs robustly killed rat granule neurons, with tBid being the strongest inducer of death (data not shown). We then transfected Bim or tBid into wild-type and Bax-deficient mouse granule neurons. Again, these constructs robustly killed wild-type neurons (23 ± 2 and 2 ± 0% neuronal viability, respectively) but did not kill Bax-deficient neurons, since the number of Bim- and tBid-transfected neurons was similar to pcDNA3-control transfected neurons (80 ± 6 and 68 ± 5%, respectively, Fig.5). However, protection in Bax-deficient neurons against tBid was not as complete as that observed for Dp5 (p < 0.05). To determine whether JNK signaling was required for Dp5-induced killing, neurons were transfected with Dp5 in the presence of CEP-1347. After 48 h, the number of viable GFP-positive neurons was counted. CEP-1347 had no effect on Dp5-induced killing (Fig.6A), indicating that JNK signaling was not required for Dp5 apoptotic function. To determine whether prosurvival signaling pathways other than those stimulated by depolarizing levels of potassium could interfere with Dp5 function, Dp5-transfected neurons were placed in medium with IGF-I (100 ng/ml) or BDNF (100 ng/ml) immediately after transfection. Both of these factors promote survival of granule neurons in the absence of depolarizing levels of potassium (28Lindholm D. Dechant G. Heisenberg C.P. Thoenen H. Eur. J. Rab11a is a small GTP-binding protein enriched in the pericentriolar plasma membrane recycling systems. We hypothesized that Rab11a-binding proteins exist as downstream effectors of its action. Here we define a family of four Rab11-interacting proteins: Rab11-Family Interacting Protein 1 (Rab11-FIP1), Rab11-Family InteractingProtein 2 (Rab11-FIP2), Rab11-FamilyInteracting Protein 3 (Rab11-FIP3), and pp75/Rip11. All four interacting proteins associated with wild type Rab11a and dominant active Rab11a (Rab11aS20V) as well as Rab11b and Rab25. Rab11-FIP2 also interacted with dominant negative Rab11a (Rab11aS25N) and the tail of myosin Vb. The binding of Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and Rab11-FIP3 to Rab11a was dependent upon a conserved carboxyl-terminal amphipathic α-helix. Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and pp75/Rip11 colocalized with Rab11a in plasma membrane recycling systems in both non-polarized HeLa cells and polarized Madin-Darby canine kidney cells. GFP-Rab11-FIP3 also colocalized with Rab11a in HeLa cells. Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and pp75/Rip11 also coenriched with Rab11a and H+K+-ATPase on parietal cell tubulovesicles, and Rab11-FIP1 and Rab11-FIP2 translocated with Rab11a and the H+K+-ATPase upon stimulating parietal cells with histamine. The results suggest that the function of Rab11a in plasma membrane recycling systems is dependent upon a compendium of protein effectors. Rab11a is a small GTP-binding protein enriched in the pericentriolar plasma membrane recycling systems. We hypothesized that Rab11a-binding proteins exist as downstream effectors of its action. Here we define a family of four Rab11-interacting proteins: Rab11-Family Interacting Protein 1 (Rab11-FIP1), Rab11-Family InteractingProtein 2 (Rab11-FIP2), Rab11-FamilyInteracting Protein 3 (Rab11-FIP3), and pp75/Rip11. All four interacting proteins associated with wild type Rab11a and dominant active Rab11a (Rab11aS20V) as well as Rab11b and Rab25. Rab11-FIP2 also interacted with dominant negative Rab11a (Rab11aS25N) and the tail of myosin Vb. The binding of Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and Rab11-FIP3 to Rab11a was dependent upon a conserved carboxyl-terminal amphipathic α-helix. Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and pp75/Rip11 colocalized with Rab11a in plasma membrane recycling systems in both non-polarized HeLa cells and polarized Madin-Darby canine kidney cells. GFP-Rab11-FIP3 also colocalized with Rab11a in HeLa cells. Rab11-FIP1, Rab11-FIP2, and pp75/Rip11 also coenriched with Rab11a and H+K+-ATPase on parietal cell tubulovesicles, and Rab11-FIP1 and Rab11-FIP2 translocated with Rab11a and the H+K+-ATPase upon stimulating parietal cells with histamine. The results suggest that the function of Rab11a in plasma membrane recycling systems is dependent upon a compendium of protein effectors. Myosin Vb, the second Rab11a-interacting protein, was identified from yeast two-hybrid screening of a parietal cell cDNA library (24Lapierre L.A. Kumar R. Hales C.M. Navarre J. Bhartur S.G. Burnette J.O. Mercer J.A. Bahler M. Goldenring J.R. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 1843-1857Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar). Myosin Vb interacts with all members of the Rab11 family: Rab11a, Rab11b, and Rab25. In MDCK and HeLa cells, myosin Vb associates with the Rab11a-containing plasma membrane recycling systems. Transfection of the tail of myosin Vb lacking the motor domain retards trafficking through the plasma membrane recycling systems (24Lapierre L.A. Kumar R. Hales C.M. Navarre J. Bhartur S.G. Burnette J.O. Mercer J.A. Bahler M. Goldenring J.R. Mol. Biol. Cell. 2001; 12: 1843-1857Crossref PubMed Scopus (345) Google Scholar). Recently, a third protein, Rab11-interacting protein (Rip11), was reported to bind with Rab11 (25Prekeris R. Klumperman J. Scheller R.H. Mol. Cell. 2000; 6: 1437-1448Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (182) Google Scholar). The Rip11 sequence was identified previously as pp75, a phosphoprotein that interacts with the 60-kDa SS-A and Ro autoantigens and may function as an autoantigen due to the presence of pp75 antibodies in the sera of some autoimmune disease patients (26Wang D. Buyon J.P. Zhu W. Chan E.K.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1999; 104: 1265-1275Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). pp75/Rip11 was located in the apical recycling endosome of polarized epithelial cells and appeared to be involved in apical vesicle trafficking (26Wang D. Buyon J.P. Zhu W. Chan E.K.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1999; 104: 1265-1275Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Since only three interacting proteins for Rab11a have been recognized and because the function of the ubiquitously expressed Rab11a is still unclear, we hypothesized that other interacting proteins must exist. By utilizing a yeast two-hybrid screen and EST data base searches, we have identified a family of four Rab11-binding proteins that have a highly conserved Rab11 family-binding amphipathic α-helical motif. Immunofluorescence and Western blot data show a close association between Rab11a and this family of interacting proteins. These results suggest that the functions of Rab11a in plasma membrane recycling systems are regulated by a complex compendium of interacting proteins. Poly(A)+ mRNA was isolated from rabbit gastric parietal cells and primed with oligo(dT) to construct a parietal cell cDNA library in pAD-GAL (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA) with an average clone length of 2.0 kilobase pairs. Rab11aS20V was mutated as described previously (6Wang X. Kumar R. Navarre J. Casanova J.E. Goldenring J.R. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 29138-29146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (197) Google Scholar) from wild type Rab11a via a single base pair substitution and cloned into pBD-GAL (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). pBD-GAL/Rab11aS20V was transfected into the Y190 yeast strain to produce a stable bait line that was isolated on tryptophan-deficient media. The bait line was then transfected with 100 µg of parietal cell cDNA library plasmid and plated on media deficient in leucine, tryptophan, and histidine (TLH−) and supplemented with 2.5 mm 3-aminotriazole. Following 4 days of growth, colonies were lifted onto filter paper, frozen twice for 10 s in liquid nitrogen, and incubated with 1.67 ml of X-gal stock (50 mm5-bromo-4-chloro-3-indolyl β-d-galactoside inN,N-dimethylformamide) in 100 ml of Z buffer (60 mm Na2HPO4, 40 mmNaH2PO4, 10 mm KCl, and 1 mm MgSO4). Interactions were judged positive if the blue product from the β-galactosidase reaction was present within 3 h at room temperature. Positive clones were regrown on TLH− media (CLONTECH, Palo Alto, CA), and β-galactosidase activity was reconfirmed. Plasmids were then rescued from yeast and transformed into XL-1 Blue bacteria and selected on ampicillin. Isolated plasmids were sequenced by automated sequencing (Medical College of Georgia, Molecular Biology Core Facility) using pAD-GAL flanking vector sequences. The larger isolated cDNA clone was used to screen a UniZAP phage parietal cell cDNA library. Phage plaques were screened on duplicate filter lifts of 150-mm dishes plated with 50,000 plaque-forming units/dish. The filters were probed with [32P]dCTP random-primed labeled probe prepared from our original isolated cDNA sequence. Filters were washed to high stringency (65 °C, 0.2× SSC), and phage plaques demonstrating hybridization in both duplicate filter lifts were cloned to plaque purity through serial dilutional replating and screening. Sequences were then rescued into pBluescript using Exassist helper phage. The plasmid cDNA inserts were sized to identify the largest clones that were submitted for automated sequencing. 5′-Rapid amplification of cDNA ends was performed using a linked cDNA prepared from rabbit parietal cell mRNA (Ambion, Austin, TX). Briefly, 5 ng of parietal cell cDNA was utilized as template in the 12 buffer Fail-Safe PCR system (Epicentre Technologies) with the outer RNA linker primer (Ambion) and inner antisense gene-specific primer (5′ TGGGCAGGGACATGAGCACAT 3′). Advantage Taq polymerase (CLONTECH) was used in the 25-µl reactions (5 cycles of 95 °C, 30 s, 72 °C, 180 s; 5 cycles of 95 °C, 30 s, 70 °C, 180 s; and 20 cycles of 95 °C, 30 s, 68 °C, 180 s). The 750-nucleotide band obtained from buffer K of the Fail-Safe PCR kit was cloned into pTOPO-T vector (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA) and sequenced (MCG Molecular Biology Core Facility). An oligonucleotide for the start site of Rab11-FIP1 designed with aSacI site (5′ GCGCGAGCTCAATGGAGGCTGCAAGAGAAACCCAG 3′) and an antisense oligonucleotide containing a SacI site (5′ GAGCCTTTAGATCCACGCCCGAG 3′) was utilized to amplify the 542 amino-terminal nucleotides of Rab11-FIP1 from parietal cell cDNA. Following digestion with SacI (New England Biolabs, Beverly, MA), this fragment was ligated (New England Biolabs ligase) to the carboxyl-terminal 1414 nucleotides of Rab11-FIP1 already cloned into the GFP-C2 vector. Rab11-FIP1 was then recloned in pET-30c and pAD-GAL. pAD-GAL4/Rab11-FIP1 mutant constructs were created utilizing PCR amplification and normal cloning techniques. Rab11-FIP2(KIAA0941), Rab11-FIP3(KIAA0665), and pp75/Rip11(KIAA0857) were identified utilizing Rab11-FIP1 to search the human EST data base. Buyon J.P. Zhu W. Chan E.K.L. J. Clin. Invest. 1999; 104: 1265-1275Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar). Yeast two-hybrid binary assays were conducted as follows. For 20 reactions, 25 ml of YPD liquid (CLONTECH) were inoculated with a single colony from the yeast strain Y190. The culture was grown overnight at 30 °C. Cells were harvested by centrifugation at 1000 × g. Yeast cells were resuspended in 10 ml of water and centrifuged again at 1000 × g. Yeast cells were resuspended in a 100 mm lithium acetate/Tris EDTA solution (10 mm Tris-HCl, 1 mm EDTA, pH 7.5) and incubated for 5 min. For each reaction, 20 µl of the lithium acetate/Tris-EDTA/yeast solution were added to a solution containing 20 µg of heat-denatured salmon sperm DNA, 120 µl of lithium acetate/Tris-EDTA/polyethylene glycol solution (100 mmLiAc, pH 7.5, 10 mm Tris-HCl, 1 mm EDTA, pH 7.5, 40% polyethylene glycol), 200 ng of pBD-GAL4/construct plasmid, and 200 ng of pAD-GAL4 construct plasmid. The solution was mixed well and placed at 30 °C shaking for 30 min. Cells were then heat-shocked at 42 °C for 15 min. The yeast cells were pelleted at 1000 ×g for 30 s; the supernatant was removed; the cells were resuspended in 100 µl sterile water, and then the cells were plated onto a tryptophan- and leucine-deficient medium. The plate was incubated at 30 °C for 3 days, and the colonies were lifted with a 70-mm filter paper disc. The discs were then processed for detection of β-galactosidase activity as detailed above. Observation of a blue color within 3 h was considered a positive result. Hawkins W. Navarre J. Am. J. Physiol. 1996; 270: G515-G525PubMed Google Scholar).
