The tumor suppressor gene PTEN(MMAC1/TEP1) is lost frequently in advanced prostate cancer (PCa). However, the function of PTEN in tumorigenesis is not understood fully. In this study, we demonstrate that expression of Bcl-2 in prostate tumors correlates with loss of the PTEN protein. This finding was verified by studies in the PCa cell lines DU145, PC-3, LNCaP, and an androgen-refractory subline of LNCaP. Transient transfection of PTEN into the PTEN-null cells resulted in decreased levels of Bcl-2 mRNA and protein. These effects appear to be mediated at the level of gene transcription, since a Bcl-2 promoter-reporter construct was down-regulated by ectopic expression of PTEN in LNCaP cells. The inhibition of Bcl-2 required the lipid-phosphatase activity of PTEN and was blocked by overexpression of a constitutively active form of Akt. Moreover, the transcription-regulatory protein cAMP-response element-binding protein (CREB) may be involved, since decreased phosphorylation of CREB at Ser133 was detected following PTEN expression, and ectopic expression of CREB repressed completely the PTEN-induced inhibition of Bcl-2 promoter activity. Furthermore, cotransfection of Bcl-2 and PTEN expression vectors rescued PTEN-induced cell death but not G1 cell cycle arrest. Finally, forced expression of PTEN sensitized LNCaP cells to cell death induced by staurosporine, doxorubicin, and vincristine, and this chemosensitivity was attenuated by exogenous expression of Bcl-2. Taken together, these data demonstrate that loss of PTEN leads to up-regulation of thebcl-2 gene, thus contributing to survival and chemoresistance of PCa cells. These findings suggest that thePTEN gene and its regulated pathway are potential therapeutic targets in prostate cancer. However, the mechanisms underlying overexpression of Bcl-2 and its associated chemoresistance in PCa are poorly understood. In this study, we demonstrate that there is a causal relationship between PTEN loss and overexpression of Bcl-2 in prostate cancer. Transient transfection studies indicate that PTEN-induced down-regulation of Bcl-2 requires not only its lipid phosphatase function but also its modulating effects on Akt and CREB signaling. In addition, we show that PTEN-induced chemosensitivity in PCa cells is achieved, at least in part, by inhibition of Bcl-2 expression. The prostate cancer cell lines PC-3, DU145, and LNCaP were purchased from the American Type Culture Collection (Manassas, VA). Cells were maintained in RPMI 1640 medium (BioWhittaker, Walkersville, MD) containing 10% fetal bovine serum (Life Technologies, Inc.). An androgen-refractory subline of LNCaP, LNCaP-Rf, was established by following the protocol described previously (39Kokontis J. Takakura K. Hay N. Liao S. Cancer Res. 1994; 54: 1566-1573PubMed Google Scholar). LNCaP-Rf cells were cultured in androgen-deprived medium containing 10% charcoal-stripped serum instead of untreated fetal bovine serum. Cell viability was determined by trypan blue exclusion analysis. Cells were transfected with expression vectors for PTEN and/or Bcl-2 along with pEGFP-N1. 12 h after transfection, transfected cells were sorted for EGFP expression as described previously (40Thangaraju M. Kaufmann S.H. Couch F.J. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33487-33496Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (126) Google Scholar). Enriched cells (5 × 105) were seeded into the 35-mm plate. Following treatments with staurosporine (500 nm), doxorubicin (500 ng/ml), or vincristine (500 ng/ml) (Calbiochem), adherent and nonadherent cells were collected over the time course indicated. Cells were stained with trypan blue reagent (Sigma). Seventeen cases of prostate tumors were selected from the surgical pathology files at the Mayo Clinic from patients who had undergone radical retropubic prostatectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy between 1991 and 1994. All patients had clinically localized prostate cancer, and none had received preoperative hormone or radiation therapy. The distribution of Gleason scores was as follows: Gleason 7 (seven cases), Gleason 8 (four cases), and Gleason 9 (six cases). The distribution of pathological TNM stage (1997) was as follows: T2bN0 (four cases), T3aN0 (three cases), T3bN0 (five cases), T3bN1 (two cases), and T3bN2 (three cases). Five-micrometer sections were cut from formalin-fixed paraffin-embedded tissues, and immunohistochemistry was performed. Sections were treated with 0.1 m citrate (pH 6.0) in an 800-watt microwave oven for 15 min for antigen retrieval. Immunostaining was performed as described previously (41Cheville J.C. Lloyd R.V. Sebo T.J. Cheng L. Erickson L. Bostwick D.G. Lohse C.M. Wollan P. Mod. Pathol. 1998; 11: 324-328PubMed Google Scholar) by using the Elite Avidin-biotin-peroxidase kit (Vector Laboratories, Burlingame, CA). Antibodies for immunohistochemistry staining of PTEN and Bcl-2 proteins are the same as those used for Western blot analysis. The association of Bcl-2 expression and PTEN loss was tested by using InStat software. Immunofluorescence studies were performed as described previously (42Papoutsopoulou S. Janknecht R. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2000; 20: 7300-7310Crossref PubMed Scopus (73) Google Scholar). Briefly, cells were grown on coverslips for 48 h after subculture. Cells were washed twice with 1× PBS and fixed for 10 min in 1× PBS, 2% sucrose, 3.7% formaldehyde. After one wash with 1× PBS, 0.1 m glycine for 5 min, cells were premeabilized and treated with blocking solution (1× PBS, 5% normal goat serum, 0.4% Triton X-100) for 20 min. Cells were incubated for 1 h with anti-PTEN mouse monoclonal antibody (6H2.1; Cascade BioScience) or anti-Bcl-2 murine monoclonal antibody (100; Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc., Santa Cruz, CA) (1:100). Coverslips were washed 5 min each four times with solution (1× PBS, 0.2% bovine serum albumin, 0.1% Triton X-100). Cells were incubated with fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated goat anti-mouse secondary antibody (Molecular Probes, Inc., Eugene, OR) (1:1000) for 1 h. Following two washes, cells were counterstained with bisbenzimide (Sigma) at 1 µg/ml for 2 min. Coverslips were washed twice with 1× PBS and mounted on glass slides using ProLong Antifade (Molecular Probes). Fluorecein and bisbenzimide fluorescence was detected with 488- and 385-nm, respectively, on a Zeiss LSM-510 confocal laser microscope. A full-length PTEN cDNA clone was provided by Dr. C. D. James (Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN). A wild-type PTEN expression plasmid (pCMV-PTEN) was constructed by subcloning the full-length cDNA into pcDNA3.1(+) vector (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA). The PTEN open reading frame was confirmed by sequencing in both directions. PTEN mutants were generated by using a QuickChange site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene, La Jolla, CA). The forward primers used for polymerase chain reaction mutagenesis were the following: pCMV-PTEN-C124S, 5′-AGCAATTCACTCTAAAGCTGGAAAGGGACGAACTGGTG-3′; pCMV-PTEN-G129E, 5′-CTGTAAAGCTGGAAAGGAACGAACTGGTGTAATGATATGTGC-3′; pCMV-PTEN-G129R, 5′-CTGTAAAGCTGGAAAGAGACGAACTGGTGTAATGATATGTGC-3′ (the altered nucleic acids are underlined). All of the PTEN mutants were verified by sequencing. Bennett S. Goldman P. Korsmeyer S.J. EMBO J. 1988; 7: 123-131Crossref PubMed Scopus (456) Google Scholar, 44Adachi M. Tsujimoto Y. Oncogene. 1990; 5: 1653-1657PubMed Google Scholar, 45Dong L. Wang W. (Lake Placid, NY). pEGFP-N1 and pCMV-CREB were purchased from CLONTECH (Palo Alto, CA). A myristoylated form of Akt was provided by Dr. L. M. Karnitz (Mayo Clinic, Rochester, MN). Protein samples were prepared by lysing cells in radioimmune precipitation buffer (50 mm Tris-HCl, pH 7.4, 1% Nonidet P-40, 0.25% sodium deoxycholate, 150 mm NaCl, 1 mm EGTA, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 µg/ml leupeptin, 1 µg/ml aprotinin, 1 µg/ml pepstatin, 1 mmNa3VO4, and 1 mm NaF). Equal amounts of protein (15–50 µg) from cell lysates were denatured in sample buffer; subjected to SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis on 8, 12, or 4–20% gels (Invitrogen, Carlsbad, CA); and transferred to nitrocellulose membranes (Bio-Rad). The filters were immunoblotted with specific primary antibodies, horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies, and visualized by enhanced chemiluminescence (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). A monoclonal antibody against PTEN (6H2.1) was purchased from Cascade BioScience (Winchester, MA). A monoclonal anti-β-tubulin (2-28-33) was purchased from Sigma. Antibodies against Bcl-2 (100), Bcl-XL (H-5), and extracellular signal-regulated kinase 2 (D-2) were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc. Polyclonal antibodies against Akt, phospho-Akt (Ser473), CREB, and phospho-CREB (Ser133) were purchased from Cell Signaling Technology (Beverly, MA). Transient transfections of LNCaP and PC-3 cells were performed by electroporation. Total plasmid DNA (5–20 µg) was kept constant for all transfections by adding empty vectors and pEGFP-N1 plasmid (1–2 µg). Cells were mixed with DNA in 400 µl of growth medium. The DNA-cell mixture was transferred into a 4-mm cuvette (BTX Inc., San Diego, CA) and electroporated with a 150–300-V/10-ms pulse using a BTX T820 square wave electroporator (BTX Inc., San Diego, CA). In each experiment, transfection efficiency was monitored 12 h after transfection by examining aliquots of cells under a Zeiss fluorescence microscope with a wavelength of 488 nm. Transfection efficiency was determined by the percentage of the green cells in the whole cell population. Routinely, 70–95% transfection efficiencies were obtained, and the cells with >75% transfection efficiency were used for further experiments. Northern blot analysis of Bcl-2 RNA expression was performed as described previously (46Huang H. Reed C.P. Zhang J.S. Shridhar V. Wang L. Smith D.I. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 2981-2988PubMed Google Scholar). Cells transfected with pCMV-PTEN or a control vector were collected, and total RNA was isolated using the TRIZOL reagent (Life Technologies, Inc., Grand Island, NY). Aliquots (15 µg) of cellular RNA were separated on 1.2% denaturing formaldehyde-agarose gels. A fragment for human Bcl-2 cDNA in pB4 plasmid, purchased from the American Type Culture Collection, was used as a probe for Northern blot hybridization. After stripping, the blot was reprobed with a PTEN cDNA fragment (corresponding to the open reading frame of thePTEN gene) to monitor the ectopic expression of thePTEN gene. Regulation of Bcl-2 promoter activity was determined by using luciferase reporter assays. Cells were harvested 36 h after transfections, and cell lysates were prepared by adding lysis buffer directly to the cells on ice. Firefly luciferase andRenilla luciferase activities were determined using a dual luciferase kit (Promega), and Renilla luciferase activities of cells were used as internal controls. The cells were sorted for EGFP expression 12 h after transfection using FACS Vantage SE (Becton Dickinson, San Jose, CA). Enriched transfected cells were cultured for an additional 48 h. Cells were collected and fixed in freshly prepared ice-cold 70% ethanol for 30 min. After washing with 1× PBS, the cells were stained with 10 µg/ml propidium iodide and 50 µg/ml RNase A. Cells (1 × 106) were incubated for 30 min. Cell cycle distributions were determined by flow cytometry analysis using a FACSCalibur flow cytometer (Becton Dickinson). Cells were lysed in HFS solution (0.1% sodium citrate, 0.1% Triton X-100, 50 µg/ml propidium iodide), and hypodiploid nuclei were counted by flow cytometry to identify those undergoing apoptosis. Cell cycle and apoptosis data were analyzed with ModFit II and WinMDI software, respectively. A number of studies have reported either loss of PTEN or overexpression of Bcl-2 in advanced prostate tumors (9Suzuki H. Freije D. Nusskern D.R. Okami K. Cairns P. Sidransky D. Isaacs W.B. Bova G.S. Cancer Res. 1998; 58: 204-209PubMed Google Scholar, 10McMenamin M.E. Soung P. Perera S. Kaplan I. Loda M. Sellers W.R. Cancer Res. 1999; 59: 4291-4296PubMed Google Scholar, 33McDonnell T.J. Troncoso P. Brisbay S.M. Logothetis C. Chung L.W. Hsieh J.T. Tu S.M. Campbell M.L. Cancer Res. 1992; 52: 6940-6944PubMed Google Scholar). However, no study has examined expression of both proteins in the same tumors. Therefore, we utilized immunohistochemistry to measure expression of PTEN and Bcl-2 in 17 cases of high grade (Gleason score 7 or higher) prostate tumors. As shown in TableI, there was an inverse correlation of PTEN and Bcl-2 staining in 82.4% of the tumors examined (41.2% exhibited negative staining for PTEN but positive staining for Bcl-2, whereas 41.2% exhibited positive staining for PTEN but negative staining for Bcl-2). Examples of each type of staining pattern can be seen in Fig. 1, where case A exhibits PTEN (+) and Bcl-2 (−), and case B exhibits PTEN (−) and Bcl-2 (+). Expression of both PTEN and Bcl-2 proteins was also examined in the PCa cell lines DU145, PC-3, LNCaP, and LNCaP-Rf, an androgen-refractory subline of LNCaP. As shown in Fig.2A, DU145 cells express PTEN, but not Bcl-2. In contrast, PC-3, LNCaP, and LNCaP-Rf cells express Bcl-2 but not PTEN. Expression levels of PTEN and Bcl-2 proteins in individual cells were further analyzed by immunofluorescence. As shown in Fig. 2B, although PTEN protein was detected, no Bcl-2 protein was evident in DU145 cells. In contrast, Bcl-2 protein was observed, but no PTEN was detectable in PC-3, LNCaP, and LNCaP-Rf cells. To determine a causal relationship between the PTEN loss and Bcl-2 overexpression, we transiently transfected a PTEN expression vector into LNCaP and PC-3 cells. As shown in Fig.3, ectopic expression of PTEN in both LNCaP and PC-3 cells resulted in decreased levels of Bcl-2 protein in a dose-dependent manner. In contrast, PTEN did not affect the expression of Bcl-XL, another antiapoptotic member of the Bcl-2 family, in either LNCaP or PC-3 cells (Fig. 3). We next examined the steady-state levels of Bcl-2 mRNA by Northern blot analysis. Bcl-2 mRNA was found to be down-regulated by PTEN expression in LNCaP cells (Fig.4A), suggesting that regulation of Bcl-2 expression by PTEN is at the transcriptional level or involves mRNA stability. In order to determine if transcriptional activity of Bcl-2 is modulated by PTEN expression, we utilized a reporter construct that contained the Bcl-2 core promoter region from −1652 to −1527, since both basal and growth factor-stimulated transcriptional activity of Bcl-2 is mediated by this region (27Wilson B.E. Mochon E. Boxer L.M. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 55

The microtubule-associated protein tau is a family of six isoforms that becomes abnormally hyperphosphorylated and accumulates in neurons undergoing neurodegeneration in the brains of patients with Alzheimer disease (AD). We investigated the isoform-specific interaction of normal tau with AD hyperphosphorylated tau (AD P-tau). We found that the binding of AD P-tau to normal human recombinant tau was τ4L > τ4S > τ4 and τ3L > τ3S > τ3, and that its binding to τ4L was greater than to τ3L. AD P-tau also inhibited the assembly of microtubules promoted by each tau isoform and caused disassembly when added to preassembled microtubules. This inhibition and depolymerization of microtubules by the AD P-tau corresponded directly to the degree of its interaction with the different tau isoforms. In vitro hyperphosphorylation of recombinant tau (P-tau) conferred AD P-tau-like characteristics. Like AD P-tau, P-tau interacted with and sequestered normal tau and inhibited microtubule assembly. These studies suggest that the AD P-tau interacts preferentially with the tau isoforms that have the amino-terminal inserts and four microtubule binding domain repeats and that hyperphosphorylation of tau appears to be sufficient to acquire AD P-tau characteristics. Thus, lack of amino-terminal inserts and extra microtubule binding domain repeat in fetal human brain might be protective from Alzheimer's neurofibrillary degeneration. We investigated the isoform-specific interaction of normal tau with AD hyperphosphorylated tau (AD P-tau). We found that the binding of AD P-tau to normal human recombinant tau was τ4L > τ4S > τ4 and τ3L > τ3S > τ3, and that its binding to τ4L was greater than to τ3L. AD P-tau also inhibited the assembly of microtubules promoted by each tau isoform and caused disassembly when added to preassembled microtubules. This inhibition and depolymerization of microtubules by the AD P-tau corresponded directly to the degree of its interaction with the different tau isoforms. In vitro hyperphosphorylation of recombinant tau (P-tau) conferred AD P-tau-like characteristics. Like AD P-tau, P-tau interacted with and sequestered normal tau and inhibited microtubule assembly. These studies suggest that the AD P-tau interacts preferentially with the tau isoforms that have the amino-terminal inserts and four microtubule binding domain repeats and that hyperphosphorylation of tau appears to be sufficient to acquire AD P-tau characteristics. Thus, lack of amino-terminal inserts and extra microtubule binding domain repeat in fetal human brain might be protective from Alzheimer's neurofibrillary degeneration. Alzheimer's disease abnormally hyperphosphorylated tau frontotemporal dementia with Parkinsonism-linked to chromosome 17 paired helical filaments microtubule-associated protein 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid A common feature among several neurodegenerative dementias called tauopathies, which include Alzheimer's disease (AD)1 and frontotemporal dementia with Parkinsonism-linked to chromosome 17 (FTDP-17), is the accumulation in the brain neurons of abnormally hyperphosphorylated tau, mostly polymerized into tangles of paired helical filaments (PHF). The number of neurofibrillary tangles is known to directly correlate to the degree of dementia in AD patients (1Tomlinson B.E. Blessed G. Roth M. J. Neurol. Sci. 1970; 11: 205-242Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1386) Google Scholar, 2Alafuzoff I. Iqbal K. Friden H. Adolfsson R. Winblad B. Acta Neuropathol. Furthermore, the recent discovery of the co-segregation of specific mutations in the tau gene with disease in some pedigrees of FTDP-17 has confirmed that certain abnormalities in the tau protein can cause neurodegeneration and dementia in the affected individuals (4Poorkaj P. Bird T.D. Wijsman E. Nemens E. Garruto R.M. Anderson L. et al.Ann. Neurol. 1998; 43: 815-825Crossref PubMed Scopus (1225) Google Scholar, 5Hutton M. Lendon C.L. Rizzu P. Baker M. Froelich S. A. 1998; 95: 7737-7741Crossref PubMed Scopus (1307) Google Scholar). Thus, understanding the molecular mechanism of neurofibrillary degeneration is critical to developing a rational therapeutic treatment of AD and related tauopathies. Tau is one of the major and most studied microtubule-associated proteins (MAPs) in the central nervous system. It promotes assembly of tubulin both in vitro and in vivo into microtubules and maintains the microtubule structure (7Weingarten M.D. Lockwood A.H. Hwo S.Y. Kirschner M.W. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. Biol. 1989; 9: 1381-1388Crossref PubMed Scopus (422) Google Scholar, 15Goedert M. Spillantini M.G. Jakes R. Rutherford D. Crowther R.A. Neuron. 1989; 3: 519-526Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1844) Google Scholar). The human brain tau isoforms range from 352 to 441 amino acids. They differ in whether they contain three (τ3L, τ3S, or τ3) or four (τ4L, τ4S, or τ4) tubulin binding domains (repeats, R) of 31 or 32 amino acids, each in the C-terminal half, and two (τ3L, τ4L), one (τ3S, τ4S), or no (τ3, τ4) inserts of 29 amino acids each in the N-terminal portion of the molecule (Fig. 1). Here we show that (i) the binding of AD P-tau to normal τ4L > τ4S > τ4 and τ3L > τ3S > τ3, and that to 4Rτ tends to be greater than to the corresponding 3Rτ, and (ii) AD P-tau inhibits the assembly and disrupts the microtubules formed with any of the six tau isoforms, and this inhibition and depolymerization of microtubules by the AD P-tau corresponds directly to the degree of its interaction with the different tau isoforms. All of the incubations, blocking, and washing were done as previously described (39Kremer L. Dominguez J.E. Avila J. Anal. Biochem. 1988; 175: 91-95Crossref PubMed Scopus (18) Google Scholar). Med. 1996; 2: 783-787Crossref PubMed Scopus (689) Google Scholar). Any of the six isoforms or the tau fragments (100 μg) was mixed with AD P-tau (8 μg) in a final volume of 100 μl of 100 mm MES buffer containing 2 mm EGTA, 2% bovine serum albumin, 0.5 mm MgCl2, 1 μmaprotinin, and 1 μm leupeptin (binding buffer). The mixture was allowed to interact for 1 h at 30 °C and then was overlaid on 100 μl of 8% sucrose in the binding buffer and centrifuged for 1 h at 100,000 × g. After centrifugation, 150 μl of the supernatant from the top was separated, and the rest, 50 μl, which contained the AD P-tau-N-tau complexes, was sonicated for 1 h in a bath sonicator and assayed for the levels of normal tau by radioimmuno-dot-blot assay using Tau-1 antibody. MAP-free tubulin was isolated from bovine brain by phosphocellulose chromatography of thrice-cycled microtubules as previously described (20Alonso A.del C. Zaidi T. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5562-5566Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar). Tau isoforms (83–333 μg/ml) were mixed at 4 °C with purified bovine brain MAP-free tubulin (2 mg/ml) and 1 mm GTP, all in polymerization buffer (100 mmMES, pH 6.7, 1 mm EGTA, and 1 mmMgCl2) in a final volume of 60 μl. Tau was added last to initiate the reaction. After rapid mixing, the samples were pipetted into quartz microcuvettes and equilibrated at 37 °C in a thermostatically controlled Cary 1 recording spectrophotometer. The turbidity of the reaction mixture was continuously monitored at 350 nm. For the disruption assay, after the steady state was reached, 10 μg/5 μl of AD P-tau was added, and the turbidity was monitored. For the inhibition experiments, an 83 μg/ml concentration of a tau isoform was mixed with 67 or 133 μg/ml AD P-tau before incubating with tubulin. The state of assembly of microtubules was confirmed by negative stain electron microscopy as described previously (40Wisniewski H.M. Merz P.A. Iqbal K. J. Neuropathol. Exp. Neurol. 1984; 43: 643-656Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar). To determine the role of the amino-terminal inserts and the extra repeat in the interaction of normal tau with AD P-tau, the binding of recombinant human isoforms and tau deletion constructs (Fig.1) to AD P-tau was studied by a dot-blot overlay assay. The AD P-tau had a tendency to bind to 4Rτ more than to 3Rτ (Fig. 2). In the case of the 4R isoforms, the binding to AD P-tau was τ4L > τ4S > τ4. The isoforms with 3R showed a similar tendency, i.e.τ3L > τ3S > τ3. No binding was detected to any of the tau deletion constructs that lacked the amino-terminal half of the molecule (i.e. τ4L244–441 and τ4L267–441). All of these findings taken together suggest that the N-terminal inserts promote the interaction of tau with AD P-tau. The tau construct, τ4L1–392, lacking the C-terminal 49 residues, showed a binding similar to that of the full-length tau, suggesting that this C-terminal region does not promote or inhibit the tau-AD P-tau interaction. The association of AD P-tau to different tau isoforms and deletion constructs was also studied by a sedimentation assay. The interaction of each recombinant tau isoform and the tau construct with AD P-tau was studied by mixing 100 μg of the recombinant protein with 8 μg of the AD P-tau in a final volume of 100 μl, and the aggregates formed were separated by centrifugation and assayed by a radioimmuno-dot-blot assays. The percentage of the recombinant tau in the aggregates is shown in Table I. The interaction with AD P-tau found was τ4L > τ4S > τ4; τ3L > τ3S > τ3; 4Rτ > 3Rτ. These results are consistent with those found by the dot-blot overlay assay, confirming that the tau-AD P-tau interaction is more favorable when the two N-terminal inserts are present in normal tau. The tau constructs that lacked the N-terminal half, τ4L244–441 and τ4267–441, did not bind to AD P-tau (Table I), suggesting that this region is required for the binding, and the C-terminal half of tau is not sufficient for this interaction.Table IBinding of τ4L, τ4S, τ4, τ3L, τ3S, τ3, τ4L1–392, τ4L244–441, and τ4L267–441 to AD P-tauPercentage of bound proteinBackground (no addition) (A)Total (addition of AD P-tau) (B)Difference (B − A)%%%τ4L8 ± 659 ± 1051 ± 4τ4S10 ± 550 ± 940 ± 7τ417 ± 723 ± 86 ± 1τ3L7 ± 549 ± 942 ± 6τ3S10 ± 528 ± 718 ± 2τ318 ± 920 ± 102 ± 1τ4L1–39210 ± 54 ± 930 ± 4τ4L244–44122 ± 623 ± 81 ± 2τ4L267–44121 ± 720 ± 8−1 ± 1The binding of recombinant taus to AD P-tau was studied by the sedimentation assay, and the quantitation of the bound recombinant proteins was determined by 125I-radioimmunodot-blot assay as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Results represent the mean ± S.D. of three separate experiments. Since AD P-tau differentially interacted with different tau isoforms, we investigated the disruption by AD P-tau of microtubules assembled with the various tau isoforms. Recombinant tau isoforms (83 and 333 μg/ml) were mixed with isolated bovine tubulin (2 mg/ml), and the microtubule assembly was monitored at 350 nm. At steady state, 5 μl containing 10 μg of AD P-tau was added to 60 μl of the assembly reaction mixture. In the case of τ4L, τ4S, τ3L, and τ3S, the microtubules were disrupted by the addition of AD P-tau when the assembly was carried out either with 83 or 333 μg/ml of the recombinant tau (Fig. 3). In contrast, the microtubules formed with 333 μg/ml τ3 and τ4 (Fig.3, curve 1) were quite resistant to the disruption by AD P-tau, although disruption could be observed both by turbidimetry (Fig. 3A, curve 2) and by electron microscopy (Fig. 3B) when the assembly was performed with an 83 μg/ml concentration of these recombinant proteins. To examine the ability of AD P-tau to inhibit thein vitro assembly of microtubules induced by each tau isoform, τ4L, τ3L, τ3, and τ4 were mixed individually with AD P-tau before adding to tubulin and the assembly reaction was followed by turbidimetry. AD P-tau inhibited the assembly promoted by all of the isoforms (Fig. 4). However, the inhibition achieved was greater with τ4L than with τ3L, τ4, or τ3 at an AD P-tau concentration of 67 μg/ml (comparecurves 2 of τ4L with τ4, τ3L, and τ3). Almost complete inhibition was achieved in all cases with 133 μg/ml of AD P-tau (Fig. 4A, curves 3). These findings suggest that the tau isoforms that have the N-terminal inserts and the fourth repeat are more readily sequestered by AD P-tau than those that lack these inserts. Electron microscopy confirmed the presence of microtubules at the lower concentration (67 μg/ml) of AD P-tau in the case of τ4, τ3L, and τ3, whereas only occasional microtubules were seen under this condition in the case of τ4L (data not shown). No microtubules could be seen at the higher concentration (133 μg/ml) of AD P-tau with any of the tau isoforms examined (Fig.4B, b, d, f, andh). In order to confirm the role of the abnormal hyperphosphorylation in converting tau into “AD P-tau-like” molecule, we in vitro hyperphosphorylated recombinant τ4L with the protein kinases present in the normal brain extract and studied the ability of this phosphorylated tau to bind normal tau and to inhibit microtubule assembly. Phosphorylation of τ4L with rat brain extract resulted in incorporation of ∼12–15 mol of phosphates/mol of the protein (phosphorylated tau, P-tau) during ∼24 h. Immunolabeling with phosphodependent antibodies to specific sites revealed that τ4L was phosphorylated at similar sites and to a similar extent as the AD P-tau, (Fig.5A). The sites found to bein vitro phosphorylated were: Ser262/356 (12E8); Ser195/198/199/202 (Tau-1); Ser396/404 (PHF-1); Thr231/Ser235 (M4); Ser422 (R145); Thr181 (AT270, Thr(P)181); Thr212/Ser214 (AT100); Thr205(Thr(P)205); Thr212 (Thr(P)212); Ser214 (Ser(P)214); Thr217(Thr(P)217); Ser396 (Ser(P)396). However, because of the lack of standards in which the protein was 100% phosphorylated at the sites examined, it was not possible to determine the percentage phosphorylation of these sites by Western blot analysis. Next we examined whether like AD P-tau, the in vitrohyperphosphorylated recombinant tau (P-tau) also bound to normal recombinant tau. For these studies, P-tau was dotted in different concentrations on a nitrocellulose membrane and overlaid with 3 and 6 μg/ml normal tau. P-tau was able to bind normal tau in a concentration-dependent manner (Fig. 5B). The association of P-tau to normal tau was also studied by sedimentation assay. The interaction of normal tau with P-tau was studied by mixing 100 μg of the normal protein with 4 μg of P-tau in a final volume of 100 μl, and the aggregates formed were separated by centrifugation and quantified by radioimmuno-dot-blot assay as above. The percentage of the normal tau in the aggregates is shown in Fig. 5C. Thus, like AD P-tau, P-tau could also sequester normal tau, both in a dot-blot overlay assay and in a sedimentation assay. To examine the ability of P-tau to inhibit the in vitro assembly of microtubules, normal τ4L at two different concentrations, 0.1 and 0.03 mg/ml, was mixed with increasing concentrations of P-tau before adding to tubulin, and the assembly reaction was followed by turbidimetry. P-tau inhibited the assembly promoted by normal τ4L (Fig. 5D). The sequestration and the inhibition of normal τ4L-induced microtubule assembly by P-tau suggest that hyperphosphorylation converts tau into an AD P-tau-like state. Independent of the etiology (i.e. genetic or nongenetic), the clinical expression (i.e. dementia in AD and most likely in other tauopathies such as FTDP-17) appears to require neurofibrillary degeneration. The cytoskeleton of the neurons affected in AD is disrupted and microtubules are rarely seen in neurons with neurofibrillary tangles (41Terry R.D. Wisniewski H.M. Gaitz C.M. Aging and the Brain. Plenum, New York1972: 89-116Google Scholar). The abnormal hyperphosphorylation of tau seems to precede the presence of PHF (11Köpke E. Tung Y.-C. Shaikh S. Alonso A.del C. Iqbal K. Grundke-Iqbal I. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24374-24384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 42Bancher C. Brunner C. Lassmann H. Budka H. Jellinger K. Wiche G. Seitelberger F. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Wisniewski H.M. Brain Res. 1989; 477: 90-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (701) Google Scholar). Thus, the elucidation of the molecular mechanism by which the abnormal hyperphosphorylation might lead to neurofibrillary degeneration is critical to understanding the pathogenesis of AD and related tauopathies. Previously, we have shown that unlike normal tau, the AD P-tau does not promote but instead inhibits in vitromicrotubule assembly by sequestering normal MAPs and that this toxic behavior is solely due to the abnormal hyperphosphorylation, becausein vitro dephosphorylation converts AD P-tau into a normal-like protein (20Alonso A.del C. Zaidi T. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 5562-5566Crossref PubMed Scopus (596) Google Scholar, 21Alonso A.del C. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Nat. Med. 1996; 2: 783-787Crossref PubMed Scopus (689) Google Scholar, 22Alonso A.del C. Grundke-Iqbal I. Barra H.S. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1997; 94: 298-303Crossref PubMed Scopus (367) Google Scholar, 43Wang J.-Z. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Nat. Med. 1996; 2: 871-875Crossref PubMed Scopus (289) Google Scholar). Most recently we have found that hyperphosphorylation promotes the self-assembly of tau into tangles of PHF/straight filaments (38Alonso A.del C. Zaidi T. Novak M. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6923-6928Crossref PubMed Scopus (741) Google Scholar). The present study shows that (i) the N-terminal half is required for the association of normal tau to AD P-tau; (ii) the binding of AD P-tau to normal tau is τ4L > τ4S > τ4 and τ3L > τ3S > τ3, and that to 4Rτ is >3Rτ; (iii) AD P-tau inhibits the assembly of microtubules promoted by each tau isoform and causes disassembly when added to preassembled microtubules and that these inhibitory activities of AD P-tau directly correlate to the degree of its association to the normal tau isoforms; and (iv) in vitro hyperphosphorylation converts normal tau into an AD P-tau-like toxic state. The lack of the N-terminal half, as in τ4L244–441or in τ4L267–441, completely abolished the sequestration by AD P-tau (Table I, Fig. 2), suggesting that the major site involved in the interaction is in the N-terminal half of the molecule or that the conformation acquired without the N-terminal half is such that tau cannot be sequestered by AD P-tau. Previous studies have shown that the minimal site for the tau-tau interaction of the normal protein comprises the microtubule binding repeats region (38Alonso A.del C. Zaidi T. Novak M. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6923-6928Crossref PubMed Scopus (741) Google Scholar,44Arrasate M. Perez M. Armas-Portela R. Avila J. FEBS Lett. 1999; 446: 199-202Crossref PubMed Scopus (105) Google Scholar, 45von Bergen M. Friedhoff P. Bienart J. Heberle J. Mandelkow E.-M. Mandelkow E. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2000; 97: 5129-5134Crossref PubMed Scopus (764) Google Scholar), and we have postulated that the regions flanking these repeats, probably because of their positive charges, have an inhibitory effect on the interaction (38Alonso A.del C. Zaidi T. Novak M. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2001; 98: 6923-6928Crossref PubMed Scopus (741) Google Scholar). In AD P-tau, these flanking regions, especially the amino-terminal half, are highly phosphorylated (46Iqbal K. Grundke-Iqbal I. Neurobiol. Aging. 1995; 16: 375-379Crossref Scopus (23) Google Scholar, 47Morishima-Kawashima M. Hasegawa M. Takio K. Suzuki M. Yoshida H. Titani K. Ihara Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 823-829Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (528) Google Scholar), which probably results in neutralization of the inhibitory basic charges. The carboxyl-terminal half of tau, which has been shown to bind to microtubules (11Köpke E. Tung Y.-C. Shaikh S. Alonso A.del C. Iqbal K. Grundke-Iqbal I. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 24374-24384Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 48Goode B.L. Denis P.E. Panda D. Radeke M.J. Miller H.P. Wilson L. Feinstein S.C. Mol. Biol. Cell. 1997; 8: 353-365Crossref PubMed Scopus (236) Google Scholar), contains the microtubule binding domains. Thus, taus lacking the N-terminal half would be able to induce microtubule assembly as well as being immune to sequestration by AD P-tau. Whether neurons vulnerable to neurofibrillary degeneration employ such a strategy for their survival in tauopathies is currently not known. Previously, we have shown that the association of tau with AD P-tau is probably of hydrophobic nature because it is inhibited both by 0.5% Triton X-100 and by 2 m NaCl, and the interaction increases with the increase in temperature from 4 to 37 °C (21Alonso A.del C. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Nat. Med. 1996; 2: 783-787Crossref PubMed Scopus (689) Google Scholar). In the present study, τ4L was found to be sequestered the best by AD P-tau. The presence of the acidic N-terminal inserts partially neutralizes the positive charge of the rest of the tau molecule and, along with the extra repeat, probably facilitates a hydrophobic interaction of τ4L with AD P-tau. Such a scenario might account for the increased vulnerability of the taus with N-terminal inserts to sequestration by AD P-tau. Like the two N-terminal inserts, the abnormal hyperphosphorylation that occurs in AD and other tauopathies also neutralizes the basic charge of tau and makes it more hydrophobic. Ruben et al. (49Ruben G.C. Ciardelli T.L. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Synapse. 1997; 27: 208-229Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) have postulated, based on inverse temperature transition, that 5–9 phosphate groups are enough to neutralize tau's basic nature and that AD P-tau is more hydrophobic than normal brain tau because of its lower inverse temperature transition. We have found that 4Rτs have the tendency to be more sensitive to the interaction with AD P-tau than 3Rτs (Fig. 2, Table I). This observation might explain why, despite the higher levels of phosphorylation in fetal tau, τ3, which lacks both the extra repeat and the two N-terminal inserts, no neurodegeneration is observed. On the other hand, a neuron enriched in 4Rτs, as in the case of the intronic and the silent mutations of the tau gene in FTDP-17 (18Goedert M. Spillantini M.G. Cairns N.J. Crowther R.A. Neuron. 1992; 8: 159-168Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (904) Google Scholar, 19Spillantini M.G. Yoshida H. Rizzini C. Lantos P.L. Khan N. Rossor N.N. Goedert M. Brown J. Ann. Neurol. 2000; 49: 939-943Crossref Scopus (127) Google Scholar), will be more vulnerable than a normal neuron to the presence of hyperphosphorylated tau. With respect to the levels of 4Rτs in AD, the reports have been contradictory (50Liu W.-K Dickson D.W. Yen S.-H. Am. J. Pathol. 1993; 142: 387-394PubMed Google Scholar, 51Ksiezak-Reding H. Shafit-Zagardo B. Yen S.-H. J. Neurosci. Res. 1995; 41: 583-593Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). In AD, an imbalance of the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation system has been proposed through a decrease in the phosphatase activity (52Gong C.-X. Singh T.J. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. J. Neurochem. 1993; 61: 921-927Crossref PubMed Scopus (457) Google Scholar). Hyperphosphorylation of tau and higher levels of 4Rτs provide optimal conditions for the disruption of the microtubule network, because the AD P-tau sequesters most the 4Rτs. In addition to abnormal hyperphosphorylation, glycosylation (43Wang J.-Z. Grundke-Iqbal I. Iqbal K. Nat. Med. 1996; 2: 871-875Crossref PubMed Scopus (289) Google Scholar), ubiquitination (31Grundke-Iqbal I. Vorbrodt A.W. Iqbal K. Tung Y.C. Wang G.P. Wisniewski H.M. Brain Res. 1988; 464: 43-52Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar, 53Mori H. Kondo G. Ihara Y. Science. 1987; 235: 1641-1644Crossref PubMed Scopus (719) Google Scholar, 54Perry G. Friedman R. Shaw G. Chau V. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1987; 84: 3033-3036Crossref PubMed Scopus (541) Google Scholar), glycation, and the addition of lipid peroxide adducts (55Ledesma M.D. Bonay P. Colaco C. Avila J. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 21614-21619Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 56Yan S.D. Chen X. Schmidt A.M. Brett J. Godman G. Zou Y.S. Scott C.W. Caputo C. Frappier T. Smith M.A. Perry G. Yen S. Stern D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 7787-7791Crossref PubMed Scopus (529) Google Scholar) of tau have been shown in AD. However, as shown in the present study, only hyperphosphorylation of tau appears to be enough to convert normal tau into a toxic AD P-tau-like molecule. The tau in vitro hyperphosphorylated to a similar extent and in several of the same sites as the AD P-tau was found to bind normal tau in a similar proportion as the AD P-tau, both in the sedimentation and the overlay assays (Fig. 5). P-tau also mimicked AD P-tau in the ability to inhibit microtubule assembly. In conclusion, our findings suggest a scenario that is compatible both with the imbalance in the expression of tau isoforms and an imbalance in the phosphorylation/dephosphorylation system. The association between the AD P-tau and normal tau appears to be quite specific. In AD, FTDP-17, and other tauopathies, most likely upon hyperphosphorylation tau is released from microtubules. The released hyperphosphorylated tau sequesters normal tau and other MAPs, causing on one hand the disassembly of microtubules and on the other hand the self-assembly of the hyperphosphorylated protein into PHF and straight filaments. The disruption of the microtubules probably leads to neurodegeneration even in those neurons that do not contain PHF. Thus, inhibition of abnormal phosphorylation of tau might inhibit neurofibrillary degeneration in AD, FTDP-17, and other related tauopathies. Consistent with the present study, a paper by Wittmann et al. (57Wittmann C.W. Shulman J.M. Salvaterra P.M. Lewis J. Hutton M. Feany M.B. Science. 2001; 293: 711-714Crossref PubMed Scopus (739) Google Scholar) reported neuronal degeneration associated with hyperphosphorylation of tau in the absence of formation of filaments/tangles in transgenic Drosophila overexpressing wild type or V337M or R406W mutated forms of human tau. The type 1 insulin-like growth factor receptor (IGF1R) is required for growth, tumorigenicity and protection from apoptosis. IGF1R overexpression is associated with radioresistance in breast cancer. We used antisense (AS) RNA to downregulate IGF1R expression in mouse melanoma cells. Cells expressing AS-IGF1R transcripts were more radiosensitive in vitro and in vivo than controls. Also they showed reduced radiation-induced p53 accumulation and p53 serine 18 phosphorylation, and radioresistant DNA synthesis. These changes were reminiscent of the cellular phenotype of the human genetic disorder ataxia-telangiectasia (A-T), caused by mutations in the ATM gene. Cellular Atm protein levels were lower in AS-IGF1R-transfected cells than in control cells, although there was no difference in Atm expression at the transcriptional level. AS-IGF1R cells had detectable basal Atm kinase activity, but failed to induce kinase activity after irradiation. This suggests that IGF1R signalling can modulate the function of Atm, and supports the concept of targeted IGF1R downregulation as a potential treatment for malignant melanoma and other radioresistant tumours.

Survival of memory B lymphocytes is tightly linked to the integrity of the Bcl-2 protein and is regulated by a nerve growth factor (NGF) autocrine circuit. In factor-starved memory B cells, the addition of exogenous NGF promptly induced p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK), but not c-Jun N-terminal kinase (JNK), dephosphorylation. Conversely, withdrawal of endogenous NGF was followed by p38 MAPK activation and translocation onto mitochondria, whereby it combined with and phosphorylated Bcl-2, as assessed by co-immunoprecipitation and kinase assays in vivo and in vitro. Mitochondria isolated from human memory B cells, then exposed to recombinant p38 MAPK, released cytochrome c, as did mitochondria from Bcl-2-negative MDCK cells loaded with recombinant Bcl-2. Apoptosis induced by NGF neutralization could be blocked by the specific p38 MAPK inhibitor SB203580 or by Bcl-2 mutations in Ser-87 or Thr-56. These data demonstrate that the molecular mechanisms underlying the survival factor function of NGF critically rely upon the continuous inactivation of p38 MAPK, a Bcl-2-modifying enzyme. In multicellular organisms, the fate of a given cell is under the social control exerted by the surrounding elements, which deliver life or death signals. A class of molecular inputs that keep alive the cell are the survival factors, whose surface receptors transmit signals that inhibit the pathways leading to cell death. Nerve growth factor (NGF)1 is the first and perhaps most representative protein of this class (23Levi-Montalcini R. Science. 1987; 237: 1154-1162Crossref PubMed Scopus (2681) Google Scholar). Since NGF withdrawal in factor-dependent cells typically affects Bcl-2 protein (17Rosini P. De Chiara G. Lucibello M. Garaci E. Cozzolino F. Torcia M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 278: 753-759Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 24Torcia M. Bracci-Laudiero L. Lucibello M. Nencioni L. Labardi D. Rubartelli A. Cozzolino F. Aloe L. Garaci E. Dermatol. 1997; 109: 757-764Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (92) Google Scholar), we wanted to define the molecular events linking NGF surface receptors with Bcl-2 in memory B lymphocytes, a cell type that depends on a functional NGF autocrine circuit for survival (24Torcia M. Bracci-Laudiero L. Lucibello M. Nencioni L. Labardi D. Rubartelli A. Cozzolino F. Aloe L. Garaci E. Cell. 1996; 85: 345-356Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). In the present paper, we describe that, upon factor withdrawal, p38 mitogen-activated protein kinase (MAPK) in its active form rapidly translocates onto mitochondria, specifically interacts with Bcl-2, and phosphorylates it, an event that is followed by cytochrome c release from the organelle and by apoptotic cell death. Transfection experiments with Bcl-2 mutants bearing substitutions of Ser-87 or Thr-56 residues within the loop region showed increased resistance to apoptosis induced by NGF withdrawal. The observation that p38 MAPK is promptly dephosphorylated after NGF administration to factor-starved cells indicates that the cytokine modulates the enzyme activation to maintain survival of NGF-dependent cells. Rabbit anti-human p38 MAPK, anti-human JNK, anti-human phosphorylated JNK, anti-human actin, anti-human PARP, and goat and mouse anti-human Bcl-2 Abs were purchased by Santa Cruz Biotechnology, Inc. (Santa Cruz, CA). Rabbit anti-human phosphorylated p38 MAPK was purchased by New England Biolabs. Anti-human hsp60 was purchased by Stressgen. Human recombinant NGF was a generous gift of Dr. G. Ferrari (Fidia, Abano, Italy). The p38 MAPK inhibitor SB203580, the inactive SB202474, the PD098059 MEK1/2 inhibitor, and the Trk-A inhibitor K252a were purchased by Calbiochem. Anisomycin was purchased by Sigma. Human recombinant Bcl-2-His6-(1–218) was expressed with a C-terminal His6 tag using pQE60 vector (Quiagen) in M15 cells (Escherichia coli). Recombinant protein was purified by resuspending 1-liter cell cultures in 50 mmphosphate buffer, pH 8, with 300 mm NaCl, 10 mmimidazole. The cell suspension was incubated with 1 mg/ml lysozyme for 30 min at 4 °C, sonicated to reduce viscosity, and centrifuged at 10,000 × g for 30 min. The supernatant was applied to a nickel-activated Hi-TrapTM chelating column (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) and purified with an FPLC apparatus (Amersham Pharmacia), using a wash step with 50 mm phosphate buffer, 300 mm NaCl, 30 mm imidazole, pH 8.0, until theA280 reached <0.01. Proteins were eluted with 250 mm imidazole, desalted against 10 mmHepes, 150 mm NaCl, pH 7.4, and stored at −20 °C. Bracci-Laudiero L. Lucibello M. Nencioni L. Labardi D. Rubartelli A. Cozzolino F. Aloe L. Garaci E. Cell. 1996; 85: 345-356Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). CESS and MDCK cell lines were purchased by ATCC (Manassas, VA) and cultured in RPMI 1640 medium supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum. sIgD− B cells were cultured overnight at 2 × 105 cells/ml, washed, and incubated at 107cells/ml with human recombinant NGF (100 ng/ml) or with 10 µg/ml anti-NGF Abs or rat IgG. At different time intervals, cells were washed, lysed in sample buffer, run on SDS-PAGE, blotted onto nitrocellulose filters, and stained with 0.1 µg/ml rabbit anti-human phosphorylated p38 MAPK or rabbit anti-human JNK. The reaction was visualized by ECL detection system as recommended by the manufacturer (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Membranes were stripped at 56 °C and stained with 0.1 µg/ml rabbit anti-human p38 MAPK or anti-human JNK. For immunofluorescence analysis, sIgD− cells, treated with 10 µg/ml anti-NGF Abs or control Ig for 4 h, were incubated with 25 nmMitotracker (Molecular Probes, Inc., Eugene, OR) for 30 min at 37 °C and then attached on poly-l-lysine-sensitized slides. The cells were fixed with 2% paraformaldheyde, permeabilized with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS, and, after saturation of slides with 5% low fat dry milk (Bio-Rad) in phosphate buffer, stained with 0.1 µg/ml rabbit anti-human p38 MAPK, anti-human phosphorylated p38 MAPK, or preimmune rabbit IgG, followed by fluorescein isothiocyanate-conjugated goat anti-rabbit IgG. The slides were analyzed by a confocal laser-scanning microscope. 108 cells were suspended in 5 mmTris, pH 7.4, with 5 mm KCl, 1.5 mmMgCl2, 0.1 mm EGTA, pH 8.0, containing 1 mm dithiothreitol, 0.2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 5 µg/ml leupeptin, 5 µg/ml aprotinin, 0.7 µg/ml pepstatin for 30 min on ice, Dounce-homogenized, and centrifuged at 750 × g at 4 °C to obtain the nuclear fraction. The supernatant was further centrifuged at 10,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C to obtain the mitochondrial fraction (pellett) and the cytosolic fraction (supernatant). For Western blot analysis, the nuclear and mitochondrial fractions were directly lysed in sample buffer, while the cytosolic fraction was vacuum-concentrated and subsequently suspended in sample buffer. The purity of each fraction was assessed by staining aliquots with Abs to hsp60 for mitochondria, to actin for cytosol, and to PARP for nuclei. For co-immunoprecipitation studies, mitochondrial fraction from 108 sIgD−cells, treated with 10 µg/ml anti-NGF antibodies or control IgG, were lysed in 10 mm Hepes, 142.5 mm KCl, 5 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EGTA, 0.2% Nonidet P-40, pH 7.5, and immunoprecipitated with 1 µg/ml rabbit anti-p38 MAPK Abs, anti-Bcl-2 mAbs, or 1 µg/ml polyclonal rabbit IgG or mouse IgG, followed by protein A-Sepharose or protein G-Sepharose, respectively. The same approach was used with recombinant proteins; a mixture of 200 ng of rBcl-2-His6 and 200 ng of active rp38 MAPK-GST was immunoprecipitated with 1 µg/ml anti-Bcl-2, or with 1 µg/ml rabbit anti-p38 MAPK Abs or control Abs followed by protein G-Sepharose or protein A-Sepharose. The immune complexes were washed, run on 10% SDS-PAGE, and blotted onto nitrocellulose filter. 100 ng of human recombinant Bcl-2-His or hrp38 MAPK-GST were used as internal standard. Surface plasmon resonance analysis was performed using a BIACORE instrument with CM5 sensor chips and an amine coupling kit (BIACORE AB). For immobilization of proteins, the sensor chip was equilibrated with HBS buffer (10 mm Hepes, 150 mm NaCl, 3.4 mm EDTA, pH 7.4, plus 0.005% p20 surfactant) at 5 µl/min and then activated by injecting 35 µl of 0.2 mN-ethyl-N′-3-diethylaminopropylcarbodiimide, 0.05mN-hydroxysuccinimide. 35 µl of kinases or control protein at ∼20 µg/ml in 10 mm sodium acetate, pH 4.5, were then injected. ExcessN-hydroxysuccinimide-esters on the surface were deactivated with 35 µl of 1 methanoldiamine-hydrochloride (pH 8.5), and noncovalently bound dimers were washed out with 10 µl of regeneration buffer (4 mGu-HCl buffered with 50 mm phosphate buffer, pH 6.8). Binding experiments were performed with 10 mm Hepes, 150 mm NaCl, 20 mm MgCl2 as running buffer. For in vivo metabolic labeling, 107 sIgD− cells were incubated with 0.5 mCi of [32P]orthophosphate for 4 h in the presence of 1 µm okadaic acid or 10 µl of ethanol vehicle control, in phosphate-free medium, in the presence or absence of anti-NGF Abs, 25 µm SB203580, SB202474, PD098059, or 100 ng/ml NGF. Cells were then lysed as described, immunoprecipitated with anti-Bcl-2 Abs as reported above, and separated on 10% SDS-PAGE. Gels were dried and autoradiographed on Eastman Kodak Co. XAR films for 72 h at −20 °C. 108 sIgD− cells, treated with rat anti-NGF mAb for 12 h, were lysed in 20 mm Tris, pH 7.4, containing 1% Triton X-100, 10% glycerol, 137 mm NaCl, 2 mm EDTA, 25 mm β-glycerophosphate, 2 mm NaPP, 1 mm NaVO3, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 10 µg/ml leupeptin. 400 µg of proteins were immunoprecipitated in duplicate with 2 µg/ml rabbit anti-p38 MAPK Abs coupled to Sepharose beads or 2 µg/ml rabbit anti-JNK or with 2 µg/ml control rabbit IgG. The efficacy of immunoprecipitation was checked by Western blot analysis with anti-P38 MAPK Ab or anti-JNK Ab. Immune complexes were incubated with 0.25 µg of human recombinant Bcl-2-GST protein or Bcl-2-His6 or 0.25 µg of rATF-2-GST and 3 µCi of [32P]ATP (specific activity 3,000 Ci/mmol; Amersham Pharmacia Biotech), in the presence of 25 µm SB203580, or Me2SO as control, in 30 µl of kinase buffer (25 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, with 25 mm β-glycerophosphate, 2 mm dithiothreitol, 0.1 mm NaVO3). After 30 min at room temperature, samples were suspended in 2-ME sample buffer, run in SDS-PAGE, dried, and autoradiographed on Kodak XAR films for 12 h at −20 °C. A kinase assay was performed in the same experimental conditions by using 0.25 µg of recombinant active or inactive p38 MAPK-GST or JNK-GST and 0.25 µg of rBcl-2-His. To assess the activity of recombinant proteins, 0.25 µg of active rp38 MAPK or rJNK-GST were incubated, with or without 25 µm SB203580, with 0.25 µg of rATF-2-GST in kinase buffer for 30 min in the presence of 3 µCi of [γ-32P]ATP. Samples were run on SDS-PAGE and autoradiographed. Mitochondrial and cytosolic (S100) fractions were prepared by resuspending cells (3 × 107) in 0.8 ml of mitochondrial isolation buffer (250 mm sucrose, 20 mm Hepes, 10 mm KCl, 2 mm MgCl2, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride protease inhibitor, 2 µg/ml leupeptin, 10 µg/ml aprotinin, pH 7.4). Cells were passed through an ice-cold cylinder cell homogenizer. Unlysed cells and nuclei were pelleted via a 10-min, 750 × g spin. The supernatant was spun at 10,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C, and the pellet containing the mitochondrial fraction was suspended in modified mitochondrial isolation buffer with 75 mmMgCl2, containing active p38 MAPK or active JNK (0.25 µg), 200 µm ATP, and 25 mmβ-glycerophosphate. After incubation at 30 °C for 30 min, the mitochondrial mixture reactions were then centrifuged at 4,000 ×g for 10 min, and supernatant and pellet proteins were separated on SDS-PAGE, followed by transfer to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The blot was probed with anti-human cytochrome c peptide mAb (7H8.2C12, Pharmigen), diluted at 1:500. A secondary probe (1:5,000 dilution) with horseradish peroxidase-labeled antibodies (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) was detected by ECL (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). MDCK cells, detached by trypsin-EDTA, were washed twice in phosphate-buffered saline and suspended in 8 ml of mitochondrial isolation buffer. Mitochondrial fractions were obtained as above and incubated for 30 min on ice and 15 min at 22 °C, with or without extracts of E. coli cells (8.5%, v/v), expressing Bcl-2-His6 or transformed with empty plasmid, obtained by lysing the cells with 20 mm Hepes, pH 7.4, 30 mm KCl, 1 mm EDTA, 1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 20 µg/ml aprotinin, 20 µg/ml leupeptin, and 1% CHAPS. 0.25 µg of active p38 MAPK or JNK, with or without 25 µm SB203580, was then added, and the phosphorylation reaction was performed in the presence of 200 µm ATP (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for 30 min at 30 °C. Mitochondrial mixture reactions were then centrifuged at 4,000 × g for 10 min, and then supernatant and pellet proteins were separated on SDS-PAGE, blotted on polyvinylidene difluoride membranes, and stained with anti-human cytochromec mAbs. sIgD− B cell subpopulations were cultured at 5 × 106/ml, with 10 µg/ml anti-NGF mAb or control rat IgG, in the presence or absence of 25 µm SB203580 for 12 h, lysed with 0.1% Triton X-100 in PBS, run on SDS-PAGE, blotted onto nitrocellulose filters, and stained with 1:1,000 anti-PARP mAbs, followed by peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse Abs. Reaction was visualized by ECL. For annexin-V staining, the cells, cultured as above with anti-NGF antibodies in the presence or absence of SB203580, were washed once in PBS, incubated with 5 µg/ml PE-annexin-V (Alexis) in binding buffer (0.01 m Hepes, pH 7.4, 150 mm NaCl, 5 mm KCl, 1 mm MgCl2, 2.5 mm CaCl2) for 15 min at room temperature. After washing, the cells were analyzed by cytofluorimetry. For DNA fragmentation analysis, sIgD−, cultured at 5 × 106/ml, with 10 µg/ml anti-NGF mAb or control rat IgG, in the presence or absence of 25 µm SB203580 for 12 h, were diluted 1:1.5 with 5 mm Tris, 20 mmEDTA, and 0.5% (v/v) Triton X-100, pH 8.0, and allowed to lyse for 15 min on ice before centrifugation for 20 min at 27,000 ×g to separate intact chromatin (pellet) from DNA fragments (supernatant). Pellets were resuspended in 5 ml of a buffer containing 10 mm Tris and 1 mm EDTA, pH 8.0, and pellet and supernatant samples were assayed for DNA content, using the diphenylamine reagent (1.5% diphenylamine in acetic acid plus 10% acetaldehyde) for 16 h at 30 °C. Rubartelli A. Cozzolino F. Aloe L. Garaci E. Cell. 1996; 85: 345-356Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (374) Google Scholar). Cell viability was evaluated by trypan blue dye exclusion. The full-length human-bcl-2 sequence was amplified by polymerase chain reaction from lysates of freshly isolated human lymphocytes and cloned as a BglII/EcoRI fragment in pIRES2-EGFP vector (CLONTECH), using the following primers 5′-TTAGATCTATGGCGCACGCTGGGAGAAC-3′ (forward) and 5′-CCGAATTCTCACTTGTGGCTCAGATAGG-3′ (reverse), yielding the wild type (WT) construct. To replace Thr-56, Ser-70, Thr-74, and Ser-87 with Ala, mutagenesis reactions using a QuikChangeTM site-directed mutagenesis kit (Stratagene) were performed. The Δ-loop plasmid, containing the bcl-2 deletion mutant (Δ40–91 amino acids), was generated by two-step recombinant polymerase chain reaction using WT as template and two oligonucleotide pairs: 5′ - CCACGGGCCCGGCGCCCACATCTCCCGC-3′ with 5′-GCAGAGCTGGTTTAGTGAACCGTCA-3′ and 5′-GGGCCCGTGGTCCACCTGGCCCTCCGCCAA-′ with 5′- TATTCCAAGCGGCTTCGGCCAGTAA-3′. The two polymerase chain reaction products were mixed in the same polymerase chain reaction tube and reamplified with terminal primers. The resulting deleted cDNA was purified, digested withBglII and EcoRI restriction endonucleases, and ligated in the MCS of pIRES2-EGFP. All constructs were verified by sequencing analysis. Transient transfections of CESS cells were obtained by LipofectAMINE (Life Technologies, Inc.). 2 × 106cells were seeded into six-well plates and incubated for 5 h in serum-free medium with 5 µg of test plasmid and lipids, according to the manufacturer's instructions. After 72 h, cells were washed and analyzed by using the FL-1 detector of a FACScan flow cytometer (Becton Dickinson). For each sample, 104 cells were analyzed at a rate of 300 cells/s. The percentage of transfected cells was calculated after subtracting the nonspecific fluorescence of nontransfected cells and resulted in ≥30%. Apoptotic stimuli (10 µg/ml of anti-NGF Abs for 12 h or 200 nm K252a for 6 h) were added 72 h after transfection, and GFP+transfected cells undergoing apoptosis were detected by PE-annexin-V staining and cytofluorimetric analysis with both FL-1 and FL-2 detectors. In the NGF-responsive cell line PC12, deprivation of NGF is followed by rapid phosphorylation of two members of the MAPK family, p38 and JNK (28Kummer J.L. Rao P.K. Heidenreich K.A. J. Biol. These results suggested that in memory B cells p38 MAPK was specifically involved in the NGF signaling, the difference between neural cells and memory B cells probably residing in the expression of p38 MAPK-specific, but not JNK-specific, phosphatase(s) in the latter cells, as described in other systems (32Chu Y. Solski P.A. Khosravi-Far R. Der C.J. Kelly K. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 6497-6501Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (395) Google Scholar). Next, to characterize the molecular pathway comprising activated p38 MAPK and antagonized by NGF, we checked whether neutralization of endogenous NGF signaling with specific Abs (or with Trk-A inhibitor K252a, not shown) caused enzyme hyperphosphorylation, which indeed occurred at early times, as expected on the basis of similar results by others (28Kummer J.L. Rao P.K. Heidenreich K.A. J. Biol. In contrast, JNK was not hyperphosphorylated in the same experimental conditions (Fig. 1B). p38 MAPK is a serine-threonine kinase, whose known molecular targets are nuclear, such as ATF-2 or GADD153, or cytosolic, such as hsp27, proteins (33Tibbles L.A. Woodgett J.R. Cell Mol. Life Sci. 1999; 55: 1230-1254Crossref PubMed Scopus (550) Google Scholar). In the inactive state, its subcellular location is the cytosol, from where it is translocated to the nucleus, following metabolic activation (34Raingeaud J. Whitmarsh A.J. Barrett T. Derijard B. Davis R.J. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 1247-1255Crossref PubMed Scopus (1140) Google Scholar). We next determined by immunofluorescence, using Abs specific for the activated form of p38 MAPK, the amount of memory B cells that scored positive upon NGF neutralization, detecting 73 ± 5% of brightly staining cells, versus 7 ± 2% in control cells, in three independent experiments. During these studies we observed, besides the nuclear staining, a spotted pattern of cytoplasmic staining (within a diffuse cytosolic context), that suggested an additional localization of the activated enzyme. Thus, to assess in detail the physical translocation events of activated p38 MAPK, confocal laser-scanning microscopy experiments were performed on memory B cells treated with anti-NGF or control IgG and with Mitotracker (a rhodamine-like mitochondrial dye) and then fixed and stained with p38 MAPK-specific Abs. Fig.2A shows that, after neutralization of endogenous NGF in memory B cells, a definite mitochondrial focusing of p38 MAPK from its cytosolic, diffuse location was evident, a localization of the enzyme that was so far undetected. Staining with specific Abs revealed that essentially only the activated enzyme translocated to mitochondria (Fig. 2A). Next, to confirm the above results, a biochemical analysis was performed on mitochondrial, nuclear, and cytosolic fractions from cells treated or not with anti-NGF Abs. Fig. 2B shows that p38 MAPK was detected in cytosol and nuclei of cells exposed to control Abs and that the enzyme also accumulated in mitochondria of cells treated with anti-NGF Abs. Interestingly, when the same filters were stained with Abs against the active form of p38 MAPK, specific bands were evident in the mitochondrial and nuclear fractions and completely undetectable in the cytosolic fraction (Fig. 2C). Thus, neutralization of NGF interaction with surface receptors was reflected into activation of a serine/threonine-kinase, whose mitochondrial localization opened the question regarding the function exerted by the enzyme in

Calmodulin (CaM) regulates gating of several types of ion channels but has not been implicated in channel assembly or trafficking. For the SK4/IK1 K+ channel, CaM bound to the proximal C terminus (“Ct1 ” domain) acts as the Ca2+ sensor. We now show that CaM interacting with the C terminus of SK4 also controls channel assembly and surface expression. In transfected cells, removing free CaM by overexpressing the CaM-binding domain, Ct1, redistributed full-length SK4 protein from the plasma membrane to the cytoplasm and decreased whole-cell currents. Making more CaM protein available by overexpressing the CaM gene abrogated the dominant-negative effect ofCt1 and restored both surface expression of SK4 protein and whole-cell currents. The distal C-terminal domain (“Ct2”) also plays a role in assembly, but is not CaM-dependent. Co-immunoprecipitation experiments demonstrated that multimerization of SK4 subunits was enhanced by CaM and inhibited by removal of CaM, indicating that CaM regulates trafficking of SK4 by affecting the assembly of channels. Our results support a model in which CaM-dependent association of SK4 monomers at their Ct1 domains regulates channel assembly and surface expression. This appears to represent a novel mechanism for controlling ion channels, and consequently, the cellular functions that depend on them.
