The process is known as regulated exocytosis, which is often triggered by increased concentration of intracellular calcium ions, followed by docking and fusion of granule membrane with plasma membrane (1Jahn R. Sudhof T.C. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1999; 68: 863-911Crossref PubMed Scopus (1025) Google Scholar). Recent advances have revealed that the complex formation of SNARE proteins that bridge both sides of membranes is crucial for the docking/fusion process (2Sollner T. Whiteheart S.W. Brunner M. Erdjument-Bromage H. Geromanos S. Tempst P. Rothman J.E. Nature. 1993; 362: 318-324Crossref PubMed Scopus (2637) Google Scholar,3Mayer A. Curr. Opin. Cell Biol. 1999; 11: 447-452Crossref PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). Vesicle docking is also regulated by Rab small GTPases at a step upstream of the SNARE complex formation (4Lian J.P. Stone S. Jiang Y. Lyons P. Ferro-Novick S. Nature. 1994; 372: 698-701Crossref PubMed Scopus (161) Google Scholar, 5Sogaard M. Tani K. Ye R.R. Geromanos S. Tempst P. Kirchhausen T. Rothman J.E. Sollner T. Cell. 1994; 78: 937-948Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (443) Google Scholar). Platelets possess dense-core granules, α-granules, and lysosomes, which are secreted upon activation of platelets (6Silverstein R.L. Febbraio M. Blood. 1992; 80: 1470-1475Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 7Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Hoffman R.S., S. Benz E.J. Furie B. Cohen H. Silberstein L.E. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. 3rd Ed. Churchill Livingston, New York2000: 1741-1752Google Scholar). Dense-core granules contain small molecules such as 5-hydroxytriptamine (5-HT)1 and α-granules contain protein factors such as von Willebrand factors (vWF). Despite the biological significance of the secretions in platelet function (7Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Hoffman R.S., S. Benz E.J. Furie B. Cohen H. Silberstein L.E. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. 3rd Ed. Churchill Livingston, New York2000: 1741-1752Google Scholar), the molecular mechanisms governing the secretions remain unclear.N-Ethylmaleimide-sensitive factor and α-SNAP, which are required for priming SNARE proteins in other types of cells (8Mayer A. Wickner W. Haas A. Cell. 1996; 85: 83-94Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (481) Google Scholar), have also been shown to play important roles in granule secretions in platelets (9Polgar J. Reed G.L. Blood. 1999; 94: 1313-1318Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 10Chen D. Bernstein A.M. Lemons P.P. Whiteheart S.W. Blood. 2000; 95: 921-929Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Furthermore, syntaxin 2 and SNAP 23, which are members of the SNARE family, are essential for the dense-core granule secretion (10Chen D. Bernstein A.M. Lemons P.P. Whiteheart S.W. Blood. 2000; 95: 921-929Crossref PubMed Google Scholar), and syntaxin 4 and SNAP 23 function in the α-granule secretion (11Flaumenhaft R. Croce K. Chen E. Furie B. Furie B.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 2492-2501Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (124) Google Scholar). Recently, we have identified small GTPase Rab4 as an essential regulator of α-granule secretion, but not of dense-core granule secretion, using the assay system used in this investigation (12Shirakawa R. Yoshioka A. Horiuchi H. Nishioka H. Tabuchi A. Kita T. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33844-33849Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). In addition to membrane-associated factors such as SNARE proteins and Rab small GTPases, cytosolic factors also play critical roles in intracellular membrane docking/fusion (13Avery J. Jahn R. Edwardson J.M. Annu. Rev. Physiol. 1999; 61: 777-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). For example, Rab5-regulated membrane docking/fusion of early endosomes in vitro is cytosol-dependent and the rate-limiting factor in cytosol was demonstrated to be a protein complex composed of a Rab5 effector, Rabaptin-5, and a Rab5 GDP/GTP exchange factor, Rabex-5 (14Horiuchi H. Lippe R. McBride H.M. Rubino M. Woodman P. Stenmark H. Rybin V. Wilm M. Ashman K. Mann M. Zerial M. Cell. 1997; 90: 1149-1159Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (486) Google Scholar). The Ca2+-induced norepinephrine release from neuroendocrine cells also requires cytosolic factors, including the phosphatidylinositol transfer protein (15Hay J.C. Martin T.F. Nature. 1993; 366: 572-575Crossref PubMed Scopus (308) Google Scholar), phosphatidylinositol-4-phosphate 5-kinase (16Hay J.C. Fisette P.L. Jenkins G.H. Fukami K. Takenawa T. Anderson R.A. Martin T.F. Nature. 1995; 374: 173-177Crossref PubMed Scopus (454) Google Scholar) and Ca2+-dependent activator protein for secretion (CAPS) (17Walent J.H. Porter B.W. Martin T.F. Cell. 1992; 70: 765-775Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar, 18Ann K. Kowalchyk J.A. Loyet K.M. Martin T.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 19637-19640Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (148) Google Scholar), a mammalian homologue of Caenorhabditis elegans unc31. However, cytosolic factors involved in the platelet secretion have not been identified. Protein kinase C (PKC) family members are important signaling molecules (19Nishizuka Y. Science. 1992; 258: 607-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (4232) Google Scholar, 20Newton A.C. Johnson J.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1376: 155-172Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar). Conventional PKCs have regulatory Ca2+- and phorbol ester-binding domains (19Nishizuka Y. Science. 1992; 258: 607-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (4232) Google Scholar, 20Newton A.C. Johnson J.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1376: 155-172Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar). The function of PKC as a signaling molecule has been analyzed mainly pharmacologically using small cell-permeable compounds of inhibitors and stimulators such as phorbol esters. Recently, Munc13-1, which contains a phorbol ester-binding domain, has been demonstrated to play an important role in membrane docking/fusion in exocytosis in synapses (21Betz A. Ashery U. Rickmann M. Augustin I. Neher E. Sudhof T.C. Rettig J. Brose N. Neuron. 1998; 21: 123-136Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (337) Google Scholar, 22Augustin I. Rosenmund C. Sudhof T.C. Brose N. Nature. 1999; 400: 457-461Crossref PubMed Scopus (567) Google Scholar). Specifically, we do not understand whether the effects of phorbol ester are mediated by Munc13 and/or PKC. Therefore, the interpretation of the earlier reports with experiments using phorbol ester has become complicated especially concerning vesicle transport. Furthermore, since PKC increases intracellular Ca2+ concentration through modulation of Ca2+ channels in the plasma membrane in neurons (23Swartz K.J. Neuron. 1993; 11: 305-320Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (186) Google Scholar, 24Stea A. Soong T.W. Snutch T.P. Neuron. 1995; 15: 929-940Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (194) Google Scholar), it remains a question whether PKC acts upstream and/or downstream of increase of Ca2+. In platelets, PKC inhibitors have been shown to inhibit platelet aggregation and granule release, and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, a phorbol ester, have been shown to stimulate both functions (25Kaibuchi K. Takai Y. Sawamura M. Hoshijima M. Fujikura T. Nishizuka Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 6701-6704Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 26Siess W. Lapetina E.G. Biochem. J. 1988; 255: 309-318PubMed Google Scholar, 27Gerrard J.M. Beattie L.L. Park J. Israels S.J. McNicol A. Lint D. Cragoe E.J. Blood. 1989; 74: 2405-2413Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Therefore, PKC has been considered to be an important signaling molecule in platelet activation (7Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Hoffman R.S., S. Benz E.J. Furie B. Cohen H. Silberstein L.E. Hematology: Basic Principles and Practice. 3rd Ed. Churchill Livingston, New York2000: 1741-1752Google Scholar). However, with reasons described above, further characterization of PKC function in platelet activation is required especially in the granule secretions. Here, we have demonstrated that the Ca2+-induced secretions of α- and dense-core granules in platelets are ATP- and cytosol-dependent and that PKCα is an essential, but not sufficient, cytosolic factor for both secretions. The standard assay method was essentially as described previously (12Shirakawa R. Yoshioka A. Horiuchi H. Nishioka H. Tabuchi A. Kita T. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33844-33849Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Briefly, freshly obtained washed platelets (5 × 107platelets per assay, counted with Coulter counter) were incubated with [3H]5-HT (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) to allow uptake into dense-core granules. After washing the platelets, the platelet plasma membrane was permeabilized in Buffer A (50 mmHepes/KOH, pH 7.2, 78 mm KCl, 4 mmMgCl2, 0.2 mm CaCl2, 2 mm EGTA, 1 mm dithiothreitol, the calculated free calcium ion concentration was ∼20 nm (28Fabiato A. Fabiato F. J. Physiol. (Paris). 1979; 75: 463-505PubMed Google Scholar)) containing 4 mg/ml bovine serum albumin and 0.6 µg/ml SLO as described (12Shirakawa R. Yoshioka A. Horiuchi H. Nishioka H. Tabuchi A. Kita T. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33844-33849Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Approximately, more than 80% of the cytosolic lactate dehydrogenase was recovered in the media by the procedure, measured with lactate dehydrogenase-cytotoxic test kit (Wako Chemical, Osaka, Japan). Usually, the permeabilized platelets per assay contained ∼20,000 cpm of [3H]5-HT. Unless otherwise specified, the platelets were incubated in Buffer A containing 4 mg/ml bovine serum albumin with an ATP regeneration system containing 8 mm creatine phosphate, 50 µg/ml creatine phosphokinase, and 1 mm ATP, cytosol, and/or others at 4 °C for 60 min followed by further incubation at 30 °C for 5 min. Finally, the platelets were stimulated with 20 µm Ca2+(28Fabiato A. Fabiato F. J. Physiol. (Paris). 1979; 75: 463-505PubMed Google Scholar) by addition of CaCl2 at 30 °C for 1 min. Then, after removing the platelets by centrifugation, aliquots of the supernatant containing any secreted [3H]5-HT and vWF were measured for the presence of [3H]5-HT by a liquid scintillation counter (Beckman) and of vWF by Western blot analysis after immunoprecipitation with anti-vWF antibody (Sigma) followed by quantification using densitometric detection and NIH Image software. Secretion levels of vWF and [3H]5-HT were expressed as percentages of the total vWF and [3H]5-HT, respectively, above those (3–8% of total vWF and 5–10% of total [3H]5-HT) released before the final incubation. Unless otherwise specified, they were expressed as mean ± S.E. of more than five independent experiments with similar results. For vWF secretion, representative Western blots were also shown in some figures. Fifty rats were anesthetized and sacrificed. The rat brains were homogenized in Buffer A using a Potter-type blender and centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 30 min at 4 °C. The supernatant was used as rat brain cytosol. The cytosols of Jurkat cells and HeLa cells were prepared in a similar way. The cytosol of human platelets isolated from blood of healthy volunteers was prepared in a similar way except using sonication instead of a Potter-type blender. The purification procedures were carried out at 4 °C and column chromatography was performed using the fast protein liquid chromatography system (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The assay during the purification was carried out with rat brain cytosol at 0.5 mg of protein/ml, which supported 5–10% secretions over the controls (Fig. 7). In each purification procedure (TableI), the activity for both α- and dense-core granule secretions was recovered in a single peak which supported both α- and dense-core granule secretions. The rat brain cytosol was fractionated by ammonium sulfate precipitation. The precipitate was dialyzed against Buffer A without KCl. The peak was recovered in a 35–55% precipitate. The fraction was loaded onto a Mono-Q HR 10/10 column equilibrated with Buffer A without KCl, and eluted with a linear gradient of KCl. The peak of the activity was recovered at around 100 mm KCl. The collected fractions were dialyzed with Buffer A (pH 6.5) without KCl and loaded onto a Mono-S HR 5/5 equilibrated with buffer A (pH 6.5) without KCl, and eluted with a linear gradient of KCl. The peak of the activity was recovered at KCl concentration around 150 mm. The collected peak fractions were then concentrated with Centricon 10 (Amicon) and separated by Superdex 200 gel filtration column in Buffer A. The peak of the activity was recovered between the protein markers (Bio-Rad) of 44 and 158 kDa. The collected peak fractions were added with KCl to adjust the KCl concentration at 2 m. Then the sample was loaded onto a hydrophobic-interaction column, Resource PHE, equilibrated with Buffer A containing 2 m KCl, and eluted with a decreasing linear gradient of KCl. The peak of the activity was recovered at a KCl concentration around 250 mm. For the characterization of PKCα, the samples purified by the last column Resource PHE were used as purified PKCα. By using this procedure, a protein band at 80 kDa was purified to homogeneity in a Coomassie Blue-stained SDS-PAGE gel and the intensity was paralleled with the secretion activity. The band was excised and analyzed for partial amino acid sequencing by Edman's method (29Edman P. Mol. Biol. Biochem. Biophys. 1970; 8: 211-255PubMed Google Scholar) performed by Apro Science Co. (Tokushima, Japan). Then, the GST-JAM290 was collected with glutathione-Sepharose beads (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). The phosphorylation levels of the JAM290 were analyzed by autoradiography after SDS-PAGE. Anti-vWF rabbit polyclonal antibody was purchased from Sigma, anti-PKCα rabbit polyclonal antibody used for Western blot analysis was from Santa Cruz, anti-PKCα mouse monoclonal antibody used for immunodepletion was from Transduction Laboratories, and a control mouse IgG from Zymed Laboratories Inc. Horseradish peroxidase-labeled anti-mouse and anti-rabbit IgG monoclonal antibodies were from Amersham Pharmacia Biotech, which were used as secondary antibodies for Western blot analysis visualized by the enhanced chemiluminescence method (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Unless otherwise specified, all the chemicals were purchased from Sigma, except Gö6850 (bisindolylmaleimide 1) which was from Calbiochem Co. and streptolysin-O (SLO) from Dr. Bhakdi, Mainz University, Mainz, Germany. Protein concentrations were determined by Bradford's method (31Bradford M.M. Anal. Biochem. 1976; 72: 248-254Crossref PubMed Scopus (217544) Google Scholar) (Bio-Rad) or densitometric scanning of the Coomassie Blue-stained band of SDS-PAGE, using bovine serum albumin as a standard. We established an in vitro assay system using SLO-permeabilized platelets by monitoring secreted vWF stored in α-granules and [3H]5-HT in dense-core granules (12Shirakawa R. Yoshioka A. Horiuchi H. Nishioka H. Tabuchi A. Kita T. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33844-33849Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). It is well known that agonists drive the granule secretions by increasing intracellular calcium ion concentrations in platelets (32Knight D.E. Hallam T.J. Scrutton M.C. Nature. 1982; 296: 256-257Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Since the calcium ion concentration inside the platelets would be the same as that of the outside following permeabilization, we used calcium chloride as a stimulus. Therefore, we analyzed the secretion mechanism triggered by increased Ca2+. In the assay, secretions of α- and dense-core granules appeared physiological, since the characterization of the secretions revealed similar time course and Ca2+sensitivity to those in intact platelets (12Shirakawa R. Yoshioka A. Horiuchi H. Nishioka H. Tabuchi A. Kita T. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 33844-33849Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (90) Google Scholar). Without addition of ATP, Ca2+ did not induce α-granule secretion (vWF) or dense-core granule secretion ([3H]5-HT) (data not shown) (33Knight D.E. Scrutton M.C. Thromb. Res. 1980; 20: 437-446Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar, 34Haslam R.J. Davidson M.M. FEBS Lett. 1984; 174: 90-95Crossref PubMed Scopus (113) Google Scholar), indicating that ATP is essential for both secretions. The permeabilized platelets were extensively depleted of cytosol since more than 80% of lactate dehydrogenase, a cytosolic protein, was recovered in the media following permeabilization (data not shown). Under this condition, Ca2+ did not induce α- (Fig.1A) or dense-core (Fig.1B) granule secretion without addition of exogenous cytosol, even in the presence of ATP. On the other hand, the Ca2+-induced secretions of both types of granules were efficiently reconstituted by addition of both ATP and rat brain cytosol (Fig. 1, A and B). The efficient secretions were also confirmed morphologically with electron microscopy, since most of the granules in the permeabilized platelets disappeared upon Ca2+ stimulation in the presence of ATP and cytosol (data not shown), as shown previously (35Sloan D.C. Haslam R.J. Biochem. J. 1997; 328: 13-21Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). These results indicated that both ATP and cytosolic factor(s) are essential for the Ca2+-induced secretions in platelets. The cytosol dependence indicated the presence of essential cytosolic factor(s) for the secretions. Cytosols of human fibroblast cell line, HeLa cells, and human T-cell cell line, Jurkat cells, also supported the Ca2+-induced secretions of both granules (data not shown), suggesting that the essential cytosolic factor(s) are expressed ubiquitously among various species and tissues. The cytosol dependence prompted us to identify the essential factor(s) in the cytosol. The Ca2+-induced secretions of both vWF and [3H]5-HT were almost maximal in the presence of rat brain cytosol at 2–5 mg of protein/ml (Figs. 6 and 7). In order to maintain minimal secretory activity, the assays during the purification procedure were performed in the presence of rat brain cytosol at 0.5 mg of protein/ml, which supported ∼5–10% of both secretions induced by Ca2+ (Figs. 6 and 7). We first separated rat brain cytosol by Superdex 200 gel filtration column (Fig. 2A). We detected a potent peak of secretion supporting activity between markers 44 and 158 kDa (Bio-Rad) (Fig. 2A). Notably, the peaks for α- and dense-core granule secretions were almost completely overlapped, suggesting that the factor is common for both secretions. Then, we scaled up the purification procedure. The purification was performed by ammonium sulfate precipitation and sequential column chromatography with Mono-Q, Mono-S, Superdex 200, and Resource PHE columns as described under “Experimental Procedures.” During each procedure (Table I), the most potent activity for either α- or dense-core granule secretion was recovered in a single peak. Then, the peaks of both α- and dense-core granule secretions were almost completely overlapped in each column chromatography (data not shown). In Superdex 200 gel filtration column chromatography, the peak fraction emerged at a position between 44 and 158 kDa (data not shown), similar to the results in experiments of the direct separation of the cytosol by Superdex 200 (Fig. 2A). As shown in Fig. 2B, a band with apparent molecular mass at ∼80 kDa was purified to homogeneity after the fifth step of Superdex 200 column chromatography (Table I). Furthermore, the active fractions were collected and fractionated by a hydrophobic interaction column, Resource PHE. The secretion-supporting activities for both granules again paralleled the 80-kDa band (data not shown). The molecular weight was consistent with the results in the Superdex 200 gel filtration column chromatography for direct separation of rat brain cytosol (Fig. 2A). Taken together, the 80-kDa protein was most likely the essential common factor for both secretions. The partial amino acid sequences of the purified 80-kDa protein excised from the SDS-PAGE gel after the Resource PHE column chromatography (Fig. 2B, lane 6) were determined by the Edman's method (29Edman P. Mol. Biol. Biochem. Biophys. 1970; 8: 211-255PubMed Google Scholar). The determined sequence IARFF, LIPMDPNGL, and IRSTLNPQW completely corresponded to the sequences of rat PKCα 38–44, 182–191, and 214–222, respectively (36Ono Y. Fujii T. Igarashi K. Kikkawa U. Ogita K. Nishizuka Y. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 5199-5200Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Since all three sequences corresponded to parts of the rat PKCα sequence, the 80-kDa protein was determined to be PKCα which was a conventional type of PKC composed of 672 amino acids with a calculated molecular mass of 76.6 kDa (36Ono Y. Fujii T. Igarashi K. Kikkawa U. Ogita K. Nishizuka Y. Nucleic Acids Res. 1988; 16: 5199-5200Crossref PubMed Scopus (58) Google Scholar). Accordingly, Gö6850, a PKC inhibitor, concentration dependently inhibited the Ca2+-induced secretions of both types of granules in the permeabilized platelets (Fig.3, A and B). Gö6850 at 10 µm almost completely inhibited both secretions (Fig. 3, A and B). Furthermore, when PKCα was immunodepleted from the purified samples with anti-PKCα monoclonal antibody-coated beads (Fig.4A), the immunodepleted samples lost the secretion stimulatory activity for both types of granules (Fig. 4, B and C). Thus, PKCα was identified to be an essential factor in rat brain cytosol for the Ca2+-induced secretions of both α- and dense-core granules in platelets.Figure 4The purified PKC α sample immunodepleted with anti-PKCα antibody (A) lost the stimulatory activity of the Ca2+-induced secretion of α- (B) and dense-core (C) granules.A, the purified PKCα samples (lane 1) were immunodepleted with an anti-PKCα monoclonal antibody (lane 2) or a control mouse IgG (lane 3). Then, the samples were analyzed by Western blot with anti-PKCα polyclonal antibody.B and C, the permeabilized platelets were incubated for 60 min at 4 °C in the presence of 0.5 mg of protein/ml rat brain cytosol and the ATP regeneration system with the purified PKCα (40 nm) (lane 2), the purified PKCα after immunodepletion as shown in A (lanes 3 and4) or without purified PKC (lane 1). The platelets were then stimulated with 20 µmCa2+ for 1 min at 30 °C and released vWF (B) and [3H]5-HT (C) were measured as described under “Experimental Procedures.” The data shown were mean ± S.E. in five independent experiments. Suzuki H. Kita T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 2000; 276: 873-878Crossref PubMed Scopus (64) Google Scholar) of JAM, a cell-cell adhesion molecule (37Martin-Padura I. Lostaglio S. Schneemann M. GST-JAM290 was hardly phosphorylated by the permeabilized platelets alone without the purified PKCα (Fig.5, lane 3). On the other hand, the purified PKCα alone weakly phosphorylated GST-JAM290 (Fig. 5,lane 4). The phosphorylation level of GST-JAM290 was strongly enhanced in the presence of both purified PKCα and permeabilized platelets (Fig. 5, lane 5) to the similar level obtained in the experiments with the purified PKCα, permeabilized platelets, and phorbol 12-myristate 13-acetate, a PKC activator (Fig. 5, lane 1). These results suggested that the exogenously added PKCα was indeed activated in the assay by Ca2+ and the permeabilized platelets. Since PKCα is activated by Ca2+ in the presence of activators such as phosphatidylserine and diacylglycerol (19Nishizuka Y. Science. 1992; 258: 607-614Crossref PubMed Scopus (4232) Google Scholar, 20Newton A.C. Johnson J.E. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1376: 155-172Crossref PubMed Scopus (244) Google Scholar), the permeabilized platelet membrane could substitute for the activators. In another set of experiments, 10 µm Gö6850 completely inhibited Ca2+-induced phosphorylation of GST-JAM290 in the presence of permeabilized platelets (data not shown). Since Gö6850 at 10 µm also inhibited platelet secretion as shown in Fig. 3, catalytic activity of PKC could be required for secretion. We characterized the purified PKCα in the Ca2+-induced secretions in permeabilized platelets. First, we examined the amount of PKC remaining after permeabilization by Western blot analysis. Since we detected very little PKC associated with the permeabilized platelets after the procedure (data not shown), most of the PKC in the platelets appeared to be lost by diffusion through holes in the plasma membrane. Second, we carefully determined the PKC concentration in rat brain cytosol by Western blot analysis using purified PKCα as a control. The PKC concentration in the ra

Gain-of-function mutations in the gene encoding the receptor tyrosine kinase RET have been identified as the aetiological factor for multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2A (MEN2A). MEN2A is a dominantly-inherited cancer predisposition syndrome characterized by medullary thyroid carcinoma, a tumour of the calcitonin-producing thyroid C-cells. There are three isoforms of RET: RET9, RET43 and RET51, and although in vitro evidence suggests they vary in cellular transformation activities, little is known about their function in tumorigenesis in vivo. To address this, we used RET51 cDNA to construct mice in which the most frequent MEN2A mutation, Cys-634-Arg, was expressed under the control of the human calcitonin promoter (CT-2A mice). These mice developed C-cell tumours resembling human MTC and follicular tumours resembling human papillary thyroid carcinoma (PTC) depending on the founder line examined. One founder line developed compound MTC/PTC at low frequency (8%) and pancreatic cystadenocarcinoma. CT-2A mice also displayed a developmental defect in thyroid follicular structure, in which much of the thyroid was occupied by large irregular cystic follicles thought to be derived from the ultimobranchial body, a developmental precursor of the thyroid gland. The CT-2A mice will provide a suitable model to further study the effects of the MEN 2A RET mutation in vivo.

The Saccharomyces cerevisiaepheromone, α-factor (WHWLQLKPGQPMY), and Ste2p, its G protein-coupled receptor, were studied as a model for peptide ligand-receptor interaction. The affinities and activities of various synthetic position-10 α-factor analogs with Ste2p expressing mutations at residues Ser47 and Thr48 were investigated. All mutant receptors were expressed at a similar level in the cytoplasmic membrane, and their efficacies of signal transduction were similar to that of the wild-type receptor. Mutant receptors differed in binding affinity (Kd) and potency (EC50) for gene induction by α-factor. One mutant receptor (S47K,T48K) had dramatically reduced affinity and activity for [Lys10]- and [Orn10]α-factor, whereas the affinity forSaccharomyces kluyveri α-factor (WHWLSFSKGEPMY) was increased over 20-fold compared with that of wild-type receptor. In contrast, the affinity of [Lys10]- and [Orn10]α-factor was increased greatly in a S47E,T48E mutant receptor, whereas the binding of the S. kluyveriα-factor was abolished. The affinity of [Lys10]- and [Orn10]α-factor for the S47E,T48E receptor dropped 4–6-fold in the presence of 1 m NaCl, whereas the affinity of α-factor was not affected by this treatment. These results demonstrate that when bound to its receptor the 10th residue (Gln) of the S. cerevisiae α-factor is adjacent to Ser47 and Thr48 residues in the receptor and that the 10th residue of α-factors from two Saccharomycesspecies is responsible for the ligand selectivity to their cognate receptors. Based on these data, we have developed a two-dimensional model of α-factor binding to its receptor. G protein-coupled receptor transmembrane domain high performance liquid chromatography [3H-Pro8,Nle12]α-factor trifluoroacetic acid wild type G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs)1 comprise a broadly distributed class of transmembrane proteins that mediate cellular responses to extracellular signals such as light, hormones, and neurotransmitters. Upon activation, GPCRs interact with a cytoplasmic heterotrimeric G protein, leading to the exchange of GTP for bound GDP and dissociation into its subunits, which in turn activates diverse pathways mediated by molecules such as protein kinases, adenylate cyclase, phospholipases, and ion channels (1Dohlman H.G. Thorner J. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1991; 60: 653-688Crossref PubMed Scopus (1132) Google Scholar, 2Ostrowski J. Kjelsberg M.A. Caron M.G. Lefkowitz R.J. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 1992; 32: 167-183Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). GPCRs contain a common structural pattern consisting of seven hydrophobic segments that are predicted to form transmembrane helices. A detailed knowledge of the structure of GPCRs will be required to understand the determinants of ligand binding and the mechanism by which binding leads to activation of the cytoplasmic G protein. Except for a recent crystallographic structure of rhodopsin (3Placzewski K. Kumasaka T. Hori T. Behnke C.A. Motoshima H. Fox B.A. Le Trong I. Teller D.C. Okada T. Stenkamp R.E. Yamamoto M. Miyano M. Science. 2000; 289: 739-745Crossref PubMed Scopus (5022) Google Scholar), the difficulty of obtaining, purifying, solubilizing, and crystallizing integral membrane proteins has hindered the application of x-ray crystallography to all other GPCRs. The size of the GPCR membrane complex prevents application of high resolution NMR procedures to solve the three-dimensional structure of the receptor. However, insights into the structural basis underlying the biological function of the GPCRs have come from the analysis of mutant receptors, either site-directed or chimeric, where large stretches of residues are swapped for those of a related receptor. Mutant receptors have been used to examine several aspects of receptor functions including post-translational modifications, G protein coupling, and, of most relevance to us, ligand binding. The tridecapeptide α-factor pheromone (WHWLQLKPGQPMY) ofSaccharomyces cerevisiae induces conjugation in yeast by binding to Ste2p, its cognate GPCR, activating a G protein signal pathway that is highly conserved with mammalian signaling pathways (4Leberer E. Thomas D.Y. Whiteway M. Curr. Opin. Genet. Dev. 1997; 7: 59-66Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar). This peptide has been studied extensively as a model for understanding the biochemistry of mammalian peptide hormones. 1H NMR studies on this peptide indicate that the Lys7-Gln10 residues assume a β-turn structure and that this conformational feature is an important factor in the bioactive state of the molecule (5Jelicks L.A. Naider F. Shenbagamurthi P. Becker J.M. Broido M.S. Biopolymers. 1988; 27: 431-449Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar, 6Gounarides J.S. Broido M.S. Becker J.M. Naider F. Biochemistry. 1993; 32: 908-917Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). This structural feature has been supported by further studies of covalently constrained (7Yang W. McKinney A. Becker J.M. Naider F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1308-1315Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar) and peptidomimetic analogs (8Zhang Y.L. Marepalli H.R. Lu H.-F. Becker J.M. Naider F. Biochemistry. 1998; 37: 12465-12476Crossref PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). In addition, a recent systematic investigation of the importance of the side chain functionality of α-factor using l-Ala and d-Ala scanning of its primary sequence pinpointed residues or segments with dominant roles in forming the biologically active conformation of α-factor (residues 7–10), in receptor binding (residues 10–13), and in receptor activation and signal transduction (residues 1–4) (9Abel M.G. Zhang Y.L. Lu H.-F. Naider F. Becker J.M. J. Peptide Res. 1998; 52: 95-106Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). The structure and function of the α-factor receptor (Ste2p) have been studied extensively. Analysis of constitutively active mutants indicated that residues in the sixth transmembrane domain (TM6) play a key role in receptor activation (10Konopka J.B. Margarit M. Dube P. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 6764-6769Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar, 11Sommers C.M. Martin N.P. Akal-Strader A. Becker J.M. Naider F. Dumont M.E. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 6898-6909Crossref PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). Studies of the intracellular domains of the receptor have demonstrated that the third intracellular loop is important for G protein activation (12Clark C.D. Palzkill T. Botstein D. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8831-8841Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Mutagenesis studies also indicated that the cytoplasmic C terminus is involved in down-regulation of receptors by endocytosis (13Schandel K.A. Jenness D.D. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1994; 14: 7245-7255Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) and desensitization of receptors by phosphorylation (14Chen Q. Konopka J.B. Mol. Cell. Biol. 1996; 16: 247-257Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). In addition to the results of the functional studies described above, results from cysteine cross-linking experiments between TM5 and TM6 (15Dube P. DeCostanzo A. Konopka J.B. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 26492-26499Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar) defined the spatial proximity of these domains of the receptor, and a biophysical study of synthetic peptides corresponding to each TM of Ste2p (16Xie H. Ding F.-X. Schreiber D. Eng G. Liu S.-F Arshava B. Arevalo E Becker J.M. Naider F. Biochemistry. 2000; 39: 15462-15474Crossref PubMed Scopus (46) Google Scholar) provided evidence for the heptahelical nature of this GPCR. Taken together the above studies indicated that, despite a lack of sequence similarity among the GPCR family members, there is a remarkable similarity in the overall structure and function of these receptors. Despite numerous studies concerning the structure and function of α-factor pheromone or its receptor, very few studies have focused on the identification of the ligand binding sites. Although no information has been published yet on determinants involved in ligand binding to the α-factor receptor, a few recent studies provided valuable information for identifying the α-factor binding sites. In an α-factor receptor containing a mutation in TM1 (F55V), [d-Ala10]α-factor was an agonist with a good binding affinity, whereas the affinities of α-factor and several antagonists (modified or truncated at the N terminus of α-factor) were decreased by 10–100-fold (17Abel M.G. Lee B.-K. Naider F. Becker J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1448: 12-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar). Because [d-Ala10]α-factor did not bind to the wild-type receptor (9Abel M.G. Zhang Y.L. Lu H.-F. Naider F. Becker J.M. J. Peptide Res. 1998; 52: 95-106Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar), we hypothesized that one aspect of the binding of α-factor to the receptor involved interactions of the C terminus of the pheromone (residues 10–13) with the extracellular part of TM1. Additional information for identifying α-factor binding sites has come from the study of chimeras of the S. cerevisiae andSaccharomyces kluyveri α-factor receptors. The α-factor receptors from these two related species exhibit 50% overall identity to each other (18Marsh L. Herskowitz I. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1988; 85: 3855-3859Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). The S. kluyveri α-factor pheromone (WHWLSFSKGEPMY) shows identity to the S. cerevisiaeα-factor at 8 of 13 residues (19Egel-Mitani M. Hansen M.T. Nucleic Acids Res. 1987; 15: 6303Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). Using chimeras of these two α-factor receptors, Sen et al. (20Sen M. Marsh L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 968-973Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 21Sen M. Shah A. Marsh L. Curr. Genet. 1997; 31: 235-240Crossref PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) identified small extracellular regions that determined the specificity of ligand binding and/or receptor activation. Residues 47–49 (STV in S. cerevisiae and KKI in S. kluyveri α-factor receptor) at the junction between the N-terminal domain and TM1 were found to control binding specificity and were proposed to be a direct contact region with one or more of the five variant residues of the two α-factors (residues 5–8 and 10). In light of these chimera studies, a turn structure in residues 7–10 of α-factor, and potential interactions between the C terminus of α-factor and TM1, we hypothesized that the 10th residue of α-factor interacts with residues 47–48 of the receptor. To test this hypothesis, we constructed receptors with mutations in this region and tested the binding affinities and biological activities of these constructs with α-factor and its analogs in which the 10th residue was substituted by various functional groups. The yeast strain used in the study, LM102, has been described by Sen and Marsh (20Sen M. Marsh L. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 968-973Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The relevant genotype is MATa, bar1, leu2,ura3, FUS1-lacZ::URA3,ste2-dl (the α-factor receptor coding region deletion). LM102 was used as the recipient of the wild-type and site-directed mutant STE2, and used to measure pheromone-induced growth arrest (halo assay) and pheromone-induced gene expression (lacZ assay) and to determine pheromone binding. The strain carried the bar1 mutant allele inactivating the BAR1 protease that is responsible for degradation of α-factor. The wild-type STE2 gene with a native promoter was cloned into a yeast/bacterial shuttle vector, pGA314.WT (17Abel M.G. Lee B.-K. Naider F. Becker J.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1998; 1448: 12-26Crossref PubMed Scopus (24) Google Scholar) and was used as a template for the site-directed mutagenesis of the α-factor receptor gene. This plasmid carries the TRP1 gene as a selectable marker and is a low copy CEN-based plasmid. Single-stranded phagemid DNA of pGA314.WT was prepared by infecting Escherichia coli strain CJ236 (ung−,dut−) carrying pGA314.WT with the helper phage M13KO7 (22Vieira J. Messing J. Methods in Enzymology. 1987; 153: 3-11Crossref PubMed Scopus (2007) Google Scholar). Oligonucleotide-directed mutagenesis of single-stranded phagemid DNA was constructed as described by Kunkel et al. (23Kunkel T.A. Sabatino R.D. Bambara R.A. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 154: 367-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (4558) Google Scholar). The product of the mutagenesis reaction mixture was transformed intoE. coli strain DH5α (Life Technologies, Inc.), and transformants were selected on ampicillin-containing plates. Plasmids were then isolated from transformants using the Wizard Miniprep kit (Promega). After sequence confirmation, constructs were transformed into yeast strain LM102 (ste2-deletion strain), and transformants were selected by their growth in the medium lacking tryptophane. All primers were purchased from Sigma/Genosys (The Woodlands, TX). Sequences of the primers are: 5′-GCAAGGTTTAGTTAACAAGACTGTTACTCAGGCC for the S47K mutation; 5′-GCAAGGTTTAGTTAACAGTAAGGTTACTCAGGCC for the T48K mutation; 5′-GCAAGGTTTAGTTAACAAGAAGGTTACTCAGGCC for the S47K,T48K double mutation; and 5′-GCAACCTTTAGTTAACGAGGAGGTTACTCAGGCC for the S47E,T48E double mutation. DNA sequencing was carried out in the DNA sequencing facility located on the campus of the University of Tennessee. l-Norleucine, which is isosteric withl-methionine, was incorporated at position 12 to replacel-methionine in all the analogs. This replacement was shown previously to result in an analog with activity and binding affinity equal to that of native pheromone (24Raths S.K. Naider F. Becker J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17333-17341Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The solid-phase syntheses of five analogs (Table I) were carried on an Applied Biosystems 433 peptide synthesizer (Applied Biosystems, Foster City, CA) starting withN-α-9-fluorenylmethoxycarbonyl-Tyr(OtBu)-Wang resin (0.65 mmol/g resin, Advanced ChemTech, Louisville, KY). The synthesis of α-factor, [Asp10]α-factor, and [Glu10]α-factor were described previously (7Yang W. McKinney A. Becker J.M. Naider F. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 1308-1315Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). The 0.1-mmol FastMoc chemistry of Applied Biosystems was used for the peptide chain elongation with a 2-(H-benzotriazole-1-yl)-1,1,3,3-tetramethyluronium hexaflourophosphate/N-hydroxybenzotriazole/diisopropylethylamine-catalyzed single coupling using 4 equivalents of protected amino acid and a 30-min coupling time followed by an Ac2O/N-hydroxybenzotriazole/diisopropylethylamine capping (10 min). The N-α-protected peptide resin was washed thoroughly with 1-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone and dichloromethane and dried in vacuo for 2 h. The cleavage was carried out in a mixture of TFA, crystalline phenol, ethane-1,2-dithiol, thioanisole, and water at room temperature for 1.5 h. After the evaporation of trifluoroacetic acid under reduced pressure, the residue was precipitated and thoroughly washed with ethyl ether and extracted into 20% aqueous acetonitrile. The crude peptide was purified by reversed phase HPLC (Hewlett-Packard Series 1050) on a semipreparative Waters Bondapak C18 (19 × 300-mm) column. The cleavage product was applied to the column and eluted with a linear gradient of water and acetonitrile, both containing 0.025% trifluoroacetic acid from 0 to 55% acetonitrile. The fractions were collected and analyzed on an analytical Waters μBondapak C18 column (3.9 × 300 mm). The fractions of more than 99% homogeneity were combined and lyophilized, and purity was judged with analytical HPLC using two different solvent systems and with high performance capillary electrophoresis (Hewlett-Packard 3D-CE model G1600A). Open table in a new tab Synthetic [Nle12]α-factor was labeled by the reduction of dehydroproline containing α-factor by the TR3 hydrogenation procedure of Amersham Pharmacia Biotech as described previously (24Raths S.K. Naider F. Becker J.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 17333-17341Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Unpurified labeled peptide (dissolved in ethanol/water 1:1) was dried in vacuo, redissolved in sterile water, and purified by HPLC using a Waters μBondapak C18 column (3.9 × 300 mm) on a Beckman System Gold HPLC. The peptide solution was injected into the HPLC and eluted with a water/acetonitrile gradient from 0 to 40% acetonitrile. Fractions containing peptide eluting from the column similarly to unlabeled α-factor (elution at 32.3% CH3CN) were collected and counted for radioactivity in a scintillation counter. All collected fractions were dried, resuspended in storage buffer (1 mm methionine, 0.03% trifluoroacetic acid, and 20% ethanol), andcombined, and the concentration and specific activity of the purified labeled peptide were determined. Yeast nitrogen base medium (Difco) without amino acids (SD medium) supplemented with histidine (20 μg/ml), leucine (30 μg/ml), and methionine (20 μg/ml) was overlaid with 4 ml of cell suspension (2.5 × 105cells/ml of Nobel agar). Filter disks (sterile blanks from Difco), 8 mm in diameter, were impregnated with 10-μl portions of peptide solutions at various concentrations and placed onto the overlay. The plates were incubated at 30 °C for 24–36 h and then observed for clear zones (halos) around the disks. The data were expressed as the diameter of the halo including the diameter of the disc. All assays were carried out at least three times with no more than a 2-mm variation in halo size at a particular amount applied for each peptide. The data were plotted as halo size versus the amount of peptide and linearized by regression analysis. To compare the relative activities of different peptides with different receptors, the amount of peptide producing a halo size of a particular size was determined from the regression line. NaCl (1 m) was added to the medium and peptide solution to test the effect of high salt on the growth arrest assay. Halo size was measured after 48–60 h incubation because of the slow growth rate of the culture in the presence of 1m NaCl. S. cerevisiaeLM102 carries a FUS1-lacZ gene that is inducible by mating pheromone. Cells were grown overnight in SD medium at 30 °C to 5 × 106 cells/ml, washed by centrifugation, and grown for one doubling (hemocytometer count) at 30 °C. Induction was performed by adding 0.5 ml of peptide at various concentrations to 4.5 ml of concentrated cells (1 × 108 cells/ml). The mixtures were vortexed and placed at 30 °C with shaking for 2 h. After this time, cells were harvested by centrifugation, and each pellet was resuspended and assayed for β-galactosidase activity (expressed as Miller units) in triplicate by a modification (25Kippert F. FEMS Microbiol. Lett. 1995; 128: 201-206PubMed Google Scholar) of a standard protocol (26Guarente L. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 101: 167-180Crossref PubMed Scopus (273) Google Scholar, 27Miller J.H. Experiments in Molecular Genetics. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1972Google Scholar). EC50 and Emax values were calculated with a 95% confidence interval using GraphPad Prism software (sigmoidal dose-response curve fitting, variable slope). Each experiment was carried out at least three times with the results similar in each assay. Saturation and competition binding assays were performed using tritiated α-factor. In general, cells were grown overnight at 30 °C and harvested at 1 × 107cells/ml by centrifugation at 5000 × g at 4 °C. The pelleted cells were washed two times in ice-cold YM-1 medium (9Abel M.G. Zhang Y.L. Lu H.-F. Naider F. Becker J.M. J. Peptide Res. 1998; 52: 95-106Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar) and resuspended to 4 × 107 cells/ml. The competition binding assay was started by the addition of [3H]α-factor and various concentrations of nonlabeled α-factor analogs (140 μl) to a 560-μl cell suspension such that the final concentration of radioactive peptide was 6 × 10−9m (20 Ci/mmol). Analog concentrations were adjusted using UV absorption at 280 nm and the corresponding extinction coefficients. After a 30-min incubation, triplicate samples of 200 μl were filtered and washed over glass fiber filtermats using the Standard Cell Harvester (Skatron Instruments, Sterling, VA) and placed in scintillation vials for counting. NaCl (1 m) was added to all the solutions and media to test the effect of high salt on the binding affinity of α-factor analogs. In saturation binding assays, various concentrations of radioactive α-factor were added to cell suspension. Specific binding was determined by subtracting counts associated with the LM102 (ste2 deletion) strain from counts bound to the strains harboring wild-type or mutant receptors. Each experiment was carried out at least three times with similar results. Nonspecific binding of labeled α-factor to filters in the absence of cells was less than 20 cpm. Data curves were fitted from at least eight triplicate data points with GraphPad Prism software (nonlinear regression, one site competition or saturation). TheKi values were calculated by using the equation of Cheng and Prusoff (28Cheng Y. Prusoff W.H. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1973; 22: 3099-3108Crossref PubMed Scopus (12256) Google Scholar), where Ki = EC50/(1 + [ligand]/Kd). The goal of this study was to determine whether the side chain of the 10th residue of α-factor (Gln) binds to Ste2p via interactions with residues 47 and 48 of this GPCR. The approach used was to carry out parallel modifications by site-directed mutagenesis of Ser47 and Thr48 in the receptor and synthetic modification of Gln10 of the α-factor tridecapeptide. The sequences of the targeted region of the receptor and synthetic α-factor analogs are represented in Fig.1. Analogs of α-factor containing polar (Asn and Ser), cationic (Lys and Orn), and anionic (Asp and Glu) replacements of Gln10 were assembled using solid-phase procedures on a Wang resin. All peptides were purified by HPLC and were >99% homogeneous in two HPLC systems. The synthetic peptides had the expected amino acid ratios, the calculated mass within ±1 Da, and intact Trp residues as confirmed by ultraviolet spectroscopy (Table I). Using site-directed mutagenesis (see “Experimental Procedures”) Ste2p mutant receptors containing either S47K (this mutant receptor is designated KT to denote the amino acids in the 47th and 48th positions), T48K receptor (designated SK), S47K,T48K receptor (designated KK), or S47E,T48E receptor (designated EE) in place of Ser47,Thr48 of the wild-type receptor were generated. All mutations were confirmed by sequencing, and no other substitutions in the receptor were uncovered. The [3H]α-factor binding properties of the wild-type and mutant receptors were analyzed by a saturation binding assay using whole cells. The Kd value for the EE receptor (6.5 ± 1.4) was equivalent to that of the wild-type receptor (Table II and Fig. 2). The affinity of [3H]α-factor was decreased ∼5-fold in the KK receptor and decreased about 3- and 2-fold in the KT and SK receptors, respectively. As judged by the Bmax values, all receptors were expressed at the cell surface in approximately equivalent numbers. These results suggest that mutation in this region of the receptor does not drastically alter the binding of α-factor to the receptors or the facility of the receptor to reach the membrane and assume a structure competent for ligand recognition.Table IIBinding parameters for wild-type and mutant α-factor receptors with [3H]α-factorReceptorKdBmaxnmBinding sites/cellWT(ST)6.8 ± 1.544,408 ± 3,360KK37.0 ± 4.237,503 ± 1,464EE6.5 ± 1.436,404 ± 2,564KT20.5 ± 3.350,825 ± 2,873SK15.7 ± 2.746,384 ± 2,013Saturation binding curves were determined using whole cells carrying wild-type or mutant receptors (Fig. 2). Kd andBmax values, calculated using a one-site model, are presented as the means ± S.E. of at least three experiments. Each determination was performed in triplicate. Kd andBmax values, calculated using a one-site model, are presented as the means ± S.E. of at least three experiments. Each determination was performed in triplicate. The induction of growth arrest of S. cerevisiae LM102 by α-factor was measured using a halo assay on agar plates. The data were analyzed using linear regression analysis, and the relative amount of α-factor needed to cause a 10-mm halo was determined. This assay indicated that, compared with wild-type Ste2p, the EE mutant receptor was ∼30% more sensitive to α-factor (TableIII). The KK receptor was significantly less sensitive requiring more than twice as much pheromone to induce a 10-mm halo. Compared with wild-type Ste2p the KT and the SK receptors were only slightly reduced in sensitivity to pheromone. In a solution assay that measured gene induction by the signaling cascade, the concentration of α-factor required to cause 50% induction of theFUS-lacZ gene was nearly equal for the wild-type and EE receptor and was 4-, 2-, and 2-fold higher for the KK, KT and SK receptors, respectively (Table IV and Fig. 3). The KK, KT, SK, and EE receptors all triggered a maximum gene induction approximately equal to that of wild-type Ste2p. The Cbl proto-oncogene product is tyrosine phosphorylated in response to a wide variety of stimuli. Cbl and the Abl nonreceptor tyrosine kinase both bind to SH3 domains from the SH2/SH3 adaptor Nck, and are candidate effectors for Nck function. Numerous additional SH2- and SH3-domain-mediated interactions are also possible between Cbl, Abl, and Nck. We find that these three signaling proteins associate when overexpressed in mammalian cells and can regulate each other's activity. Co-expression of wt Cbl together with c-Abl, the activity of which is normally repressed in vivo, led to extensive Abl-dependent phosphorylation of Cbl. The major proline-rich region of Cbl was required for its phosphorylation by c-Abl, but not by a constitutively activated Abl mutant, suggesting Cbl activates c-Abl by engaging its SH3 domain. Efficient phosphorylation of Cbl and its stable association with Abl required the SH2 domain of Abl, suggesting that SH2-phosphotyrosine interactions prevent dissociation of active Abl from Cbl. We also show that overexpression of Nck could repress the phosphorylation of Cbl by Abl in vivo. Studies with Nck mutants suggested that the Nck SH2 domain is responsible for inhibiting the activity of Abl toward both Cbl and Nck itself, most likely by competing with the Abl SH2 for tyrosine-phosphorylated binding sites.

To gain better understanding of the molecular alterations responsible for the aggressive growth potential of epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR)-positive breast cancers, we utilized an expression cloning strategy to seek gene products that mediate the EGF-independent growth of human breast cancer cells. A retroviral cDNA expression library was constructed from the EGFR-positive SUM-149PT cell line, and transduced into growth factor-dependent human mammary epithelial (HME) cells. Recipient cells were functionally selected for their ability to proliferate in serum-free, EGF-free medium. Library cDNAs were recovered from EGF-independent colonies by PCR amplification or by biological rescue. Clone H55a#1 contained a library insert encoding amphiregulin. This EGFR ligand was able to confer EGF independence when transduced into HME cells. SUM-149PT and H55a#1 cells overexpressed amphiregulin transcripts, and secreted moderate EGF-like activity in conditioned media, indicating a possible autocrine loop. EGFR membrane levels and constitutive phosphorylation were consistent with this hypothesis, as well as the sensitivity of the cells to an ErbB-specific kinase inhibitor. Expression of the WT1 Wilms' tumor suppressor gene, a transcriptional activator of amphiregulin, did not parallel amphiregulin transcript levels, suggesting that another factor regulates amphiregulin in SUM-149PT. Our data confirm the importance of amphiregulin in the etiology of breast cancer.

The Drosophila segment polarity genefused encodes a putative protein-serine/threonine kinase, and plays a critical role in the signal transduction for Hedgehog (Hh)-dependent gene expression. We show that theDrosophila Schneider 2 (S2) cell line has the potential to transduce the Hh-triggered intracellular signals, leading to the activation of target gene expression, when a transcription factor, Cubitus interruptus (Ci), is provided exogenously. Using S2 cells transfected with the Ci-expressing plasmid and a patchedpromoter reporter construct, we demonstrate that the forced expression of Fused (Fu) stimulates Hh-triggered and Ci-dependent transcriptional activation. The N-terminal kinase domain of Fu is required for this activity, but the C-terminal domain is not. Two kinase-inactive Fu mutants fail to enhance the reporter activation, indicating that the kinase catalytic activity is essential for this function. Negative components of the Hh-signaling pathway, Costal-2 and Suppressor of Fused, strongly antagonize the Fu activity, irrespective of the presence or absence of the Fu C-terminal domain, suggesting an indirect mechanism for the inhibition of Fu by these proteins. Furthermore, mutational analyses of threonine 158 and serine 159, in the activation segment of the Fu protein kinase, indicate that threonine 158 is essential for Fu activity and that phosphorylation of this threonine residue may be involved in the activation of the kinase catalytic activity upon Hh stimulation.

5-HT3 receptors possess a number of highly conserved proline residues. We changed each of these to alanine, expressed the mutants as homomeric 5-HT3Areceptors in HEK293 cells, and analyzed them with radioligand binding, electrophysiology, and immunocytochemistry. Mutation of Pro56, Pro104, Pro123, and Pro170 resulted in ablation of radioligand binding, whereas mutation of Pro257 and Pro301 did not. Only the latter were expressed at the plasma membrane but were non-functional. Thus the former, which are in the N-terminal domain, may be involved in forming correct receptor structure, while those in the transmembrane region (Pro257 and Pro301) are necessary for the function of the protein. To explore the conformational preference (propensity) of these residues we examined the proportion ofcis-prolines and the influence of adjacent residues in known protein structures. 4.7% of prolines in the protein data base were in the cis conformation, and the distribution of amino acids adjacent to cis-prolines was not randomly distributed. Comparison of the proportion of each amino acid residue adjacent to acis-proline revealed that aromatic and bend-facilitating residues were favored while those with β-branched chains were not. Thus five residues (Gly, Pro, Tyr, Trp, Phe) and three residues (Pro, Tyr, Phe) were found more frequently than expected before and aftercis-prolines respectively, whereas five residues (Val, Ile, Leu, Asp, Thr) and two residues (Asp, Glu) were found less frequently. Of the 20 proline residues in the 5-HT3A receptor subunit only Pro170 has adjacent residues that are favorable. Mutating these to non-favorable residues resulted in ablation of ligand binding, whereas replacement with alternative favorable residues did not. We therefore propose that Pro170, which is part of the characteristic cys-loop found in this family of proteins, may be in the cis conformation. 5-HT3 receptors possess a number of highly conserved proline residues. Thus five residues (Gly, Pro, Tyr, Trp, Phe) and three residues (Pro, Tyr, Phe) were found more frequently than expected before and aftercis-prolines respectively, whereas five residues (Val, Ile, Leu, Asp, Thr) and two residues (Asp, Glu) were found less frequently. Mutating these to non-favorable residues resulted in ablation of ligand binding, whereas replacement with alternative favorable residues did not. We therefore propose that Pro170, which is part of the characteristic cys-loop found in this family of proteins, may be in the cis conformation. ligand-gated ion channels nicotinic acetylcholine protein data bank Human embryonic kidney wild type The 5-HT3 receptor is a member of the cys-loop family of ligand-gated ion channels (LGIC),1 which includes nicotinic acetylcholine (nACh), γ-aminobutyric acidA, and glycine receptors. These receptors are pentamers and are usually constituted of 2–4 different subunits each with a large extracellular N-terminal region and four putative transmembrane domains (M1-M4). Two 5-HT3 receptor subunits, 5-HT3A and 5-HT3B, have been identified so far, and receptors can function as either homo-oligomeric 5-HT3Aor hetero-oligomeric 5-HT3A and 5-HT3B subunit complexes (1Maricq A.V. Peterson A.S. Brake A.J. Myers R.M. Julius D. Science. 1991; 254: 432-437Crossref PubMed Scopus (884) Google Scholar, 2Davies P.A. Pistis M. Hanna M.C. Peters J.A. Lambert J.J. Hales T.G. Kirkness E.F. Nature. 1999; 397: 359-363Crossref PubMed Scopus (489) Google Scholar). Evidence from early biochemical and mutagenesis studies on nACh receptors indicated that the extracellular N-terminal domain contains the ligand binding site, and this has been confirmed by the construction of a chimeric protein consisting of the N-terminal domain of the α7 neuronal nACh receptor subunit linked to the C-terminal portion of the 5-HT3A receptor subunit; the resulting chimera possessed nACh receptor pharmacological properties and 5-HT3 receptor channel properties (3Eisele J.-L. Bertrand S. Galzi J.-L. Devillers-Thiery A. Changeux J.-P. Bertrand D. Nature. 1993; 366: 479-483Crossref PubMed Scopus (360) Google Scholar). Recently the high resolution structure of a protein homologous to the extracellular domain of the nACh receptor has been determined (4Brejc K. van Dijk W.J. Klaassen R.V. Schuurmans M. van Der Oost J. Smit A.B. Sixma T.K. Nature. 2001; 411: 269-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (1578) Google Scholar). The transmembrane domain is less well understood but there is good evidence from a variety of studies that the second transmembrane domain, M2, lines the channel. To date, however, details of the complete structure of the receptor are lacking (5Corringer P.J. Le Novere N Changeux J.-P. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2000; 40: 431-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (706) Google Scholar). Examining LGIC receptor subunit sequences shows that there are a number of highly conserved proline residues. Recently the role of the conserved proline in the M1 domain of the 5-HT3A receptor has been examined (6Dang H. England P.M. Farivar S.S. Dougherty D.A. Lester H.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 2000; 57: 1114-1122PubMed Google Scholar) and was shown to be critical for the function of the protein; replacing it by any other amino acid resulted in a non-functional receptor. However, replacing it by a series of unnatural amino acids that possessed the restricted H bonding capabilities of proline restored function, indicating that it is this property that is critical. Currently however, the structural contribution and functional significance of the other conserved proline residues remain unknown. To examine their role we have changed each of the six conserved proline residues in the 5-HT3A receptor subunit (Fig.1) individually to alanine. The resulting mutants have been expressed in HEK293 cells and characterized with radioligand binding, electrophysiology, and immunocytochemistry. The data suggest that all of the conserved proline residues play an important role in the structure and/or function of the receptor. Proline is also interesting because this residue exists in proteins in the cis conformation, as compared with the more usual trans conformation, at much higher proportions than is found for other amino acids; this can significantly affect the structure of the protein. Cis peptides do occur for other amino acids (7Jabs A. Weiss M.S. Hilgenfeld R. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 286: 291-304Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar) but are rare. The cis form of proline probably has a very specific structural role in proteins:cis-proline is the second most conserved residue type, the first being half-cystine (8Sali A. Overington J.P. Protein Sci. 1994; 3: 1582-1596Crossref PubMed Scopus (261) Google Scholar). It is not known which, if any, of the prolines in the LGIC family are in the cis conformation, but it does seem likely that both forms are present in the mature protein; a recent study shows that a peptidylprolyl isomerase is involved in posttranslational folding and/or assembly in 5-HT3 and α7 nACh receptors (9Helekar S.A. Char D. Neff S. Patrick J. Neuron. 1994; 12: 179-189Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar). Peptidylprolyl isomerases catalyze the rotation of the prolyl peptide bond between the cis and trans conformations, an isomerization that is known to be rate-limiting in the folding of a number of proteins. Previous studies (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar, 11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar, 12Stewart D.E. Sarkar A. Wampler J.E. J. Mol. Biol. 1990; 214: 253-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (468) Google Scholar) have indicated that certain amino acid residues may be more favorable than others in stabilizing a cis-proline. We therefore decided to examine the proportion of residues adjacent tocis-prolines identified from the current protein data bank (PDB) (13Berman H.M. Westbrook J. Feng Z. Gilliland G. Bhat T.N. Weissig H. Shindyalov I.N. Bourne P.E. Nucleic Acids Res. 2000; 28: 235-242Crossref PubMed Scopus (27327) Google Scholar) to gauge the possibility that one or more of the conserved proline residues in the 5-HT3A receptor subunit may exist in the cis configuration. These data, combined with mutagenesis studies to convert the adjacent residues to favorable or non-favorable alternatives, suggest that Pro170 may be in the cis conformation. Human embryonic kidney (HEK) 293 cells were cultured on 90-mm tissue culture plates in Dulbecco's modified Eagles medium/F12 (1:1) medium (Life Technologies, Inc.) supplemented with 10% fetal calf serum (Sigma) at 37 °C and 7% CO2 in a humidified atmosphere. Mutant 5-HT3A receptor subunits were developed using the eukaryotic expression vector pRc/CMV (Invitrogen, Abingdon, U.K.) containing the complete coding sequence for the 5-HT3A(b)subunit from NIE-115 cells as previously described (14Hargreaves A.C Taylor C.W. Lummis S.C.R. Mol. Pharmacol. 1994; 46: 1120-1128PubMed Google Scholar). Mutagenesis reactions were performed using the Kunkel method (15Kunkel T.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1985; 82: 488-492Crossref PubMed Scopus (4897) Google Scholar) and confirmed by DNA sequencing. For transfections HEK cells at 60–70% confluency (∼48 h postpassage) were transfected with wild type (WT) or mutant plasmid DNA by the calcium phosphate precipitation method (16Chen C.A. Okayama H. BioTechniques. 1988; 6: 632-637Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). For radioligand binding studies cells were grown on 90 mm plates (Falcon) and harvested 3 days after transfection. For electrophysiology experiments cells were grown on 35-mm plates and recordings performed 1–4 days posttransfection. In immunofluorescence experiments cells were grown on 22-mm diameter glass coverslips in 35-mm plates and stained 3 days posttransfection. Transfected HEK293 cells were washed twice with phosphate-buffered saline at room temperature; all subsequent steps were carried out at 1–4 °C. Cells were scraped into 1 ml of HEPES buffer (10 mm, pH 7.4) containing the following proteinase inhibitors: 1 mm EDTA, 50 μg/ml soybean trypsin inhibitor, 50 μg/ml bacitracin and 0.1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride. Harvested cells were washed in HEPES/proteinase inhibitors and frozen at −20 °C. After thawing, they were washed twice with HEPES buffer and resuspended, and 50 μg of cell membranes were incubated in 0.5 ml of HEPES buffer containing 1 nm [3H]granisetron (81 Ci/mmol, DuPont) for single point binding or concentrations ranging from 0.05 nm to 2 nm for saturation studies; 1 μmd-tubocurarine was used to determine nonspecific binding. Reactions were incubated for 1 h at 4 °C and were terminated by rapid vacuum filtration using a Brandel cell harvester onto GF/B filters presoaked for 3 h in 0.3% polyethylenimine followed by two rapid washes with 4 ml of ice-cold HEPES buffer. Radioactivity was determined by scintillation counting (Beckman LS6000sc). Protein concentration was estimated using the Bio-Rad Protein Assay with bovine serum albumin standards. Data were analyzed by iterative curve fitting (GraphPad, PRISM, San Diego, CA) according to the equation: B = (Bmax[L]n)/([L]n+ Kn), where B is bound radioligand,Bmax is maximum binding at equilibrium,K is the equilibrium dissociation constant, [L] is the free concentration of radioligand and n is the Hill coefficient. Transfected cells were washed with three changes of Tris-buffered saline (TBS: 0.1 m Tris/HCl, pH7.4, 0.9% NaCl) and fixed using ice-cold 4% paraformaldehyde in phosphate buffer (PB: 66 mm Na2HPO4, 38 mm NaH2PO4, pH 7.2). To label the N-terminal domain pAb120 antiserum (17Spier A.D. Wotherspoon G. Nayak S.V. Nichols R.A. Priestley J.V. Lummis S.C.R. Mol. Brain Res. 1999; 67: 221-230Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar) was used at 1:1000 dilution in TBS. Intracellular receptor expression was determined by inclusion of 0.3% Triton X-100 for membrane permeabilization. Primary antibody incubation was overnight at 4 °C. In some studies a commercially available antiserum, serotonin 5-HT3 receptor Ab1 (Oncogene Research Products) raised against the M3-M4 loop was also used. Biotinylated anti-rabbit IgG (Vector) and fluorescein isothiocyanate avidin D (Vector) were used to detect bound antibody as per the manufacturer's instructions. Coverslips were mounted in vectashield mounting medium (Vector) and immunofluorescence was observed using a Nikon optiphot microscope. All cell culture reagents were obtained from Life Technologies, Inc. except fetal calf serum, which was from Sigma. [3H]Granisetron (81 Ci/mmol) was from DuPont (Stevenage). All other reagents were of the highest obtainable grade. This was performed largely as previously described (18Deane C.M. Allen F.H. Taylor R. Blundell T.L. Protein Eng. 1999; 12: 1025-1028Crossref PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Briefly, a set of 1010 PDB chains with a resolution better than 2.5 Å (no NMR structures were included) and pair-wise identity less than 20% were extracted from the PDB. The ω, φ and ψ dihedral angles of all the residues in this set were calculated. Cis peptide bonds were identified as those where the ω dihedral fell between −20 and 20°. The number and type of amino acid following cis and trans residues were compared. Ramachandran propensity plots were generated for the cis residues themselves and their preceding and following residues. This process was repeated for the trans residues. Significance values for the fractional occurrence of residues before and after cis-prolines were calculated using χ2; P values of < 0.05 were taken to be statistically significant. Single point binding assays were carried out for each mutant transiently expressed in HEK293 cells but showed no specific binding. Simultaneous transfection of the WT 5-HT3A receptor subunit resulted in high levels of specific ligand binding. To determine whether the mutants were correctly oligomerized and expressed at the plasma membrane, their localization was studied using an antiserum specific for the N terminus of the 5-HT3A receptor subunit, pAb120. No labeling was observed in cells transfected with the Pro56 → Ala-containing mutant, whereas in cells transfected with mutants containing Pro104 → Ala, Pro123 → Ala, and Pro170 → Ala, labeling was observed only in permeabilized preparations (Fig. 2). Pro56is close to the region where the antisera was raised, which suggests that rather than not being expressed the mutant protein may have a local change in conformation that prevents antisera recognition. Examination of the Pro56 → Ala-containing mutant using a commercially available M3-M4 loop antiserum also resulted in no labeling; however, neither was labeling observed for WT receptors, suggesting that this antiserum was not suitable for immunofluorescence experiments. Specific binding of [3H]granisetron revealed Kd values of 0.27 ± 0.05 nm and 0.20 ± 0.07 nm(mean ± S.E., n = 3) for cells transfected with Pro257 → Ala- and Pro301 → Ala-containing mutants, respectively; these values are similar to those obtained from WT (Kd = 0.23 ± 0.04 nm,n = 4). Examination of the mutant receptor localization using pAb120 showed that they were both expressed on the cell surface (Fig. 2). However, the mutant receptors appeared to be non-functional; neither of them, when expressed in HEK293 cells and analyzed using whole cell patch clamp (as described in Ref. 19Sepulveda M.-I. Lummis S.C.R. Martin I.L. Br. J. Pharmacol. 1991; 104: 536-540Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar), showed any response to 5-HT (≤1 mm). 550 cis peptide bonds were identified in the PBD using the conditions specified above, which was 0.033% of all residues examined. However, when considering only proline residues, the data revealed that 4.7% of proline residues were cis. The Ramachandran plots in Fig.3 show that the φψ dihedrals of the 486 residues prior to a cis-proline reside in the β region. Similarly the residues prior to the non-proline cis amino acids were also found in this region of the plot. The fractional occurrence of each residue before a cis-proline as compared with before a trans-proline is shown in Fig.4 using 9650 trans-proline residues. The data demonstrate that there are five residues (Gly, Pro, Tyr, Trp, and Phe) found more frequently than expected before acis-proline, with five residues being found less frequently (Val, Leu, Ile, Asp, and Thr). A similar plot for those residues located immediately following a cis-proline shows that there are only three residues whose occurrence is greater than expected (Pro, Tyr, and Phe) and two residues (Asp and Glu) whose occurrence is less.
