Residues were identified from the PDB as described in the text.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Pro170 was identified as being surrounded by residues that we observed to exist more frequently than expected adjacent to cis-prolines, and we therefore considered these as ‘favorable' residues. To further explore if these adjacent residues (Phe169 and Phe171) affected the expression of the receptor, we changed them to alternative favorable (Gly or Pro, respectively) or non-favorable (Ile or Asp, respectively) residues and transfected the resultant mutant receptor subunit DNA into HEK293 cells. Radioligand binding revealed that replacing the adjacent Phe with Gly (Phe169) or Pro (Phe171) resulted in radioligand binding, while changing them to Ile or Asp, respectively ablated such binding (Fig.6). Gly and Ile were chosen as suitable examples of residues found more or less frequently, respectively, before cis-prolines as they are significantly different in that they lack the aromatic ring of Phe, yet are residues that would not be expected to significantly change the characteristics of the protein. Unfortunately such residues were not available to substitute for Phe171. To identify the functional roles of conserved proline residues in the cys-loop family of ligand-gated ion channels, we substituted these residues in the 5-HT3A receptor subunit with alanine (Fig.1). The pharmacology, electrophysiology, and localization of the altered receptors were examined using the HEK293 cell expression system. The data we have presented suggests that the four proline residues in the N-terminal domain are critical for the correct receptor assembly and/or the structure of the ligand binding site, while those located in the transmembrane region are necessary for the correct function of the receptor. We also examined the propensity of the prolines to exist in the cis or trans conformation and these data suggest cis-prolines have a significantly higher probability of being preceded by glycine, proline, or an aromatic amino acid and be followed by proline, tyrosine, or phenylalanine. Changing the phenylalanine residues that are adjacent to Pro170 provided data that support our hypothesis that this proline may be in the cis conformation. The presence of four conserved proline residues in the N-terminal, ligand binding domain of LGICs (Fig. 7) suggests that even though different neurotransmitters activate the different proteins, the basic structure is similar, and our data confirm that all of these proline residues play an important role in the structure and/or assembly of the 5-HT3 receptor. Several of the residues that surround these conserved prolines are themselves conserved, especially those surrounding the proline located in the disulfide loop region (Pro170), which is characteristic of this protein family; indeed the name cys-loop is frequently used to distinguish it from other LGIC families. The least conserved proline is Pro104, which is not found in the 5-HT3Bsubunit. This residue is also not conserved in some non-agonist binding subunits in other members of the family, e.g. the nACh γ and δ subunits and the glycine receptor B subunit (20North R.A. Handbook of Receptors and Channels: Ligand- and Voltage-Gated Ion Channels. CRC Press, Boca Raton1995Google Scholar), suggesting it may be of particular importance in the neurotransmitter-binding subunit. The immunological studies show that the Pro104 → Ala, Pro123 → Ala, and Pro170→ Ala mutants are expressed but no receptors reach the plasma membrane, suggesting that the subunits either cannot form their correct structures, cannot assemble successfully, or cannot reach the membrane. The fact that the mutant proteins are recognized by the antisera favors one of the latter two hypotheses, and indeed these are supported by previous studies on the nACh receptor where the proline in the cys-loop (equivalent to Pro170) was changed to glycine (21Fu D.-X. Sine S.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 31479-31484Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The resulting mutant receptors could either not assemble properly (if the mutation was in the β or γ subunits) or could not reach the membrane (if the mutation was in the α or δ subunits). The data we extracted from the PDB show that 4.7% of prolines are in the cis conformation. This value is similar to previously reported values of 5.7% (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar) and 5.2% (11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). Thus, given that there are 20 prolines in the 5-HT3Areceptor subunit, the probability is that ≤ 1 are in the cis conformation. The factors that determine whether a proline is in the cis or trans conformation are not yet fully understood but include both the three-dimensional fold of the protein (it has been shown that a residue can be forced into the cis conformation when acis-proline is replaced by another amino acid) and the characteristics of the neighboring amino acid residues (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar, 11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar, 22Odefey C. Mayr L.M. Schmid F.X. J. Mol. Biol. 1995; 245: 69-78Crossref PubMed Scopus (89) Google Scholar). Our data reveal that aromatic residues are favored to precedecis-prolines, which is not observed for cis bonds in general (Fig. 4), but has been reported in previous work and may be because thecis-proline is stabilized by a C–H to π interaction (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar, 11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar, 23Reimer U. Scherer G. Drewello M. Kruber S. Schutkowski M. Fischer G. J. Mol. Biol. 1998; 279: 449-460Crossref PubMed Scopus (304) Google Scholar, 24Brandts J.F. Halvorson H.R. Brennan M. Biochemistry. 1975; 14: 4953-4963Crossref PubMed Scopus (1044) Google Scholar). Glycine and proline were also found to precede cis-prolines in higher proportions than expected. Ascis-proline always causes a turn, an adjacent bend-facilitating residue is likely to be favored. The high occurrence of these residues preceding cis prolines has also been previously observed (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar, 11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). Conversely our PDB analysis showed that residues with β-branched chains (Val, Thr and Ile) are not favored before cis-prolines, as previously reported, and that may be because the steric bulk of the side chain hinders trans/cis isomerization (11Pal D. Chakrabarti P. J. Mol. Biol. 1999; 294: 271-288Crossref PubMed Scopus (269) Google Scholar). There have been fewer studies on the roles of amino acid residues immediately following cis-prolines and indeed both our and previous data suggests that these residues play a less important role than those that precede cis-prolines. Our data showed that two aromatic residues were favored, which may help stabilize thecis-proline as discussed above. Proline was also favored, presumably because it facilitates a bend as described above. Considering the results from our data and the number of prolines in the 5-HT3A receptor subunit, this protein is unlikely to contain more than one cis-proline, and interestingly only one of the proline residues is adjoined by favorable amino acids; Pro170 is surrounded by phenylalanines. Changing these adjoining residues to non-favorable residues results in ablation of radioligand binding, indicating that the receptors are not correctly formed and/or assembled, whereas changing them to alternative favorable residues does not. While this does not prove our hypothesis that Pro170 is in the cis conformation, it does provide some experimental support. Better evidence comes from examining the residues adjacent to the equivalent proline in other LGIC subunits, and indeed this proline is preceded by an aromatic residue for all known subunits of this family (Ref. 20North R.A. Handbook of Receptors and Channels: Ligand- and Voltage-Gated Ion Channels. CRC Press, Boca Raton1995Google Scholar, Fig. 7). Many of the residues following the proline are also aromatic, e.g. in the nACh receptor subunits the following residue is either Phe or Tyr. There are also good structural reasons for the proline located here to be cis: Pro170 is located in the center of the cys-loop, a 13-amino acid region held together by disulfide-bonded cysteines, which is characteristic of this family of proteins. As this 13-amino acid peptide must form a turn, this could be facilitated by acis-proline. The fact that glycine, which is a common amino acid in other turns, cannot substitute for proline in the nACh receptor (10MacArthur M.W. Thornton J.M. J. Mol. Biol. 1991; 218: 397-412Crossref PubMed Scopus (988) Google Scholar) suggests this is a turn that perhaps can be formed only by acis-proline. The recently reported structure of the acetylcholine receptor-binding protein (AChBP), a protein highly homologous to the ligand binding domain of the nACh receptor, unfortunately is not conserved in this region (4Brejc K. van Dijk W.J. Klaassen R.V. Schuurmans M. van Der Oost J. Smit A.B. Sixma T.K. Nature. 2001; 411: 269-276Crossref PubMed Scopus (1578) Google Scholar). Proline has been identified as an amino acid that allows the correct functioning of a number of transmembrane proteins involved in signaling, and there is increasing evidence that LGICs fall into this category (25Sansom M.S.P. Weinstein H. Trends Phamacol. Sci. 2000; 21: 445-451Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (265) Google Scholar). Apart from M2, however, which has been shown in a variety of studies to be predominantly α-helical, the secondary or tertiary structures of the transmembrane regions have not yet been determined (5Corringer P.J. Le Novere N Changeux J.-P. Annu. Rev. Pharmacol. Toxicol. 2000; 40: 431-458Crossref PubMed Scopus (706) Google Scholar). Thus whether the conserved proline in M1, Pro257, is in the membrane or at an intracellular or extracellular location is not yet known. The critical role of this amino acid in the 5-HT3 receptor has been recently demonstrated in the study by Dang et al. (6Dang H. England P.M. Farivar S.S. Dougherty D.A. Lester H.A. Mol. Pharmacol. 2000; 57: 1114-1122PubMed Google Scholar), where its substitution by a variety of other residues resulted in expressed but non-functional receptors, similar to our findings with the Pro357 → Ala mutant. These authors also replaced this proline with unnatural amino acids with the same limited H bonding capacity of proline, which yielded mutant receptors that did function. In addition they demonstrated that in combination with a second mutation, Val13 → Ser, the M1 Pro to Gly substitution resulted in constitutively open channels, supporting the proposal that the M1 proline plays a critical role in allowing the conformational changes necessary for channel gating. The M2-M3 domain, which is thought to be an extracellular loop between transmembrane domains 2 and 3, has also been shown in experiments on nACh (26Grosman C. Salamone F.N. Sine S.M. Auerbach A. J. Gen. Physiol. 2000; 116: 327-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar, 27Rovira J.C. Ballesta J.J. Vicente-Agullo F. Campos-Caro A. Criado M. Sala F. Sala S. FEBS Lett. 1998; 433: 89-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar, 28Rovira J.C. Vicente-Agullo F. Campos-Caro A. Criado M. Sala F. Sala S. Ballesta J.J. Pflügers Arch. 1999; 439: 86-92Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar), glycine, (29Lynch J.W. Rajendra S. Pierce K.D. Handford C.A. Barry P.H. Schofield P.R. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 110-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar) and γ-aminobutyric acidA(30Kusama T. Wang J.-B. Spivak C.E. Uhl G.R. Neuroreport. 1994; 5: 1209-1212Crossref PubMed Scopus (35) Google Scholar) receptors to play a role in channel gating. Indeed some authors, e.g. Lynch et al. (29Lynch J.W. Rajendra S. Pierce K.D. Handford C.A. Barry P.H. Schofield P.R. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 110-120Crossref PubMed Scopus (189) Google Scholar), believe that the M2-M3 loop forms the crucial link between agonist binding and channel opening. This region appears to be flexible, and recent experiments on muscle nACh receptors suggest that movement of this loop in response to agonist binding initially occurs in α subunits and subsequently in others (26Grosman C. Salamone F.N. Sine S.M. Auerbach A. J. Gen. Physiol. 2000; 116: 327-339Crossref PubMed Scopus (102) Google Scholar). Thus Pro301 may be a critical component that allows agonist-stimulated movement of this loop resulting in channel opening, and its replacement even by alanine may prevent the flexibility of this region that is critical for its function. Combining the findings from mutations and the PDB analysis we can conclude that all of the proline residues in the 5-HT3A receptor subunits examined in this study play a important role in the correct structure and/or function of the receptor and postulate that one of these, Pro170, is in the cis conformation. The high level of conservation of these prolines with other members of the cys-loop family demonstrates that tertiary folding of the receptors is highly conserved, thus further exemplifying the high degree of structural and functional homology between the receptors in the cys-loop LGIC family.

Adhesion to the extracellular matrix is required for the expression and activation of the cyclin-cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) complexes, and for G1 phase progression of non-transformed cells. However, in non-adherent cells no molecular mechanism has yet been proposed for the cell adhesion-dependent up-regulation of the p27 cyclin-dependent kinase inhibitor (CKI), and the associated inhibition of cyclin E-CDK2. We now show that in epithelial cells the expression of c-Myc is tightly regulated by cell-substrate adhesion. When deprived of adhesion, two independently derived mammary epithelial cell lines, 184A1N4 and MCF-10A, rapidly decrease their level of c-Myc mRNA and protein. This decrease in levels of c-Myc correlates with G1 phase arrest, as indicated by hypophosphorylation of pRb and inhibition of the activity of the cyclin E-CDK2 complex. In 184A1N4 cells, cell-substrate adhesion is required for the suppression of p27, and induction of cyclin E, E2F-1, but not cyclins D1 and D3. Enforced expression of c-Myc in non-adherent 184A1N4 and MCF-10A cells reverses the adhesion-dependent inhibition of cell cycle progression. Restoration of c-Myc in non-adherent cells induces the expression of E2F-1, and hyperphosphorylation of pRb in response to EGF treatment. In addition, expression of c-Myc results in the anchorage-independent activation of the CDK2 complex, the associated upregulation of cyclin E, and the destabilization and degradation of p27 by the ubiquitin-proteasome pathway. Our study thus suggests that c-Myc is the link between cell adhesion and the regulation of p27 and cyclin E-CDK2. Furthermore, we describe a role for c-Myc in adhesion-mediated regulation of E2F-1.

The phosphatase Cdc25A was shown to be a target of the transcription factor c-Myc. Myc-induced apoptosis appeared dependent on Cdc25A expression and Cdc25A over-expression could substitute for Myc-triggered apoptosis. These findings suggested that an important downstream component of Myc-mediated apoptosis was identified. However and in contrast, we recently reported that during TNFalpha-induced apoptosis, which required c-Myc function, Cdc25A was down-regulated in a human carcinoma cell line. We now provide evidence that Cdc25A rendered the non-transformed rat embryonic cell line 423 refractory to apoptosis, which was induced by serum deprivation and in absence of detectable c-myc levels. The survival promoting activity of cdc25A was abolished upon infection of cells with a full-length cdc25A antisense construct. To identify the signaling proteins mediating the survival function of the phosphatase, cdc25A- and akt- over-expressing pooled clones were exposed to selected chemicals, which inhibit or activate key proteins in signaling pathways. Inhibition of apoptosis by SU4984, NF023 and Rapamycin placed Cdc25A and Akt function downstream of FGF.R, PDGF.R, and compensated G-protein- and PP2A- activity. Interestingly, upon treatment with LY-294002, cdc25A- and akt- over-expressing clones exhibited similar apoptotic patterns as control cells, which indicates that neither Akt- nor Cdc25A-mediated survival functions are dependent on PI.3 kinase activity in rat 423 cells. In cdc25A-overexpressing cells increased levels of serine 473 phosphorylated Akt were found, which co-precipitated with Cdc25A and Raf1. Since activation of proteins requires dephosphorylation of particular residues in addition to site-specific phosphorylation, the anti-apoptotic effect of Cdc25A might derive from its participation in a multimeric protein complex with phosphoAkt and Raf1, two prominent components of survival pathways.

Insect cytokine, growth-blocking peptide (GBP), enhances cell proliferation of human keratinocyte cells with a potency almost equivalent to that of human epidermal growth factor (EGF). GBP consists of 25 amino acid residues containing a core region that shows a striking similarity to the C-terminal β-loop domain of EGF and disordered N and C termini. The present study demonstrates that, although GBP lacks the N-terminal half-portion of EGF molecule, at least five amino acids of the disordered N-terminal six-amino acid region are indispensable for affecting the cell growth activity of GBP. Upon stimulating mitogenesis in keratinocyte cells, GBP directly binds and activates their EGF receptors. GBP also effects proliferative activity on insect Sf9 cells through the binding and activation of the specific receptor, which consists of a heterodimeric complex: a binding subunit (60 kDa) and a tyrosine phosphorylation subunit (58 kDa). These results indicate that GBP enhances cell proliferation of human keratinocyte and insect Sf9 cells through the activation of EGF and GBP receptors, respectively. This developmental disturbance allows the wasps to complete their larval growth and to emerge while the host is still in the larval stage, otherwise the wasp larvae would be trapped inside the sclerotized pupal cuticles (1Hayakawa Y. J. Insect Physiol. 1995; 41: 1-6Crossref Scopus (75) Google Scholar). Growth-blocking peptide (GBP)1 was originally identified in the larval hemolymph of the armyworm, Pseudaletia separata, whose development is halted in the last larval stage from parasitization by the parasitic wasp, Cotesia kariyai(2Hayakawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 10813-10816Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 3Hayakawa Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 7982-7984Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). We have since determined that GBP is a host gene product, and that titers of this peptide are increased by external stresses such as parasitization and chilling (4Hayakawa Y. Noguchi H. Eur. J. Biochem. 1998; 253: 810-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (32) Google Scholar, 5Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Yamanaka A. Izumi S. Tomino S. Biol. 1995; 25: 1121-1127Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Larval weight gain is reduced and metamorphosis is also delayed when larvae were injected with high concentrations of GBP relative to sham-injected larvae. Low concentrations of GBP stimulate larval growth. Thus, it is clear that GBP titers are closely related to larval growth rates of insects (7Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 250: 194-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Recently we found that GBP can act as a cell growth factor controlling the proliferation of a number of cell types. Bioassay data showed that several nm GBP stimulate DNA synthesis in insect Sf9 cells and human keratinocyte cells, while several μm GBP do not stimulate cell proliferation at all (7Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 250: 194-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). Since GBP homologs have been found in other Lepidoptera as a multifunctional peptide, they are now thought to be categorized as an insect cytokine family (7Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 250: 194-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar, 8Skinner W.S. Dennis P.A. Li J.P. Summerfelt R.M. Carney R.L. Quistad G.B. J. Biol. Peptide R. 1999; 54: 256-261Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). EGF is a single-chain polypeptide of 53 amino acid residues with three disulfide bonds that define three looped regions from residues 1–20, 14–31, and 32–53 (16Savage C.R. Inagami T. Cohen S. J. Biol. Chem. 1972; 247: 7612-7621Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The mutagenesis data collected thus far have revealed that EGF interactions with its receptor (EGFR) require the involvement of regions in both the N- and C-terminal domains of EGF (17Heath W.F. Merrifield R.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1986; 83: 6367-6371Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Even though GBP adopts an EGF-like fold similar to that found in the C-terminal subdomain of EGF, GBP totally lacks the N-terminal homologous domains of EGF molecule since it consists of a mere 25 amino acids. However, the cell growth assay using human keratinocytes showed that GBP has a mitogenic activity comparable with that of EGF. Further, GBP showed a more potent mitogenic activity against insect Sf9 cells than that found for EGF (7Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1998; 250: 194-199Crossref PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar). The purpose of this work was to identify the GBP receptors in both cell types. The results reveal that GBP directly binds the EGFR in human keratinocytes while it binds a completely different type of the receptor with a molecular mass of ∼60 kDa in insect Sf9 cells. GBP and [biotin-Lys26]GBP were synthesized by the solid phase method (18Merrifield R.B. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 1963; 85: 2149-2154Crossref Scopus (6699) Google Scholar) usingtert-butyloxycarbony amino acids with an Applied Biosystem Model 430A peptide synthesizer. Deletion of GBP from the N terminus was performed by incubating synthetic GBP in 50 mmTris-HCl buffer (pH 8.0) containing 5 units of aminopeptidase I (Takara) at 90 °C for 45 min. The deleted products were separated by a reversed phase C8 column (YMC, 4.6 × 250 mm, pore size: 300 Å). Human EGF was purchased from Seikagaku (Japan). [3H]thymidine, 125I-EGF and Na125I were obtained from PerkinElmer Life Sciences. Monoclonal anti-EGFR and anti-phosphotyrosine (PY-20) were purchased from Santa Cruz Biotechnology. All other chemicals were reagent grade. Synthesized GBP was radioiodinated using the chloramine-T method (19Hunter M.W. Greenwood F.C. Nature. 1962; 194: 495-496Crossref PubMed Scopus (5860) Google Scholar) to a specific activity of 100,000–150,000 cpm/ng protein. Human foreskin keratinocytes were purchased from Morinaga and maintained in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM) containing 0.8% bovine pituitary extract (Morinaga) and 0.8 pmol/ml EGF (complete medium A) at 37 °C in 5% CO2. DNA synthesis was assayed as follows. After cultivating the cells in DMEM without any growth factor for 2 days, either GBP or EGF was added to the medium along with 1 μCi of [3H]thymidine. After incubation for 2 days, cells were washed three times with 0.15 m NaCl, lysed with 200 μl of 0.3 n NaOH, and then counted using a liquid scintillation counter (Aloka, LSC-5100) (20Shing Y. Davidson S. Klagsbrun M. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 146: 42-48Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Insect Sf9 cells were purchased from Invitrogen and maintained in TNM-FH medium (Grace's insect medium, pH 6.1, containing 0.33% lactoalbumine hydrolysate and 0.33% yeastolate) with 10% fetal bovine serum (Filtron Pty. Ltd.) at 25 °C. After cultivating the cells in TNM-FH without the serum for 2 days, either EGF or GBP was added to the medium along with [3H]thymidine. Thymidine incorporation was measured by the same procedures as described above. Competitive binding assays with125I-labeled human EGF and GBP were performed using either human foreskin keratinocyte or insect Sf9 cells essentially according to the procedure of Sarah et al. (21Sarah M.P. Lynn W. Stephan G.C. Donna E.D. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 30392-30397Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). The cells were diluted to 5 × 104 cells/ml and 500 μl of the suspension was put into each well of 24-well plates. The plate was incubated at 37 °C under 5% CO2 for 18 h. The adherent cells were then washed twice with 500 μl of PBS (8 mm Na2HPO4, 1.5 mmKH2PO4, 137 mm NaCl, and 2.7 mm KCl, pH 7.2) and preincubated with 500 μl of PBS containing 1% (w/v) BSA at 22 °C. After the preincubation for 30 min, the supernatant was replaced with 250 μl of PBS containing 1% (w/v) BSA and 0.02% (w/v) NaN3 (to inhibit EGF receptor internalization) and various concentrations of growth factors. Two hundred fifty μl of 125I-EGF (20 ng/ml, 3.7 mBq/μg) or125I-GBP in PBS containing 1% (w/v) BSA and 0.02% (w/v) NaN3 were added to each well and incubated at 22 °C for 5 h. After removing the supernatant, the cells were washed three times with PBS containing 0.1% BSA. The plate was left for drying up, after which the cells were lysed with 200 μl of 0.3 nNaOH and then counted using the liquid scintillation counter. Binding data were analyzed according to the method of Scatchard (22Scatchard G. Ann. N. Y. Acad. Sci. 1949; 51: 660-672Crossref Scopus (17801) Google Scholar). Human foreskin keratinocytes were incubated at 37 °C for 48 h under 5% CO2, and Sf9 cells were incubated at 25 °C for 48 h. Cells were stimulated with 5 nm of GBP or EGF at 25 °C for 5 min (23Vliet A.V.D. Hristova M. Cross C.E. Eiserich J.P. Goldkorn T. J. Biol. Chem. 1998; 273: 31860-31866Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (104) Google Scholar). After the treatment with the growth factors, cells were rinsed with ice cold PBS containing 1 mmNa3VO4 and were incubated with a lysis buffer (25 mm Hepes, 1% Triton X-100, 50 mm NaCl, 50 mm NaF, 5 mm EDTA, 10 nm ocadic acid, 0.1 mm Na3VO4, 1 mmp-amidinophenyl methylsulfonyl fluoride and 10 μg/ml each of aprotinin and leupeptin, pH 7.5) for 15 min on ice. Cell lysates were centrifuged at 15,000 × g for 30 min to remove insoluble material. The supernatant was incubated with an anti-EGFR antibody for 2 h at 4 °C then mixed with 20 μl of protein A-Sepharose beads and left for 1 h at 4 °C. The beads that bound the immunoprecipitates were washed three times with the lysis buffer. Protein samples of cell lysates were prepared for SDS-PAGE by incubating with 80 mm Tris-HCl buffer, pH 8.8, containing 1% SDS and 2.5% 2-mercaptoethanol in boiling water for 5 min and developed by the method of Laemmli (24Laemmli V.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207159) Google Scholar). Protein bands on SDS-PAGE gel were electrically transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane filter essentially according to Burnette (25Burnette W.N. Anal. Biochem. 1981; 112: 195-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (5912) Google Scholar). Membranes were blocked with 5% skim milk and then probed with primary antibody (monoclonal antibody against EGFR or phosphotyrosine (PY-20)), and detection was performed using the Vectastain ABC Elite Kit (Vector Laboratories). Human foreskin keratinocytes were plated into 96-well plates at an initial density of 1 × 104cells/well in 250 μl of DMEM medium, essentially according to the procedure of Sato et. al. (26Sato J.D. Le A.D. Kawamoto T. Meth. Enzymol. 1987; 146: 63-81Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar). Five μg of anti-EGFR antibody were added into each well and then incubated at 25 °C for 2 h. Following the preincubation, either GBP or EGF (5 nm) was added to the medium along with 1 μCi of [3H]thymidine. After incubating for 40 h, cells were washed three times with 0.15 m NaCl and lysed with 200 μl of 0.3 n NaOH, and then thymidine incorporation was counted using the liquid scintillation counter. Human foreskin keratinocytes were cultured in a culture flask, allowed to grow for 2 days in complete medium A at 37 °C under 5% CO2, and then serum-starved for 24 h in DMEM under the same condition. Cells were incubated with [biotin-Lys26]GBP (5 pmol/ml) at 25 °C for 5 min. The cells were washed extensively with 0.15 m NaCl and again incubated for 30 min with the UV cross-linker NHS-ASA (Pierce). For UV treatment, [biotin-Lys26]GBP and cells were irradiated with 100 mJ/cm2 short wavelength UV. Cells were then lysed in 300 μl of the lysis buffer. The lysate was clarified by 14,000 × g. The supernatant was then solubilized in SDS-electrophoresis sample buffer, separated on a SDS-polyacrylamide gel, and transferred to a polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. The membrane was probed with streptavidin-horseradish peroxidase conjugate (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Avidin-Affi-Gel 10 (Bio-Rad) fixed [biotin-Lys26]GBP (50 nmol/5 ml) as ligand was packed in a column and washed with 10-bed volumes of the lysis buffer. The Sf9 cell lysate was applied to the column. After washing the column with 5-bed volumes of the lysis buffer and PBS, the membrane protein with a molecular mass of 60 kDa was eluted with 1 μm GBP in PBS. GBP consists of three regions: the core region, which shares a high degree of similarity to the EGF C-terminal subdomain, and N- and C-terminal disordered regions. Because GBP lacks the N-terminal domain of EGF molecule, it was important to determine whether the N-terminal disordered six-amino acid chain of GBP contributes to its ability to promote cell growth activity. To check this possibility, derivatives of GBP lacking various numbers of amino acid residues from the N-terminal-six residues were prepared and tested for their abilities to stimulate DNA synthesis in human foreskin keratinocyte cells. The deletion of the N-terminal glutamic acid did not cause any significant decrease in cell growth activity, but further deletion of more than two residues lead to a drastic reduction in the activity (Fig.1), indicating that the N-terminal region, at least five of the six amino acid residues, are essential for exhibiting the mitogenic activity of GBP in the cultured cells through binding and activation of the receptor. Since it has been reported that the N-terminal subdomain of EGF is indispensable for organizing the structure for binding EGFR, it was interesting to examine whether or not GBP directly binds to the EGFR in keratinocyte cells. To characterize the GBP binding sites in human keratinocyte cells, competitive receptor binding experiments were carried out with125I-labeled EGF. GBP was able to block the binding of125I-EGF to EGFR, although the concentration difference between EGF and GBP required for competitive binding of125I-EGF to EGFR at the half-maximal competition level was about five orders of magnitude (Fig.2A). Comparison of the relative binding affinities of EGF and GBP against 125I-GBP showed that GBP (IC50 = 0.31 nm) was as strong as EGF (IC50 = 0.47 nm) in its ability to compete with 125I-GBP for binding to human keratinocyte cell membrane fractions (Fig. 2B). Scatchard plot analyses showed a single class of high affinity binding site for GBP. The dissociation constant for GBP (Kd = 0.12 nm, Fig. 2b) was not very much different from that of EGF (Kd = 0.03 nm, Fig.2a). Similar experiments with insect Sf9 cell membrane fractions showed that Sf9 cells contain a single class of binding site having a high affinity for GBP but a low affinity for EGF (Fig. 2,C and D). The Kd values for EGF and GBP calculated by Scatchard analysis were 0.64 nm(Fig. 2c) and 0.25 nm (Fig. 2d), respectively, which are comparable with that for EGFR in keratinocyte cells. Further competitive binding experiments were carried out with125I-GBP and the N-terminal deletion GBP analogs. As shown in Fig. 3, the deletion of the N-terminal glutamic acid did not change its ability to compete with125I-GBP for binding to EGFR in human keratinocytes, but further deletion of the N-terminal residue(s) lost their abilities as the competitor. These results are consistent with those in the mitogenic activity assays (Fig. 1). All the results of the receptor binding assays including Figs. 2 and 3 were interpreted as suggesting that GBP binds EGFR in human keratinocytes but binds a different receptor, GBP, in insect Sf9 cells. To explore further the interaction between GBP and EGFR in human keratinocytes, the ability of GBP to stimulate mitogenesis was tested in the presence of anti-EGFR antibody. Neither GBP nor EGF stimulated DNA synthesis in the keratinocytes when this antibody was present in the culture medium (Fig. 4). This indicates that GBP exerts its cell growth activity through binding with EGFR. Further, binding of GBP with keratinocyte EGFR was directly demonstrated by the use of biotin-labeled GBP as shown in Fig.5. To prepare the biotinylated GBP without losing the mitogenic activity, we synthesized a 26-amino acid GBP containing a C-terminal biotinylated Lys26. This [biotin-Lys26]GBP retained the cell growth promoting activity equivalent to the level of that found with intact GBP, while [biotin-Lys20]GBP lost the cell growth activity (Fig.5A). SDS-PAGE of keratinocyte membrane proteins, followed by visualization by streptavidin, showed that the bioactive [biotin-Lys26]GBP directly bound to EGFR (170 kDa), but the inactive [biotin-Lys20]GBP did not (Fig.5B).Figure 5Mitogenic activities (A) and binding (B) of biotinylated GBP. A,mitogenic activity was measured by the incorporation of [3H]thymidine into human foreskin keratinocytes during incubation with GBP, [biotin-Lys20]GBP, or [biotin-Lys26]GBP for 2 days. Data are given as means + S.D. for five separate measurements. B, the keratinocyte membrane preparation was incubated with each factor at 4 °C for 15 h in the presence and absence of unlabeled EGF. The receptor-ligand complex was cross-linked withN-hydroxysuccinimidyl-4-azidosalicylic acid (NHS-ASA) and analyzed by SDS-PAGE. The right membrane was stained with streptavidin-horseradish peroxidase conjugate, and the left one was probed with anti-EGFR antibody. Cell. 1995; 80: 213-223Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1440) Google Scholar). To investigate the basis for the mitogenic activity of GBP, we examined its ability to stimulate auto-phosphorylation of EGFR in keratinocyte cells and the GBP receptor in Sf9 cells. Equal amounts of protein extracts from keratinocytes and Sf9 cells were immunoprecipitated with anti-EGFR antibody. Then phosphorylation was detected by anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. When keratinocytes and Sf9 cells were stimulated by either EGF or GBP before the membrane preparation and the immunoprecipitation, GBP induced the tyrosine phosphorylation of the 170-kDa EGFR in keratinocyte cells, as did EGF. Both peptides also induced the phosphorylation of the 58-kDa protein (p58) in Sf9 cells (Fig.6). GBP showed a dose-dependent capacity to phosphorylate the proteins, 170 kDa in keratinocyte cells and 58 kDa in Sf9 cells; 0.1–10 nm GBP strongly phosphorylated the protein, whereas 100 nm GBP phosphorylated them to a much lesser extent (Fig.7).Figure 7Dose-dependent effects of GBP on EGFR (A) and GBPR (B). A, human keratinocyte cells were incubated with 0–100 nm GBP for 5 min. B, insect Sf9 cells were incubated with 0–100 nm GBP for 5 min. Following this, Western blotting was performed according to the procedures outlined in Fig. 6.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload Hi-res image Download (PPT) Final experiments were designed to test whether p58 possesses a GBP binding domain. The membrane fraction prepared from Sf9 cells pretreated with GBP was loaded onto an affinity column using biotinylated GBP as ligand. After washing the column well with PBS, 1 μm GBP in PBS eluted one major protein with a molecular mass of 60 kDa (p60), which is apparently bigger than p58. The affinity-purified p60 was subjected to SDS-PAGE, followed by Western blotting using anti-phosphotyrosine antibody. As shown in Fig.8, p60 did not cross-react with the phosphotyrosine antibody, indicating that p60 might be the GBP-binding subunit lacking tyrosine residue(s) to be phosphorylated. Based on these results, it is reasonable to propose that GBP receptor exists as a heterodimeric complex consisting of the p60 subunit with the GBP binding site and the p58 subunit with tyrosine residue(s) to be phosphorylated after binding of GBP. EGF is a single chain polypeptide of about 50 residues with three disulfide bonds. These disulfide bonds define three looped regions of which the N-terminal two-loop domains are indispensable to the mitogenic capacities of the molecules (17Heath W.F. Merrifield R.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. 1986; 83: 6367-6371Crossref PubMed Scopus (74) Google Scholar). Although NMR analyses revealed that the tertiary structure of GBP shares a striking similarity to the C-terminal loop region of EGF, it is apparent that GBP lacks the N-terminal loop region seen in EGF (13Aizawa T. Fujitani N. Hayakawa Y. Ohnishi A. Ohkubo T. Kawano K. Hikichi K. Nitta K. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 1887-1890Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). Instead of such a loop structure, GBP possesses a disordered N-terminal region consisting of six amino acid residues. It was interesting to examine whether this short N-terminal of GBP contributes to its mitogenic capabilities. The N-terminal Glu-deleted peptide has a mitogenic activity equivalent to that of the intact GBP, but a deletion of more than two amino acid residues from the N-terminal causes a drastic decrease of the biological activity (see Fig. 1). These results were interpreted as suggesting that the N-terminal region of GBP, at least five amino acid residues of a total six residues, is indispensable to its mitogenic activity. Losing the biological activity of GBP by the deletion of its N-terminal residues could be due to a greatly diminished affinity for its receptor in keratinocytes. This interpretation is partly supported by the receptor binding assays; GBP showed the ability to compete with 125I-EGF in the competitive binding experiment (see Fig. 3), although the concentration of GBP required for the inhibition of 125I-EGF binding to EGFR is much more than that of EGF itself. In keratinocyte cells,125I-GBP specifically bound to a certain receptor. This receptor is likely to be EGFR since the binding of 125I-GBP was completely blocked by EGF. Further, neutralization of EGFR by anti-EGFR antibody blocked the stimulation of mitogenesis of keratinocyte cells by GBP (see Fig. 4). The conclusive evidence was provided by labeling EGFR with biotin-GBP; 170-kDa EGFR was labeled with biotin-GBP in the absence of EGF but was not in the presence of EGF (see Fig. 5). Based on a series of such results, it is reasonable to conclude that GBP could exert the proliferative effect on human keratinocyte cells through direct binding of the EGFR. EGFR signaling is initiated by ligand binding, receptor dimerization, and auto-phosphorylation to create phosphotyrosine residues (27Heldin C. Cell. 1995; 80: 213-223Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (1440) Google Scholar). It was noteworthy to check whether auto-phosphorylation of tyrosine residues of EGFR occurred following incubation of keratinocyte cells with GBP. As with EGF, GBP induced the phosphorylation of the 170-kDa EGFR in a dose-dependent manner (Figs. 6 and 7). The tyrosine-phosphorylation of EGFR was induced by GBP as well as EGF at concentrations ranging up to 10 nm, but phosphorylation was drastically reduced by concentrations greater than 10 nm. The transient desensitization of EGFR with the high concentration of EGF has been reported (28Willey H.S. J. Cell Biol. 1988; 107: 801-810Crossref PubMed Scopus (168) Google Scholar). This down-regulation of EGFR has been attributed to serine and/or threonine residue phosphorylations by Ca2+/calmodulin-dependent kinase II (CaM kinase II) (29Feinmesser R.L. Wicks S.J. Taverner C.J. Chantry A. J. Biol. Chem. 1999; 274: 16168-16173Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar). In view of the receptor signaling pattern, GBP stimulates EGFR in keratinocyte cells just as EGF does. Similar experiments with Sf9 cells using anti-EGFR and anti-phosphotyrosine antibodies showed that a 58-kDa protein (p58) sharing the similar antigenicity with the extracellular domain of EGFR is selectively phosphorylated upon GBP-induced stimulation. At present, we do not know whether or not p58 itself possesses a tyrosine kinase activity that catalyzes auto-phosphorylation under the influence of GBP similar to the activation of EGFR by EGF. However, by analogy with the EGF signal transduction, it is likely that p58 will be found to be auto-phosphorylated at tyrosine residue(s) by GBP, and that the tyrosine-phosphorylation triggers off a series of intracellular signaling events. If this were true, it would mean that GBP and EGF share a close functional homology. However, it seems that GBP does not bind directly to p58 but binds to another membrane protein with a molecular mass of 60 kDa (p60), which does not have a cross-reactivity against the anti-EGFR antibody. Binding between GBP and p60 was demonstrated using a biotinylated GBP ligand affinity chromatography (see Fig. 8) and direct labeling with biotinylated GBP or 125I-GBP (data not presented). Further, similar cross-linking experiments using 125I-EGF demonstrated direct binding between EGF and a Sf9 membrane protein with a molecular mass of ∼60 kDa (data not presented). Given a plausible functional linkage between p58 and p60, it is reasonable to propose that GBP receptor is composed of a dimeric complex, p60 with the GBP biding site and p58 with the tyrosine residues, to be phosphorylated after binding of GBP. It is therefore apparent that the structure of GBP receptors in insect Sf9 cells is completely different from EGFR even though the cell growth promoting activity and the structure of GBP share significant similarities with EGF. Several peptides structurally related to GBP have been identified in some lepidopteran insects. These are: paralytic peptide (PP), plasmatocyte spreading peptide (PSP), and cardioactive peptide. It has been demonstrated that GBP and PSP cause rapid paralysis in P. separata armyworm larvae (30Strand M.R. Hayakawa Y. Clark K.D J. Insect Physiol. 2000; 46: 817-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar), GBP and PP stimulate plasmatocyte spreading and aggregation (30Strand M.R. Hayakawa Y. Clark K.D J. Insect Physiol. 2000; 46: 817-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar, 31Wang Y. Jiang H. Kanost M.R. Insect Biochem. Mol. Biol. 1999; 29: 1075-1086Crossref PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), and PSP retards larval growth of the armyworm (30Strand M.R. Hayakawa Y. Clark K.D J. Insect Physiol. 2000; 46: 817-824Crossref PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar). Further, PSP stimulates the proliferation of Sf9 cells as GBP does. 2A. Ohnishi and Y. Hayakawa, unpublished results.Based on these results, it is reasonable to propose that all these peptides should be categorized in the same family of insect cytokines. Since there has been no report on the receptors of insect cytokines or cell growth factors, the characterizations of the GBP receptor in Sf9 cells will undoubtedly contribute to our understanding of the roles played by the GBP signaling pathway in insects. Further, GBP and GBP receptor could be useful models to explore the detailed interaction between EGF and EGFR because GBP itself and GBP receptor binding domain are less than half-sizes of EGF and EGFR, respectively.

A variety of eucaryotic polypeptide growth factors are synthesized as transmembrane precursors. Many of these precursors are released from plasma membranes by proteolytic cleavage and converted into soluble mature proteins. A number of studies, however, indicate that bound growth factor precursors can be biologically active, suggesting a role for these membrane-associated ligands in cell-cell communication. Secreted heregulin is a 45-kDa growth factor with homology to epidermal growth factor. This growth factor binds directly to HER-3 and HER-4 and activates heterodimeric receptor complexes composed of the type I receptor tyrosine kinases,i.e. HER-1, HER-2, HER-3, and HER-4. Heregulin was originally detected in the conditioned medium of the human breast cancer cell line MDA-MB-231 and purified based on its ability to stimulate phosphorylation of p185HER-2/neu. In the current study, the biologic activity of plasma membrane-anchored heregulin was evaluated in human breast cells. Transmembrane heregulin binds to cells expressing p180HER-3, induces p185HER-2/neu phosphorylation, and increases DNA synthesis in cells overexpressing the HER-2/neu gene product. In addition, when cells containing heregulin receptors are co-cultured with heregulin-producing cells, specific in vivo associations are observed. This study demonstrates that transmembrane heregulin is functionally active and suggest it is capable of playing a role in cell-cell communication and subsequent signal transduction in vivo. In this study, results are presented showing that membrane-bound heregulin can be detected on the surface of MDA-MB-231 human breast cancer cells and that this form of the molecule can establish contact with HER-2/neu-expressing cells. These interactions can be specifically blocked by soluble 7-kDa rHRG, full-length rHRG, or anti-HER-2 antibodies. Plasma membranes isolated from HRG-producing MDA-MB-231 cells are capable of activating p185HER-2/neu in both HER-2/neu-non-overexpressing and HER-2/neu-overexpressing human breast cell lines. These data demonstrate that transmembrane heregulin produced by human breast cancer cells is a functional ligand and suggest that it may be capable of activating receptors in neighboring cells via a juxtacrine mechanism. In brief, 106 to 108 cells were harvested from subconfluent cultures using a 1× solution of Versene (Life Technologies, Inc.), containing protease inhibitors as follows: 2 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 0.2 mg/ml trypsin inhibitor, 0.15 units/ml aprotinin, 1 mg/ml pepstatin A, 10 mm bestatin, 1 mm N-ethylmaleimide, 20 mm leupeptin, and 1 mm EDTA. Cells were pelleted at 1,000 × g for 10 min, resuspended in 5 ml of buffer A (10 nm Tris, pH 7.4, plus 250 mmsucrose and a mixture of protease inhibitors as above), and then washed twice using the same procedure. The cell pellet was resuspended in buffer A in a 1:10 w/v ratio and homogenized (Dounce homogenizer) until a 80–90% cell rupture was observed under the inverted microscope (Diaphot, Nikon). Centrifugation of the cell homogenate (H) at 1,000 × g for 10 min yielded the pellet (P1). The resultant supernatant (S1) from this centrifugation was then spun at 15,000 × g for 50 min to obtain the pellet (P2) and supernatant (S2). Microsomes (M) were pelleted by spinning S2 at 105,000 × g for 1 h; the supernatant of this last centrifugation consists of cell cytoplasm (Cyt). Plasma membranes (PM) were purified from the microsomal fraction using a self-generating density gradient made of 17% Percoll (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) in 25 ml of buffer A. For this, the microsomal fraction was resuspended in Percoll and centrifuged at 35,000 × g for 50 min. A tube containing density marker beads was run in parallel to monitor density banding. The PM fraction was collected at a typical density of 1.04–1.045 mg/ml. Membranes were further purified by loading the PM fraction on top of a 50% sucrose step cushion. After centrifugation at 105,000 × g for 1 h, plasma membranes were collected at the interphase and resuspended in 12 ml of water for a further centrifugation at 105,000 × g for 60 min. Purified PM were then obtained as a thin layer on top of the Percoll pellet and resuspended in 0.2–0.4 ml of water for their storage at −80 °C. All the steps were performed at 4 °C under sterile conditions. Marker enzymes were used for assessment of PM purity and possible cross-contamination. The activity of the next set of enzymes was quantitated: (a) Na+,K+-ATPase as a PM marker (36Scharschmidt B.F. Keeffe E.B. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1981; 646: 369-381Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar), (b) succinate-cytochrome c reductase as a marker for the inner mitochondrial membrane (37Meier P.J. Boyer J.L. Methods Enzymol. 1990; 192: 534-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar), (c) glucose-6-phosphatase to detect possible endoplasmic reticulum contamination (37Meier P.J. Boyer J.L. Methods Enzymol. 1990; 192: 534-545Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 38Lin P.H. Selinfreund R. Wharton W. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 198: 251-259Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar), and (d) acid phosphatase for lysosomes (38Lin P.H. Selinfreund R. Wharton W. Methods Enzymol. 1991; 198: 251-259Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar). The total protein concentration in each fraction was determined by the BCA protein assay (Pierce) as indicated by the manufacturer. Specific activities were calculated as micromoles of product/min × mg of protein. MCF-7 cells (1.0 × 105) were seeded in each well of a 24-well plate and allowed to grow for 4 days (to ∼90% confluence) in 50% Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, 50% Ham's F-12 medium containing 10% FBS. The cells were serum-starved for 1.5 h prior to stimulation with either recombinant heregulin or MDA-MB-231 plasma membranes. A p185HER-2/neu phosphorylation dose-response curve was generated by treating the cells with the indicated concentrations of rHRG-β1-(177–244) for 8 min at room temperature. Cells were also treated in parallel with dilutions of the MDA-MB-231 PM suspension. All sample dilutions were made in medium containing 0.1% BSA. Following stimulation, the supernatants were removed and phosphorylation was stopped by adding 100 μl of SDS sample buffer to each well. Tyrosine-phosphorylated proteins were detected by Western blot using an anti-phosphotyrosine horseradish peroxidase conjugate (Transduction Laboratories) and a chemiluminescent substrate (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Specific p185 phosphorylation was quantitated by densitometry. Data were analyzed using a non-linear least squares regression algorithm (39Munson P.J. Rodbard D. Anal. Biochem. 1980; 107: 220-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (7772) Google Scholar). MDA-MB-231 and MCF-7 RV/H2 samples (20 μg/lane) obtained from the cell fractionation procedure were mixed in a 1:1 ratio with SDS sample buffer, boiled for 5 min, and run in a 8% Tris-glycine gel (Novex). The protein concentration of the lysates was determined using a BCA protein assay (Pierce). A Western blot of the gel was probed using the anti-HRG-α C-20 antibody (Santa Cruz Biotechnology). Following incubation with the secondary antibody, consisting of a streptavidin-horseradish peroxidase conjugate (Calbiochem), the blot was visualized with a chemiluminescent substrate (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech). Blocking of the activation of HER-2/neu tyrosine kinase activity by transmembrane-HRG in the plasma membrane of MDA-MB-231 cells was examined by Western blot analysis. HER-2/neu-overexpressing breast cell lines SK-BR-3, MCF-7 RV/H2, and MCF-7 parentals were cultured in six-well plates using 1× RPMI medium (10% FBS). Subconfluent cultures were serum-starved for 2 h before treatment as indicated in Fig. 5. The anti-receptor antibodies were added to the cells before treatment with either form of the ligand. Pre-incubation with the antibodies was allowed for 30 min at room temperature prior to treatment. Anti-HRG antibodies were pre-incubated with the ligand or PM solutions. After incubation at room temperature with either form of HRG for approximately 8 min, cells were washed once with a 20 mm glycine, 150 mm NaCl, pH 2.5, buffer, followed by two washes with cold PBS, after which 0.2 ml of lysis buffer (radioimmune precipitation buffer) were immediately added. Cell lysis was allowed for 10 min on ice, and cells were scraped from the wells using a rubber policeman. Lysates were cleared by centrifugation and kept at −80 °C. Lysates (200 mg of total protein) were incubated overnight at 4 °C with either 3 μl of the anti-p185HER-2/neu polyclonal antibody R60 (32Slamon D.J. Godolphin W. Jones L.A. Holt J.A. Wong S.G. Keith D.E. Levin W.J. Stuart S.G. Udove J. Ullrich A. Press M.F. Immunoprecipitated proteins were pelleted by brief centrifugation, washed extensively with lysis buffer, and processed for electrophoresis and Western blot analysis. MCF-7 cells were seeded (1.0 × 105) in each well of a 24-well plate and grown to ∼80% confluence in 50% Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium, 50% Ham's F-12 medium containing 10% FBS. The cells were washed briefly with ice-cold medium containing 0.1% BSA and placed on ice. All subsequent steps were performed at 0–4 °C. A competitive displacement curve for HRG binding was generated by incubating the MCF-7 cells with 50 × 103 cpm 125I-labeled rHRG-β1-(177–244) (specific activity 213 mCi/pmol), in the presence of the indicated concentrations of unlabeled rHRG-β1-(177–244). The effect of membrane-bound heregulin on DNA synthesis was evaluated on a [3H]thymidine incorporation assay. In brief, 5 × 103 cells were plated in multiscreen HATF 96-well plates (Millipore) using RPMI medium containing 1% FBS. After 24 h at 37 °C in a 5% CO2 atmosphere, cells were treated as indicated and reincubated for 2 more days under the same conditions, after which received a 2-μCi pulse of [3H]thymidine in 20 μl of culture medium. Thymidine incorporation was stopped after 4 h of incubation by filtration and washing of the wells twice with PBS. DNA was precipitated with ice-cold 5% trichloroacetic acid, and the [3H]thymidine incorporated by the cells was measured in a scintillation counter. Heregulin precursors on the plasma membranes of the HRG-producing cell line MDA-MB-231 were identified using immunocytochemical techniques (Fig. 1). When MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with either polyclonal (Fig. 1) or monoclonal (data not shown) anti-HRG antibodies, intense membrane-associated staining on the surface was observed (Fig. 1,bottom right panel). The HRG-positive staining (red fluorescence) surrounded the nuclei (counterstained in blue), always associated with plasma membranes, and possibly also with the cytoplasm (Fig. 1,bottom right). An anti-p185HER-2/neu antibody was used to assess the patterns and intensities of HER-2/neu receptor expression on these same two cell lines (Fig. 1, upper panels). Conversely, there was little or no fluorescence on the plasma membranes of the single-copy, low HER-2/neu-expressing MDA-MB-231 cells (upper right panel). The human multidrug resistance P-glycoprotein (P-gp), a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) superfamily of transporters, is frequently responsible for the failure of chemotherapy by virtue of its ability to export hydrophobic cytotoxic drugs from cells. Elucidating the inter- and intramolecular interactions of this protein is critical to understanding its cellular function and mechanism of action. Toward this end, we have used both biochemical and genetic techniques to probe potential oligomerization interactions of P-gp. Differentially epitope-tagged P-gp molecules did not co-immunoprecipitate when co-expressed in HEK293 cells or when co-translated in vitro, demonstrating that P-gp is monomeric in both the presence and absence of detergents. The two cytoplasmic domains of P-gp did not interact with each other in vivo when co-expressed as gene fusions in yeast. In contrast, the homologous domains of the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP), which reside on separate polypeptides and must form a heterodimeric transporter (TAP1/TAP2), did interact in this system, suggesting a role for these domains in TAP dimerization. Implications for understanding the subunit organization of ABC transporters are discussed. The human multidrug resistance P-glycoprotein (P-gp), a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) superfamily of transporters, is frequently responsible for the failure of chemotherapy by virtue of its ability to export hydrophobic cytotoxic drugs from cells. Elucidating the inter- and intramolecular interactions of this protein is critical to understanding its cellular function and mechanism of action. Toward this end, we have used both biochemical and genetic techniques to probe potential oligomerization interactions of P-gp. Differentially epitope-tagged P-gp molecules did not co-immunoprecipitate when co-expressed in HEK293 cells or when co-translated in vitro, demonstrating that P-gp is monomeric in both the presence and absence of detergents. The two cytoplasmic domains of P-gp did not interact with each other in vivo when co-expressed as gene fusions in yeast. In contrast, the homologous domains of the transporter associated with antigen processing (TAP), which reside on separate polypeptides and must form a heterodimeric transporter (TAP1/TAP2), did interact in this system, suggesting a role for these domains in TAP dimerization. Implications for understanding the subunit organization of ABC transporters are discussed. P-glycoprotein cystic fibrosis transmembrane regulator multidrug resistance nucleotide-binding domain phosphate-buffered saline polymerase chain reaction transporter associated with antigen presentation polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis ATP-binding cassette The product of the human MDR1 gene, P-glycoprotein (P-gp),1 is an integral membrane protein that can confer multidrug resistance on cells and tumors (reviewed in Ref. 1Gottesman M.M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1993; 62: 385-427Crossref PubMed Scopus (3567) Google Scholar). P-gp is an ATP-dependent efflux pump that transports an extraordinary range of hydrophobic substrates out of the cell and has also been implicated in the regulation of a heterologous cell swelling-activated chloride channel (reviewed in Ref. 2Bond T.D. Valverde M.A. Higgins C.F. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1998; 508: 333-340Crossref Scopus (40) Google Scholar). P-gp is a member of the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) superfamily of transporters and has the characteristic architecture of this protein family: two large cytoplasmic nucleotide-binding domains (NBDs) and two hydrophobic transmembrane domains. The first cytoplasmic domain includes a linker region that can be phosphorylated by protein kinase C. Phosphorylation of the linker has little or no effect on drug transport (3Goodfellow H.R. Sardini A. Ruetz S. Callaghan R. Gros P. McNaughton P.A. Higgins C.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 13668-13674Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (114) Google Scholar, 4Germann U.A. Chambers T.C. Ambudkar S.V. Licht T. Cardarelli C. Pastan I. Gottesman M.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1708-1716Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (158) Google Scholar) but plays a role in modulation of heterologous ion channel activity by P-gp (2Bond T.D. Valverde M.A. Higgins C.F. J. Physiol. (Lond.). 1998; 508: 333-340Crossref Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 5Hardy S.P. Goodfellow H.R. Valverde M.A. Gill D.R. Sepulveda V. Higgins C.F. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 68-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar). Biochemical and biophysical techniques have previously been employed to investigate the oligomeric structure of P-gp, with ambiguous results. Freeze-fracture electron micrographs of membranes containing overexpressed P-gp showed aggregates in the plasma membrane corresponding to an oligomeric state (6Arsenault A.L. Ling V. Kartner N. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1988; 938: 315-321Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). Radiation inactivation (7Boscoboinik D. Debanne M.T. Stafford A.R. Jung C.Y. Gupta R.S. Epand R.M. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1990; 1027: 225-228Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar) yielded an apparent molecular mass of 250 kDa for P-gp, corresponding to approximately a dimer, and chemical cross-linking indicated a small proportion of a 340-kDa form (8Naito M. Tsuruo T. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1992; 185: 284-290Crossref PubMed Scopus (34) Google Scholar). Sedimentation velocity centrifugation through sucrose gradients also indicated an oligomeric state (9Poruchynsky M.S. Ling V. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 4163-4174Crossref PubMed Scopus (51) Google Scholar), although this depended upon the detergent used and could not distinguish whether P-gp might be interacting with heterologous proteins rather than sedimenting as an oligomer. In brain capillaries and renal brush border membranes, radiation inactivation and mobility of Triton X-solubilized protein on native gels also suggested a possible dimer (10Jette L. Potier M. Beliveau R. Biochemistry. 1997; 36: 13929-13937Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). In contrast, a molecular complementation approach suggested that the functional unit of P-gp is a monomer (11Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 20986-20989Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (107) Google Scholar). Single-particle electron microscopy of purified reconstituted P-gp also showed a size for the functional protein particle most consistent with a monomeric form (12Rosenberg M.F. Callaghan R. Ford R.C. Higgins C.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10685-10694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (339) Google Scholar), and labeling with lectin-gold particles indicated a single site of glycosylation on each P-gp particle, consistent with a monomer (12Rosenberg M.F. Callaghan R. Ford R.C. Higgins C.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10685-10694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (339) Google Scholar). As the strategies used to date are subject to a number of caveats or may reflect the fortuitous interaction of the target with other proteins and aggregation due to overexpression, we have used a combination of in vitro and in vivo techniques to assess the oligomeric state of P-glycoprotein, as well as potential intramolecular interactions between the cytoplasmic nucleotide-binding domains of the protein. Restriction digests, polymerase chain reaction (PCR), and other manipulations of DNA were performed according to standard protocols. DNA was introduced into Escherichia coli SureTM cells (Stratagene) by electroporation. Transformed cells were grown in Luria-Bertani broth supplemented with 100 μg/ml ampicillin. Plasmid DNA was prepared by alkaline lysis (Qiagen). Double-stranded plasmid DNA was sequenced by the automated dye-terminator method (ABI PRISMTM 377 DNA Sequencer, PerkinElmer Life Sciences). HEK293 cells (Imperial Cancer Research Fund Cell Culture Facility, Clare Hall, UK) were maintained in monolayers in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium supplemented with 2 mm l-glutamine, 100 units/ml penicillin, 0.1 mg/ml streptomycin, and 10% fetal calf serum. Myc (EEQKLISEEDL) and FLAG (DYKDDDDK) epitope tags were added to the C terminus of P-gp by oligonucleotide-directed mutagenesis of the human MDR1 gene. A PstI-SalI fragment of MDR1 encoding the C terminus of the protein was cloned into the pAlter vector and mutagenesis performed according to the Altered Sites procedure (Promega). The mutagenic oligonucleotide was designed to replace the stop codon of MDR1 with the epitope tag followed by an in-frame stop codon and a novel AatII restriction site to facilitate identification of the tagged MDR1 genes. Sequencing of the mutant plasmids confirmed the presence of the tags and demonstrated that no other mutations had been introduced. The mutated 480-base pair PstI-SalI fragment was then used to replace the corresponding fragment of the wild type MDR1sequence in plasmid pMDR7 (13Valverde M.A. Diaz M. Sepulveda F.V. Gill D.R. Hyde S.C. Higgins C.F. Nature. 1992; 355: 830-833Crossref PubMed Scopus (524) Google Scholar) to regenerate the full-length P-gp coding sequence with the appropriate epitope tags (pMDR7.M and pMDR7.F, respectively). The pMDR7 plasmid has a T7 promoter for in vitro expression. For in vivo studies, the taggedMDR1 fragments were cloned into pcDNA3 (Invitrogen), which contains a cytomegalovirus promoter, generating pcMDR.M (myc tagged) and pcMDR.F (FLAG-tagged). Plasmids were verified by restriction analysis and DNA sequencing. For in vitro studies, proteins encoded by the pMDR7.M and pMDR7.F plasmids were expressed using the rabbit reticulocyte lysate-coupled transcription/translation system (Promega). Reactions were incubated at 30 °C for 1.5 h in the presence of [35S]methionine. Labeled proteins were separated by SDS-PAGE (14Laemmli U.K. Nature. 1970; 227: 680-685Crossref PubMed Scopus (207460) Google Scholar) and detected by autoradiography. Dynabeads cross-linked with the anti-myc or anti-FLAG antibodies were used for immunoprecipitations. The beads were first coated with either themyc or FLAG antibodies (1.5 μg/107 beads) by cross-linking using 20 mm dimethylpimelimidate in 0.2m triethanolamine at pH 9 for 45 min at room temperature. The beads were then washed in triethanolamine for 2 h, washed three times in phosphate-buffered saline (PBS), and stored at 4 °C. For in vitro immunoprecipitation, Myc and FLAG-tagged P-gps were co-expressed and 35S-labeled in the complete transcription-translation system. Dynabeads cross-linked with themyc antibody were added to the labeled protein and incubated for 2 h at 4 °C with continuous slow rotation. The Dynabeads were then harvested magnetically and washed extensively with PBS before eluting bound proteins in 50 μl of 1% SDS. The eluate was diluted to 500 μl with PBS. For the second immunoprecipitation, Dynabeads cross-linked with the FLAG antibody were added to the eluate and immunoprecipitation performed as described above. After harvesting and washing, bound proteins were eluted with 50 μl of Laemmli sample buffer and analyzed by SDS-PAGE and autoradiography. For in vivo immunoprecipitations, epitope-tagged proteins encoded by plasmids pcMDR.M and pcMDR.F were expressed in HEK293 cells. Plasmid DNA (5 μg) was complexed with 20 μl of Lipofectin (Life Technologies, Inc.) in 2 ml of Opti-MEM (Life Technologies, Inc.) for 10 min at room temperature. The mixture was added to cells grown to ∼80% confluence in 35-mm wells and incubated for 5 h. Cells were returned to Dulbecco's modified Eagles' medium for a further 48-h incubation and then lysed in solubilization buffer (150 mm NaCl, 50 mm Tris-HCl, 0.1 mmphenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 1 mm benzamidine, 20 μg/ml aprotinin, 1 mm EDTA, pH 7.4) containing, as appropriate, between 0.5 and 4% detergent (either Nonidet P-40, dodecyl maltoside, or Triton X-100). Lysates were incubated on ice for 1 h and then centrifuged at 100,000 × g for 1 h to sediment insoluble material. The supernatants were incubated overnight at 4 °C with continuous slow rotation with 150 μl of Dynabeads cross-linked with the anti-myc antibody. Dynabeads were harvested magnetically and washed in solubilization buffer. Bound proteins were eluted in 50 μl of Laemmli sample buffer. Immunoprecipitated proteins were analyzed by SDS-PAGE and detected by immunoblotting with the anti-FLAG or anti-myc antibody. Proteins were separated by SDS-polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis. Gels of radiolabeled proteins were fixed in 25% isopropanol, 10% acetic acid for 30 min, incubated in AmplifyTM (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) for 30 min, dried, and exposed for 1–24 h. Unlabeled proteins were detected by immunoblotting, performed as described previously (15Towbin H. Staehelin T. Gordon J. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1979; 76: 4350-4354Crossref PubMed Scopus (44931) Google Scholar) using enhanced chemiluminescence detection (Amersham Pharmacia Biotech) of horseradish peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibodies. Primary antibodies were M2 anti-FLAG (IBI Kodak) and 9E10 anti-myc (Imperial Cancer Research Fund Hybridoma Unit). The PCR was used to amplify, from plasmid DNA, sequences encoding the cytoplasmic domains of wild type P-gp and the P-gp-8E mutant in which phosphorylatable serine and threonine residues are replaced by glutamates (5Hardy S.P. Goodfellow H.R. Valverde M.A. Gill D.R. Sepulveda V. Higgins C.F. EMBO J. 1995; 14: 68-75Crossref PubMed Scopus (196) Google Scholar). As controls, the cytoplasmic domains of related ABC transporter proteins, TAP1, TAP2, and CFTR (Table I), were also amplified. PCR primers were designed to add restriction endonuclease recognition sequences for EcoRI and XhoI to facilitate directional cloning. The PCR products were cloned into the yeast two-hybrid vectors pEG202 and pJG4–5 to generate in-frame gene fusions with the LexA DNA binding domain and the “acid blob” transcriptional activation domain, respectively (16Gyuris J. Oligonucleotide-directed mutagenesis was used to introduce short epitope tags (mycand FLAG) to the C terminus of P-gp. Cytotoxicity tests for ability to confer drug resistance demonstrated that addition of these tags did not affect the function of P-gp (data not shown). [35S]Methionine-radiolabeled myc- and FLAG-tagged P-gps were co-expressed in vitro in a rabbit reticulocyte system and sequentially immunoprecipitated with antibody cross-linked Dynabeads. Sequential immunoprecipitation with anti-myc and anti-FLAG antibodies (myc/FLAG) gave no recovery of P-gp-FLAG in the final immunoprecipitate (Fig.1). In contrast, P-gp was recovered in the second precipitation of positive control reactions in which anti-myc antibody was used in both precipitation steps (myc/myc). This suggests that the two differentially tagged populations of P-gp do not associate with each other and that P-gp is monomeric in the absence of detergent. To ascertain whether P-gp is also a monomer in vivo, Myc- and FLAG-tagged P-gps were co-expressed in HEK293 cells by transient transfection. Epitope-tagged P-gps were recovered in immunoprecipitates from cell lysates prepared in the presence of varied concentrations of several different detergents: dodecyl-β-maltoside, Nonidet P-40, or Triton X-100 (Fig. 2). In controls, when the anti-myc antibody was used for both immunoprecipitation and immunoblotting (myc/myc), P-gp was recovered with each detergent at all the concentrations used, demonstrating the efficacy of the procedure. No P-gp was detected on immunoblots with the anti-FLAG antibody following immunoprecipitation with the anti-myc antibody under any conditions (myc/FLAG). Experiments carried out in reverse using the anti-FLAG antibody for immunoprecipitation and anti-mycantibody for immunoblotting yielded similar results (data not shown). The inability to co-immunoprecipitate FLAG-tagged P-gp with themyc-tagged P-gp in these experiments indicated that the two forms of P-gp did not associate, suggesting that P-gp in the membranes is a monomer. To determine whether P-gp oligomerizes in the absence of detergents and to assess the possibility of very weak or transient interactions, we tested the soluble domains of P-gp in the yeast two-hybrid system. The large cytoplasmic domains of P-gp were expressed as fusion proteins (Table I) as were the cytoplasmic domains of two other ABC transporters, CFTR and TAP, which served as controls. Fusion proteins were expressed singly in yeast and tested for expression, nuclear localization, and DNA binding activity (for binding domain fusions) to exclude autoactivation of reporter genes, as described previously (17Golemis E. Fusion proteins were then co-expressed in pairwise combinations and tested for interaction by assaying β-galactosidase and leucine reporters. All fusions were shown to be capable of positive interaction with other fusion proteins in related studies (data not shown). No combination of wild-type P-glycoprotein cytoplasmic domains produced a detectable interaction with either reporter gene (TableII). Interestingly, the P-gp-8E mutant, derived from a form of P-gp generated by site-directed mutagenesis to study the effects of phosphorylation of the linker region, interacted weakly with the C-terminal cytoplasmic domain of P-gp in the more sensitive leucine assay. Efforts to examine the oligomerization of P-gp have been hampered by the technical difficulties of studying protein-protein interactions of integral membrane proteins. The detergents used to solubilize membrane proteins may give rise to protein aggregates or disrupt normal associations. For these reasons, we chose to conduct oligomerization experiments both in the presence and absence of a variety of detergents. Expression of tagged P-gps in vitro in the absence of microsomal membranes obviates the need for detergent solubilization. To complement this approach, we investigated P-gp oligomerization in vivo, using a number of detergents in an attempt to control for detergent-specific effects. Detergents with differing properties in terms of head groups, hydrocarbon chain length, and critical micellar concentration were used for solubilization. Concentrations of 0.5–4% were used for each detergent, enabling efficient solubilization of P-gp and a wide enough range of concentrations to examine possible artifactual aggregation of the protein. We consistently isolated P-gp as a monomer in vitroand in vivo under all conditions tested. In vivo two-hybrid analysis allowed us to test for possible weak dimerization interactions between cytoplasmic domains on individual molecules as well as intramolecular interactions between the two cytoplasmic domains of a single molecule. The latter type of interaction could have both structural and mechanistic implications. Although the yeast two-hybrid system provides an extremely sensitive assay for interaction, allowing detection of weak and/or transient protein-protein interactions, we were unable to detect interaction between the cytoplasmic domains of P-gp or of CFTR. These results suggest that dimerization does not occur via direct interaction of the cytoplasmic domains of these ABC transporters. In contrast, interaction was observed between TAP1 and TAP2, which represent discrete subunits that upon heterodimerization constitute the four-domain structure present in a single monomer of P-gp or CFTR. While a monomer is apparently sufficient for P-gp activity (21Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 27488-27492Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (61) Google Scholar), TAP activity requires both the TAP1 and TAP2 subunits, each consisting of one membrane domain and one cytoplasmic domain (NBD). The interaction of TAP cytoplasmic domains suggests that these regions may be directly involved in TAP1/TAP2 dimerization. The absence of cytoplasmic domain interaction for P-gp is consistent with the low resolution structure of P-gp (12Rosenberg M.F. Callaghan R. Ford R.C. Higgins C.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1997; 272: 10685-10694Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (339) Google Scholar) in which two distinct lobes, predicted to be the two cytoplasmic domains, are observed. However, intramolecular interactions between cytoplasmic domains of P-gp may occur under certain conditions, as implied by the weak interaction that we observe when a pseudo-phosphorylated form of cytoplasmic domain 1 is used in interaction assays. A recent study (22Loo T.W. Clarke D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 39272-39278Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (134) Google Scholar) suggests that, at least during part of the reaction cycle, the two nucleotide-binding domains of P-gp are in close proximity to one another, as they could be chemically cross-linked. Interestingly, the cross-linking only occurred at 37 °C and was inhibited by ATP, suggesting a role for structural flexibility and substrate-induced conformational change. Our data suggest a model in which four-domain ABC transporters, such as P-gp and CFTR, are normally monomeric, whereas two-domain ABC transporters, such as TAP, may dimerize through direct protein-protein interaction to form a paradigmatic, four-domain ABC protein. However, the data do not rule out the possibility that four-domain transporters may oligomerize through indirect interaction. A recent paper by Wang and colleagues (23Wang S. Yue H. Derin R.B. Guggino W.B. Li M. Cell. 2000; 103: 169-179Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar) identifies a protein, CAP70, which interacts with CFTR, facilitating oligomerization and modulating CFTR channel activity. This interaction requires both ATP and phosphorylation of the R domain and yields a more active channel configuration. Likewise, P-gp may be regulated by oligomerization in response to effectors or via specific binding proteins. Such interactions may account for at least some of the cases in which apparent P-gp oligomers have been observed. The two-hybrid interaction reagents were the generous gift of Lauren Ha and Roger Brent.
